IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases are becoming more prevalent as our population ages, and the societal impact of these diseases is increasing in parallel due to the current lack of effective treatments. This Keystone Symposia conference, along with a joint conference on Neuroimmune Interactions, offers a unique opportunity to convene scientific experts in neuroscience, immunology and drug discovery to address these challenges. These conferences feature academic, industrial and governmental researchers and will facilitate the sharing of results as well as drive discussions that will define scientific frontiers in neurodegenerative disease research in the coming years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroimmunology is a rapidly growing field at the intersection of neurobiology and immunology that has important implications for the treatment of disorders of the central nervous system (CNS), the gut and other tissues. This Keystone Symposia conference, along with a joint conference on Neurodegenerative Diseases, brings together experts on neuroscience, immunology, genomics, microbe-host interactions and drug development. Providing a forum for interactions among these groups of researchers will promote scientific cross-fertilization to accelerate research in the neuroimmunology field and support the development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innate immune system is our first line of defense against infection and given the expanding scope of pathogens in our global ecosystem, it has become essential to understand the complex mechanisms of innate immunity. This Keystone Symposia conference will feature the latest insights on pathogen sensing, immune signaling and their connections to health and disease and will highlight the latest technologies for exploring these systems in greater detail. By bringing together researchers from academia and industry, the conference will also provide a unique opportunity to optimize targeting innate immunity pathways to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Gonorrhea remains a worldwide public health problem given the incidence of disease (87 million cases/year) and the emergence of Neisseria gonorrhoeae strains resistant to currently used antibiotics. The MtrCDE efflux pump plays a critical role in development of antibiotic resistance expressed by N. gonorrhoeae, and the work proposed herein will address how the genes encoding the efflux pump are regulated at the level of transcription and define the structure-function relationships of the MtrD transporter protein. The results will advance basic science knowledge that can be used to develop novel strategies that target this efflux pump for future therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project narrative  A large class of inherited disorders is attributable to mutations that cause atypical termination of translation of the genetic code. These mutations activate a cellular quality control mechanism called nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) that is the focus of this proposal. We expect that our work will provide new insights into the mechanism of NMD and, as a consequence, will likely have the public health benefit of improving novel therapeutic approaches to the genetic disorders that trigger NMD.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Bell, Thomas, J): Project Narrative The research demand for human tissues continues to grow and the HTORR program provides a unique service to biomedical investigators nationwide whose research requires human tissues, organs and well annotated data. Over the past 4 years, nearly 500 scientific papers were published by scientists who used HTORR-provided tissues, confirming HTORR's indispensable contribution to the biomedical research community and the impact of these services on the search for new treatments and cures for common and rare diseases, including HIV/AIDS. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inside of our cells is a complex jumble of signals that must be interpreted in space in time to regulate dynamic cell processes. To support this the signal source must be in close proximity to the desired target. The current application proposes to investigate how the distribution of mitochondria (signal source) within our cells supports protein modifications (target) required to coordinate cell attachment and movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The ultimate goal of these experiments is to expand our understanding of the molecular basis of opioid use disorder (OUD). Using single nuclei RNA sequencing methods, we identified genes in the brain associated specifically with the development of compulsive opioid taking in male rats. This proposal expands these studies to characterize cell type-specific alterations in gene expression associated with voluntary opioid taking in female rats as well as acute and prolonged withdrawal timepoints in both sexes in order to identify opioid- and withdrawal-induced molecular changes that could be targeted by new medications to treat OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The Oropharyngeal Microbiome in COVID-19 Project Narrative (Summary) SARS-CoV-2 first infects the upper respiratory tract (URT), where it stays localized until cleared or it extends to the lower respiratory tract (LRT) to cause pneumonia, but why infection sometimes stays localized in the URT but sometimes extends to involve the LRT is unknown. Human body surfaces are colonized with microorganisms including bacteria (the Microbiome) that vary with age, disease or other factors and can affect genes and immune function, and we discovered in COVID-19 patients that the URT microbiome was abnormal and correlated with disease severity, suggesting that the URT microbiome may influence progression of COVID-19. In this project we will investigate the URT microbiome in people predisposed to severe COVID-19 (based on age, diabetes, obesity), and use a novel mouse model to determine how it alters URT and LRT genes that are important in SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE General anesthetic-induced developmental neurotoxicity, which is linked to several significant long-term consequences including behavioral deficits, has largely unknown cellular and molecular mechanisms. Our preliminary data suggests a strong direction for further investigation by showing that anesthesia is toxic to mitochondria, which is extremely important for neuron function. Thus, to address the aforementioned need, the goal of our study is to uncover the unexplored functions of mitochondrial signaling in anesthetic-induced neurotoxicity and investigate the efficacy of small molecule-mediated neuroprotection which targets mitochondrial pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a significant cause of respiratory disease in infants, the elderly and immunocompromised. The goal of this project is to determine if a viral protein, called M2-1, affects expression of cellular and viral proteins by acting on their mRNAs. The information obtained could be of value for understanding how RSV causes disease, and in the longer term could aid development of antiviral agents and vaccines to control RSV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Heart transplantation is an ultimate treatment for end-stage heart failure, but its use is limited by a severe donor heart shortage. This proposed study is aimed at evaluating mesenchymal stem cell (MSC)-derived therapy applied with an ex vivo heart perfusion device to facilitate recovery of hearts from donation after circulatory death (DCD, thus increasing the number of available donor hearts), promote graft function, and improve outcomes of heart transplantation. The results from this project can provide foundation for potential clinical trials in that MSC secretions can be utilized to improve DCD hearts resuscitation, and help us gain mechanistic insights on therapeutic targets to limit ischemic injury in DCD hearts for transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Stanford BSSR training grant is to develop a cadre of highly trained behavioral and social scientists with advanced quantitative skills for dealing with complex data, with a focus on applications to heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) disorders. The BSSR program addresses a critical need to train investigators with primary skills in behavioral and social sciences to have advanced quantitative skills to deal with the increasingly complex large-scale multidimensional data from digital devices, wearables, electronic health records, social media, administrative health claims databases, and other sources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Women who have had an adverse pregnancy outcome (APO) have a lifetime of higher heart disease risk, but their heart disease risk factor levels might go back to normal levels after delivery. Measures of pulsatile vascular function, such as wave reflection and arterial stiffness, might be more sensitive for detecting excess heart disease risk after pregnancy. We propose these measurements in the large, diverse, and longitudinal nuMoM2b-HHS2 cohort to describe differences in vascular function in women with versus without different past APOs and to evaluate associations of vascular function with early pregnancy biomarkers and patterns in lifestyle behaviors to identify high risk women and strategies to reduce heart disease risk after APOs.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed United States-Zambia Trauma and Injury Research Training Program (US- Zambia TIRP) is to strengthen research capacity on the health, social and economic impact of trauma and injuries across the lifespan in Zambia through an innovative model of sustainable capacity development. The program aims to develop a core group of researchers focused on trauma and injuries (T&Is) in Zambia; promote research on key national priorities for T&Is in Zambia; and further strengthen sustainability and the research environment in Zambia by establishing a center to support T&I research in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is common, deadly, and costly, and adults with insomnia represent a large group of people at elevated risk of developing CVD in the future. This mechanistic study will determine if our updated insomnia treatment called SHADES improves biological factors thought to explain how insomnia promotes CVD and if these improvements are due to positive changes in sleep factors. This study could generate the critical evidence needed to justify a large clinical trial to determine if SHADES can help prevent CVD events, such as heart attacks and strokes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Over 380,000 infants are born preterm in the United States each year, adding millions of dollars to health care costs and life-long consequences for survivors and families. Research progress on efforts to prevent and treat preterm birth are significantly hampered by the inability to accurately predict who is at risk for preterm birth before birth is already underway. In this project we will test a novel, operator-independent imaging tool—Quantitative Cervical Elastography System (Q-CES)—to, for the first time, quantify the underlying cervical tissue changes detectable in early pregnancy that precede preterm birth allowing critically needed improvement to correctly identify patients at risk for preterm birth to move both the clinical and scientific preterm birth field forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the dynamics and mechanisms of neurochemical signaling and regulation in the lymph node is expected to inform the development of new types of treatments for chronic inflammation, autoimmunity, and even cancer. Tools to monitor rapid neurochemical signaling within intact immune tissue are lacking and we will fill this critical gap by developing tools to study neurochemical signaling in the lymph node with exquisite resolution. Thus, this proposal is relevant to part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to identify causal neural mechanisms underlying unwanted, repetitive behaviors (compulsions). Using non-invasive brain stimulation, with or without coupled practice in a computer-based `habit override' task, we will modulate activity in a target brain region and measure effects on compulsive behaviors and related measures. This work could ultimately lead to the ability to treat compulsions more effectively by synergistically targeting the regions of the brain and the specific cognitive processes that can help to overcome compulsions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  Cancer is primarily a disease of old age, however very little is known about how cancer cell-intrinsic, microenvironmental, and systemic age-related changes impact cancer initiation and growth. We will permute cancer cell age and genotype, as well as microenvironment and host age, to gain an unprecedented understanding of the contribution of these factors to lung cancer initiation and growth. Ultimately, our findings could have important implication for cancer prevention, detection, and treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is common in infants and, despite the use of therapeutic hypothermia, often results in death or neurodevelopmental impairment. This proposal will investigate caffeine as an adjunct therapy for HIE by examining how drug disposition is altered due to hypothermia. Population pharmacokinetic modeling and dose simulations will be performed using pilot data and a dose-validation clinical trial will be conducted to confirm optimal caffeine dosing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Volatile toxic industrial materials (TIMs) have potential to cause large-scale injury and death, highlighting the public health risks associated with storage and transport of these economically important chemicals. The cornea of the eye is highly susceptible to TIM vapor exposure; however, corneal toxicities and long-term outcomes remain poorly characterized. In addition to identifying toxicological mechanisms and expanding our understanding of chemotoxic injury in the cornea, these studies will inform risk assessments and exposure management plans for these highly reactive TIMs and related chemotoxic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Aging is a complex process that drives increased cancer risk in tissues throughout the body, including the blood system. To understand why aged individuals have higher risk of developing blood cancers, there is a vital need to understand the mechanisms by which aging contributes to clonal expansion and transformation. This research is relevant to public health because it will provide mechanistic insights into effective therapeutic strategies to target clonal evolution, attenuate pathophysiology promoted by clonal expansion, and intercept malignant transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delays and missed opportunities for timely treatment contribute significantly to global disparities in cervical cancer in low- and middle-income countries {LMICs) compared to high-income countries, yet little is known about how best to increase adoption of evidence-based cancer care in LMICs. This project will help to fill this critical research gap by testing the effectiveness of patient- and system-level strategies on timeliness of care among females diagnosed with cervical cancer in Botswana. The results of this project will yield fundamental knowledge about how to improve and sustain timely cancer care in Botswana, and, if successful, identify strategies that can be easily translated to address other areas of cancer control across LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One quarter of the world’s population carries the burden of tuberculosis. Efforts to reduce this burden have been hindered by the lack effective diagnostics and a protective vaccine underpinned by gaps in the understanding of the immune response in tuberculosis disease. The proposed research will examine the role of humoral immunity in tuberculosis disease with the vision that antibody features may be harnessed to expand the repertoire for immune correlates, diagnostics and rational vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – Overall The UCLA Brain Cancer SPORE will support research into new and innovative strategies to diagnose and treat brain cancer, particularly focusing on innovative ways to overcome the problem of treatment-induced resistance to current therapies (i.e., immunotherapy, chemo/drug therapy, and radiation therapy resistance). Despite many different treatment approaches, the five-year survival rate for glioblastoma (WHO grade IV) patients remains dismal, and there are still no definitive cures for this disease. Thus, the proposed research is of relevance to public health, as there is clearly an unmet need for patients with this type of cancer and continued investigations into novel therapeutic approaches for brain cancer are desperately needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 1 The studies proposed herein are designed to investigate mechanisms of immune evasion following active immunotherapy with brain cancer vaccines. We will test our hypothesis that clinically relevant anti-tumor immunity to glioblastoma (GBM) must have two cellular components: 1) significant infiltration of tumor-specific tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TIL); and 2) blockade of immunosuppressive tumor infiltrating myeloid cell (TIM) function within the tumor microenvironment. We believe that a combination of active vaccination (ATL-DC; to induce T-cell infiltration into tumors), immune checkpoint inhibition (to enhance T cell function), and CSF-1R inhibition (to block suppressive TIM function) may lead to improved outcomes for the treatment of glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to support the training of the diverse next generation of researchers who will make fundamental discoveries related to the neuroscience underlying normal communication, effects of hearing loss and dysfunction of communicative abilities. They will work toward applying those discoveries and developing them into safe and effective therapies for affected individuals. As a long- term research-training program, this effort will reap the rewards of its investments over decades of research advancements achieved through the careers of the trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to distinguish harmful and beneficial microbes is critical for the survival of animals, including humans. Our study suggests that bloating of the intestine caused by colonization of pathogenic bacteria may be a general mechanism involved in the recognition of a broad range of microbes and that it modulates host immune response and behavior via neuroendocrine signaling. Overall, a better understanding of the recognition of physiological alterations caused by infections and the neural mechanisms of control of inflammation is highly relevant to public health because inflammation accounts for the major physiological, metabolic, and pathological responses to infections.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The Architecture of High Value Health Care annual conference is the premier venue in the United States to disseminate performance improvement initiatives related to high-value practice on a national scale. Now in its 5th year, the meeting serves as a forum for national experts from across the country to vet value-based performance improvement work and a platform to disseminate care redesign that safely improves providers' ability to diagnose and treat patients. Changing long-standing provider practice patterns has proven challenging, necessitating a large-scale demonstration of accountability to inspire adoption of higher value health care and determine which interventions most effectively influence prescribing and ordering behavior.

PROJECT_TITLE: The Architecture of High Value Healthcare

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative When patients and providers use patient decision aids (PDAs) patients report improved knowledge, satisfaction, patient-provider communication, increased involvement in decision making, and reduced decisional conflict and regret. Despite these meaningful patient-centered outcomes, PDAs continue to be underutilized. We propose to use user-centered design methods to build and test a shared decision aid support system that addresses the patient, clinician, and system barriers to PDA use, supports alignment with the “5 rights of clinical decision support”, and supports reusability, interoperability, and scalability.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: An Interoperable, Reusable and Scalable Shared Decision Aid Navigator System: Supporting the 5 Rights of Patient Shared Decision-Making

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will examine the long-term clinical and economic outcomes among working-age survivors of traumatic injury by leveraging a unique data opportunity to combine our statewide trauma registry with commercial credit reports. We will then use policy simulation techniques to evaluate the impact of alternative health insurance design strategies on financial strain and health-related quality of life. Understanding the drivers of poor long-term outcomes and the potential impact of insurance policy redesign will help clinicians, researchers, and policymakers optimize long-term recovery after acute illness or injury.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Long-term Trauma Outcomes and Insurance Policy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The studies proposed herein are designed to test the feasibility, safety, and preliminary efficacy of a novel bispecific IL-13Rα2/TGF-β CART-T cell therapy for glioblastoma, as well as investigate response biomarkers and mechanisms of immune evasion following the injection of these CAR-T cells intratumorally and intraventricularly. We will test our hypothesis that clinically relevant CAR-T cell therapy for glioblastoma (GBM) must have two components: 1) tumor-specific glioblastoma cell targeting; and 2) blockade of the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME). We believe that our novel bispecific IL-13Rα2/TGF-β CAR-T cell therapy that simultaneously targets both glioblastoma cells and the immunosuppressive TME may lead to improved outcomes for the treatment of glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed BRIDGE to the Baccalaureate Program at Morgan State University utilizes a wrap-around approach to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities who successfully complete the transition from Prince George’s Community College to completion of the Baccalaureate degree in STEM and psychology majors at Morgan State University. This will increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities who are then able to successfully compete for positions in graduate or professional programs or who are able to gain entry in the workforce in areas related to biomedical or behavioral sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with stroke are at a significant risk for developing life-threatening venous thromboembolic (VTE) events including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Compelling evidence has emerged that implicates neutrophils in the initiation and pathogenesis of DVT. Using experimental models, we will investigate the mechanistic role of neutrophil integrin α9 in modulation of poststroke DVT and test whether targeting integrin α9 reduces DVT incidence following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Age restricted in-person location policies (ARLPs), which would restrict the sale of tobacco to adult-only locations (like tobacco shops), are considered a new and exciting approach to reducing tobacco use. Our research is relevant to public health because it would be the first to model the potential impact of ARLPs on youth tobacco use, both overall and for historically marginalized populations that have been negatively affected by the tobacco retailer environment. This project is relevant to NCI’s mission because it would help guide policymakers toward equity-enhancing tobacco control efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative Using deconvolution approaches, we identified two tumor-intrinsic subtypes of PDAC (basal and classical) that are robust, replicable, prognostic and predictive of treatment response. We have also found two stroma subtypes associated with outcome and show tumor-stroma interactions in patients associated with outcome, recapitulated in tumor-CAF models. We will use a combination of cancer biology, computational approaches to determine tumor-stroma interactions and how they predict treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our study will identify population-specific risk alleles and improve the risk stratification models for obesity and type-2 diabetes in Native Hawaiians. Moreover, we will reach out to members of the Native Hawaiian community to understand their concerns of participating in genomic research. Together, our research will improve our understanding of genetic risk factors in human complex diseases, provide much needed genomic resources to accelerate future studies, and also provide guidance to the design of future genomic studies in this understudied and underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The IKS channel is a voltage-gated potassium channel that is associated with multiple inherited and acquired cardiac arrhythmias, including long QT syndrome, a leading cause of sudden cardiac death. Despite this, critical information about its regulatory mechanisms (both intrinsic and by the sympathetic nervous system) is still unknown, so development of more effective therapies for these arrhythmias is severely handicapped. The objective of this research is to elucidate the mechanism of the channel and how it is regulated by the sympathetic nervous system, with the goal of identifying new targets for drug development and disease prevention.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Narrative Infectious diseases remain a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and present an ever- increasing threat to human health. The development of new, innovative strategies to combat infectious disease will require research scientists with a depth and breadth of training in both microbiology and immunology, and an appreciation for the needs and realities of clinical care. The purpose of this application is to continue and improve upon a highly successful graduate training program that provides promising predoctoral scientists with the interdisciplinary training and skills required for them to launch successful independent careers in infectious disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Urine cadmium and risk of fracture and bone loss Narrative Mechanistic experiments and cross-sectional epidemiologic studies have linked cadmium to low bone mineral density, osteoporosis, and fracture; however, currently lacking are large prospective epidemiologic studies. We propose to leverage existing samples and data from the two largest prospective US osteoporosis cohort studies to perform an in-depth investigation of cadmium, bone loss, and fractures. These studies promise to transform the field of Cd-bone research and have high potential to impact policy decisions in the US and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic studies of Alzheimer’s disease have demonstrated a critical pathogenic role for brain immune cells known as microglia, whose function appears to be impaired. This proposal aims to investigate how genetic factors that promote Alzheimer’s disease act to impair microglial function by modifying their long-term responses to inflammatory signals. Our studies will help outline the link between inflammation and Alzheimer’s disease, potentially leading to novel approaches to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposed research is responding to RFA-CA-21-056 and aims to leverage our decade-long, extensive, and successful training partnership and research collaborations in Mali and Nigeria to implement a novel West African Self-Sampling Human Papillomavirus (HPV)-Based Cervical Cancer Control Program in these two countries. The project capitalizes on existing strengths and resources including the HIV systems of care with Community Health Workers who have established relationships with women living with HIV/AIDS and can provide HPV and cervical cancer education/counseling, guidance for Self-Sampling by women, rapid collection and transport of vaginal swab specimens to hospital laboratories, personalized delivery of test results directly to the women, and facilitation of clinic referrals for those with high-Risk HPV infection for advanced diagnostics and treatment. The study will conduct an in-depth assessment of barriers, challenges, and needs to implement, contextually adapt, and evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed program.

The three Cores have been extremely productive and learned much about working effectively with the Research Community. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some patients who undergo inter-hospital transfer (IHT, transfer from one hospital to another) may be exposed to the risks of discontinuity of care without clear benefit from care received following transfer (i.e., undergo potentially inappropriate IHT). Without a reliable method for defining and determining the presence of potentially inappropriate IHT across many organizations, it is not otherwise possible to understand the safety impact of these transfers, to create and optimize future solutions to reduce them, or to directly test the effects of these solutions on patient outcomes. Our study addresses these issues by seeking to accurately define and estimate the incidence and patient safety impact of potentially inappropriate IHT among medical patients who have undergone IHT to a large network of US hospitals, characterize and identify at-risk patients, and develop a toolkit of best practices to reduce potentially inappropriate IHT for future dissemination (e.g., by replacing it with safer alternatives).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Identification and Prevention of Potentially Inappropriate Inter-hospital Transfers
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative MammoScreen is a web-based application for women ages 40-74 that identifies risks for breast cancer and guides decisions about mammography screening and genetic counseling in accordance with current clinical recommendations. To improve patient care in health systems, information entered by women in MammoScreen could be transferred directly to clinicians through the electronic health record (EHR), although methods to accomplish this have not yet been developed. This project leverages new, secure health data methods to integrate MammoScreen with compatible EHRs, allowing clinicians to access patient-generated breast cancer risk data and provide appropriate care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing USPSTF Recommendations for Breast Cancer Screening and Prevention by Integrating Clinical Decision Support Tools with the Electronic Health Record

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic eye pain is a highly distressing symptom as its occurrence results in high disability without effective treatment. Such pain can be driven by ongoing inflammation, but it can also be a result of damage to the sensory nervous system. In this program, we distinguish the difference between these two sources of pain using advanced neuroimaging to evaluate the peripheral and central nervous system pathways that innervate the eye. This first-of-its-kind study will provide invaluable information that can be applied towards the diagnosis, monitoring and treatment of persons with chronic eye pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to evaluate the efficacy and study the mechanisms of its actions of oral nitrite administration as a novel therapeutic approach to replenish NO in dystrophic muscle by targeting nitrate-nitrite-NO pathway, which is significantly disturbed in DMD. The unique beneficial effects of nitrite to both dystrophic skeletal muscle and bone tissues represent a novel intervention targeting musculoskeletal comorbidities in DMD. If succeed, this innovative strategy could represent a safe and cost-effective therapeutic pharmacological approach benefiting both muscle and bone for the currently untreatable DMD; and provide new mechanistic understanding of DMD muscle and bone pathogenesis in DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to public health: Mutations in genes encoding sodium proton exchangers found in the membranes of endosomes and lysosomes of the cell cause serious disorders ranging from syndromic autism and intellectual disability to various cancers. This project will biochemically map sodium and proton transport activity in these intracellular compartments for the first time and link gene variants and gene expression in patient populations to clinical phenotypes to understand the molecular basis of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative/Public Health relevance The proposed K01 award “Advancing equitable implementation of genomic medicine in nephrology” responds to the NIDDK’s research priorities related to filling a critical gap between the discovery of novel genes in nephrology and the limited utilization of those discoveries in practice; this gap prevents personalization of care of all patients with kidney diseases, many of whom are from underserved racial/ethnic communities. To fill this gap, this study will identify barriers to genetic testing in nephrology and develop and test a point-of-care toolbox focused on genomic literacy—a key barrier for uptake of genetic testing. This K01 will prepare the candidate to develop an independent research program in implementation science and health equity research and generate innovative interventions to accelerate equitable implementation of genomic medicine in nephrology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Major questions in cell biology can only be answered with the development of new technology. We have developed methods to image single molecules of messenger RNA and proteins in living yeast cells in order to understand how information is regulated in the cell. We have found that these molecules regulate cell growth by making proteins at exactly the right time and place and then disappear, promoting the precise timing needed for cell division. The goal of this proposal is to develop methods to visualize the life cycle of a single mRNA molecule in real time in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative The project is focused on the in vivo regulation of cytoplasmic dynein, a motor that drives many cellular cargoes. In elongated cells such as neurons, long-distance cargo transport by dynein is critical for cell survival, and dynein deficiencies cause devastating neurodegenerative diseases, for example, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Dynein is also important for brain development. Deficiencies in the dynein regulator LIS1 cause a brain developmental disorder called “lissencephaly” manifested by mental retardation and early death. Elucidating the regulatory mechanism of dynein will potentially benefit the development of therapies for these human diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Viral infection is a common cause of sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), however studies have not conclusively identified the etiology. This study will establish in vivo mouse models for SNHL caused by mumps virus and cytomegalovirus using a controlled and local viral injection method. Cochlear damage will be assessed at the cellular to molecular level and the role of immune responses will be characterized with the goal of advancing knowledge of the mechanisms leading to virus-induced SNHL to provide future prevention and treatments in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study will investigate the mechanisms of alcohol-mediated brain inflammation and activation of a protein complex called the inflammasome in the development and progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We will identify critical molecules contributing to exacerbated AD- associated cognitive impairments after excessive chronic alcohol use. Our study will provide new insights on the role of inflammasomes in alcohol-mediated neuroinflammation and AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While antibody-mediated lymphocyte depletion is commonly used to eliminate donor-reactive T cells in transplant recipients, its impact on long-term transplant survival remains controversial. The proposed studies will investigate how inflammatory pathways triggered by allograft transplantation drive rapid reconstitution of pathogenic memory T cells. Based on the gained mechanistic insights, we will test several clinically relevant approaches for prolonging heart allograft survival in recipients treated with lymphoablation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative As a major component of bacterial cell envelope, surface proteins of Gram-positive bacteria are key molecules in mediating bacterial interactions with the environment. The primary focus of this project is to understand the spatiotemporal regulation of surface protein biogenesis in Staphylococcus aureus, a human commensal bacterium and a leading cause of various infections. As surface proteins and cell envelope components are essential for bacterial virulence and fitness, the outcome of this project will not only reveal novel mechanisms of bacterial cell envelope assembly, but also provide potential new targets for new antimicrobials and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell fate engineering, for example the directed differentiation of pluripotent stem cells or the direct conversion among somatic cell types, holds great promise to improve disease modeling, drug screening, and to lead to regenerative medicine therapies. However, our ability to engineering cell fate with fidelity has been impeded by an incomplete understanding of the biological networks that govern development. In this work, I propose to address this problem through a combination of algorithm development and data generation, with an emphasis on cell types related to the synovial joint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it has significant promise to increase human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination rates among 9- to 12-year-olds, and therefore, reduce the HPV-related cancer disparity in rural areas. The project builds upon existing evidence of improving clinicians’ recommendations and increasing parents’ motivations while adding strategies that address common social determinants that inhibit parents’ ability to have their child receive the HPV vaccine. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to prevent cancer in the United States within all demographics including rural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NF-PanNETs) are a heterogeneous group of neoplasms with increasing incidence and ill-defined pathobiology. The goals of this proposal are (1) to develop and validate a clinically available assay for the prognostic stratification of NF-PanNETs, (2) to define the nanoscale chromatin changes in the stepwise progression of NF-PanNETs to metastatic disease and (3) to identify drivers and molecular pathways in the metastatic progression of NF-PanNETs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is irreversible neurodegeneration and deterioration of cognition which, in the preclinical stage, appear to be preceded by changes to self-awareness. This proposed work will investigate these behavioral changes and associated neurobiology in a non-human primate model of early AD using in vivo behavioral and imaging techniques alongside post-mortem histology. Results have the potential to expand the model’s validity and generate causal knowledge of disease impact toward mechanisms of early identification and intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The COVID-19 pandemic led to profound changes in prenatal care delivery, including the implementation of hybrid prenatal care models (reduced visit schedules and telemedicine) which have since been recognized as new national consensus recommendations for prenatal care. For hybrid prenatal care models to be adopted across clinical settings, it is critically important to evaluate their effect on clinical outcomes, including patients’ and providers’ experience with these models, prior to widespread implementation. This mixed-methods proposal leverages rigorous econometric analyses, detailed electronic health record data, and rich qualitative interviews with patients and providers, to understand how hybrid prenatal care models will affect average-risk patients and patients from key marginalized groups: low-income, Black and rural patients

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patterned changes to 3D-genome organization and chromatin state prove essential for normal gene expression, whose dysregulation is a causal determinant of many neurodevelopmental diseases. Using mouse olfactory sensory neurons as a model system, we devised a single-cell genomic strategy to understand how neurons achieve the nuclear architecture and chromatin modifications necessary to support normal gene expression. We aim to characterize structural and biochemical features that distinguish genes in active and inactive states, while delineating a molecular mechanism for how these features arise, to clarify parameters for gene regulation relevant to nervous system function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) affects millions of people in the United States annually and leads to long-term disability. The proposed project seeks to examine an understudied mechanism of poor knee joint health development that will drive the advancement of OA prevention strategies to benefit the public health. The proposed project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it contributes high-quality, foundational knowledge in clinical research to promote long- term health and reduce disability in individuals at risk for OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Air pollution is the world’s most important environmental risk factor that contributes more to global morbidity and mortality than tuberculosis, malaria, AIDS, wars and famine combined. In this transformative project, we provide compelling new data on air pollution as a disruptor of endogenous biologic “circadian” rhythms. Through careful studies in animals and humans and large cohorts, we will evaluate the impact of exposure and personalized interventions on heart and metabolic health. Our results will provide compelling new data to prevent the health problems caused by air pollution exposure globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Embryonic stem cells hold great promise for regenerative medicine because they possess unlimited self-renewal potential and the remarkable ability to differentiate into any cell type. To precisely control differentiation of embryonic stem cells for regenerative medicine, we study molecular mechanisms linking division and differentiation of embryonic stem cells. Insights from our studies will advance our understanding of the basic biology of differentiation of pluripotent cells, which has immediate implications for robust differentiation of embryonic stem cells into therapeutic cell types for regenerative medicine purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: This project seeks to develop and share a new curriculum and set of assessment tools to enable effective and efficient educational experiences for undergraduate engineering students in needs-identification and needs characterization--the first two steps in the Biodesign Process for health technology innovation. With the convergence of a rapidly changing landscape in healthcare, and the incredibly fast pace of technological change, today’s young innovators face unprecedented challenges. Yet, a combination of patient-focused approach and needs-first innovation skills can unlock unprecedented capacities to address these challenges and improve the lives of patients everywhere.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This educational program is designed to train the next generation of population researchers in the methods in formal demography necessary for research in macroeconomic demography, biodemography, emerging data sources, as well as fertility and mortality trends. The kind of demographic training in this workshop - unavailable elsewhere in the United States - provides the tools and approaches to allow early career researchers to expand their abilities. The population research supported by this training will facilitate informed decision making on public health policies and other issues relevant to the health of the U.S. population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: With antiretroviral therapy, children living with perinatally-acquired HIV are surviving into adulthood and will need to transition to adult care to achieve long-term successful outcomes. Adolescents living with HIV and transitioning to adult care have shown high rates of mortality, virologic failure, and loss to follow up. The proposed research will evaluate in-person and mHealth delivered adolescent-friendly transition interventions compared to standard of care among adolescents with low transition readiness in a randomized clinical trial and evaluate implementation factors associated with each intervention in urban and rural settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We will develop a novel computational data-driven framework for identifying molecular features across multiple scales to study antibiotic resistance (AR) in ESKAPE pathogens. This work will develop broadly usable methods and data science technologies — open software, open FAIR data repositories, and web platforms — to understand and target AR in new and (re)emerging pathogens. Our project will get us closer to ending the arms race between microbes and drugs, serving the core mission of NIAID and global public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The promise of human pluripotent stem cells as a research and therapeutic tool is critically hinged on efficient culture protocols that can promote directed differentiation of these cells towards different adult cell types with high yield and purity. This research will develop and implement new technologies to investigate how the mechanical signals in the pluripotent stem cell culture can be utilized to improve their differentiation efficiency towards functional motor neurons, loss of which is associated with spinal cord injury, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and spinal muscular atrophy. Our research can potentially enable drastic advances in large-scale production of functional motor neurons and thus contribute significantly to future motor neuron-based regenerative therapies and drug and toxicology screens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neural stem/progenitor cells (NSPCs) lie in close proximity to blood vessels in the normal brain and after cell transplant to treat neurological conditions. We studied the interaction of human NSPCs and human endothelial cells that make blood vessels and found that endothelial cell contact changed the character of human NSPCs while the NSPCs produced factors that caused vessel formation. Our studies could optimize co-transplants of human NSPCs and human endothelial cells in bioengineered scaffolds to recreate critical interactions and stimulate brain repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 200,000 people in the US develop deep vein thromboses (DVT) annually and over 43% of these patients will develop post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS), leading to a lowered quality of life. DVT is treated with catheter directed thrombolysis in addition to anti-coagulation therapy, which does not prevent the development of PTS. Thus, this research proposal seeks to elucidate the mechanisms of DVT formation and resolution, in order to identify therapeutic targets leading to the optimal treatment of DVT and its sequelae and increase the quality of life for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metformin is thought to module multiple molecular pathways involved in aging. The goal of this project is to study the effects of metformin on pillars (hallmarks) of aging in older adults and establish whether changes in pillars of aging are linked to changes in clinically-relevant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The central research mission of our lab is to uncover the core principles underlying the assembly heterochromatin, a central gene-repressive element in the genome. Heterochromatin assembly heritably partitions the genome into active and inactive regions and in its normal state, this process drives cellular differentiation, while when misregulated, underlies a variety of diseases, including several cancers. We propose an integrative approach to define central cellular and biochemical mechanisms of dynamic heterochromatin assembly, ranging from single molecule biophysical to real-time single-cell measurements, which will reveal crucial intervention points for tuning this reaction in disease treatment, regenerative medicine, and synthetic biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, I propose a research program of developing novel statistical methods and open-access tools for genetic epidemiology studies to innovatively tackle open problems in human trait genetics, methods for which are outdated or scarce or have shown limited progress in recent years. In particular, we seek to address methodological challenges in identifying non-additive genetic effects, effects of rare variants, and in prioritizing causal variants through integrative omics. This research program will support diversity in three distinct ways, will broadly apply to human health, and will impact strategies for analyzing multi-ethnic family- & hybrid designs and approaches used to aggregate summary-level data across the allele frequency spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses speech and language analysis (ASLA) as an objective, low-cost approach for dementia detection and monitoring in Latinos, a large and underserved minority. Leveraging a large cohort from Latin America and the United States (n = 2740), we will employ machine and deep learning to (a) test the diagnostic utility of ASLA markers; (b) correlate them with cognitive and neuroimaging features; and (c) identify those that are robust across, languages, dialects, and socio-biological variables. In the long term, this research will provide equitable tools for early diagnosis and monitoring of dementia in Latinos, reducing testing cost and time, avoiding biases of examiner-based tests, differentiating syndromes beyond common-cause confounds, and enabling timely adoption of neuroprotective life changes and pathology-targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progression of HIV disease and premature deaths among persons living with HIV (PLWH) have been attributed foremost to insufficient engagement in medical care and adherence to HIV treatment regimens. In response, this study will test the efficacy and implementation factors of WiseApp, an evidence-based self-management medication adherence tool with Spanish-speaking PLWH in New York City and the Dominican Republic. This application has considerable public health relevance because it is delivered to an ethnic minority group who are disproportionally affected by HIV.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Dissemination of the WiseApp for Improving Health Outcomes Across Settings

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Infectious diarrheal diseases, such as rotavirus, are leading causes of sickness and death in children worldwide despite several vaccines being available. During infection, a rotavirus protein called nonstructural protein 4 (NSP4) takes over the cell’s communication systems and reprograms the cell to promote rotavirus replication and cause diarrhea and vomiting. This proposal makes use of new genetic tools to map the parts of NSP4 responsible for commandeering cellular communication machinery, which will help us improve anti-diarrheal drugs and develop better vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Deer ticks are spreading across the Pacific West Coast of the United States and making people sick because they carry deadly bacteria. The proposed research is to study a novel potentially dangerous bacterium in deer ticks, called Rickettsia species phylotype G022, by studying the survival of the bacterium in deer ticks, detecting the infection rate of the bacterium in pet dogs, and giving it a unique scientific name. Our findings will advance the vital long-term research goal of our lab, investigating the suspicion that the G022 bacterium poses a risk of infection to humans and domestic animals across the Pacific West Coast.

PHR: There is overwhelming evidence that female reproductive aging influences lifespan and diverse health outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Prolonged social isolation results in a host of negative outcomes on mental health, including increased violence, and so represents a major public health concern. Despite this, the neural correlates of social isolation the resulting aggression remain poorly understood. Using sophisticated behavioral and computational analyses, perturbations of genetically defined neuronal populations, and in vivo imaging, the project proposed here aims to uncover the unique circuit mechanisms which exert top-down control over isolation-induced aggression, thereby informing the development of novel treatments for mental health disturbances resulting from social isolation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Natural killer (NK) cells are innate immune effector cells that may be engineered for cancer immunotherapy by expression of chimeric antigen receptors (CARs), engineered proteins that direct NK cells to kill cancer cells. Our proposed studies will generate a fundamental understanding of intracellular signaling mediated by NK-CARs to enable efficient design of optimal CARs for multiple myeloma. This research has the potential to unlock the transformative power of NK-CAR cells for cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Pyramidal neurons in the primary visual cortex (V1) undergo dynamic plasticity changes throughout visual associative learning. This proposal will define which learning events drive differential plastic changes in V1 and how learning or V1 activity shape cortico-cortical functional connectivity. We expect our findings to provide important insight into the behavioral underpinnings of V1 and cortico-cortical plasticity throughout learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advances toward potential disease-modifying therapies in Huntington disease (HD) present an urgent need to identify early, quantifiable markers of disease progression in youth and young adults at risk for HD. The goals of this study are to characterize impulsive behaviors as an early marker of HD and to examine the influence of genetic status, environmental stressors, and inhibitory control as potential predictors of these behaviors. These results will lead to better understanding and improved detection of the earliest symptoms of HD, which will help to guide the development of new therapies for those at risk of developing this fatal disease.

PHR: Poxviruses include some dangerous emerging pathogens as well as some promising vaccine vectors. Studying poxvirus host range mechanisms will provide knowledge for development of antiviral therapies and poxvirus-vectored vaccines. A new understanding on how host regulates translation in response to viral infection and how viruses evade this host response will provide fundamental insight into viral pathogenesis and benefit the development of new antiviral strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This RURAL Sleep Study will determine the prevalence of sleep disorders and sleep behaviors in the rural southern United States, their relation to social, environmental, and behavioral stressors, and their association with cardiovascular and metabolic risk. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Fall prevention alarms do not prevent falls, interrupt workflow and serve as an auditory restraint to prevent patient mobility. The goal of this study is to compare high- and low-intensity coaching to reduce indiscriminate fall prevention alarm use in 30 medical and medical-surgical nursing units from 30 diverse hospitals participating in the National Database of Nursing Quality Indicators (NDNQI).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Gastric cancer is common globally. We seek to develop and characterize model systems (iPSCs, organoids) to reveal how gastric intestinal metaplasia and dysplasia, precursors to gastric cancer, form. In so doing, we will unravel new insights into potential applications for prevention, early detection, screening and surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Project Narrative The strategic goal of the Precision Aging Network is to develop the essential scientific knowledge and appropriate technologies to predict individual brain health risks and to discover personalized solutions to maximize cognitive healthspan. Because of the enormous heterogeneity in brain and cognitive functions among older individuals, the urgent challenge for science, medicine and healthcare providers is to discover interventions that are individually effective in delaying or preventing the onset of symptoms that arise from age- related cognitive impairment or brain disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias. To achieve this we will determine how specific categories of risk relate to brain aging and cognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spontaneous pregnancy loss is a devastating and serious public health problem affecting 1 in 4 women worldwide. While uterine infection is associated with pregnancy loss, how infectious triggers impact endometrial function is unknown. The proposed research will determine the mechanisms by which bacterial and viral components impact endometrial inflammation, decidualization, and communication with placental trophoblasts, contributing to our current understanding of the pathophysiology of early pregnancy loss in women who have been exposed to infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health relevance of this study relates to the persistent problem of undernutrition among very preterm infants (those born <32 weeks of gestation) receiving neonatal intensive care. By creating a new fetal reference for body composition and identifying targets for fat-free mass accretion based on neurodevelopmental outcomes, this project will inform new and more effective strategies for assessing and monitoring the nutritional status of very preterm infants. The overall goal is for pragmatic nutrition-based interventions within neonatal intensive care that support optimal long-term health and neurodevelopmental outcomes for the ~63,000 very preterm infants born each year in the U.S. and many more worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative consortium that combines next- generation sequencing with state- of- the- art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this consortium are to identify gene variants that are associated with compulsive-like cocaine intake and behavioral endophenotypes using genome- wide association studies (GWAS) in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to strengthen the infrastructure of a newly created data/tissue repository (Cocaine Biobank) accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms related to cocaine use disorder. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of cocaine addiction-like behaviors in males and females, and increase the impact of a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow- up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative ARHI, a complex trait, is the most common cause of hearing loss and is one of the most prevalent conditions affecting the elderly globally. Estimates suggest approximately two-thirds of people over the age of 70 in the United States experience ARHL,1 and that by 2020, over half of all people in the United States with hearing loss will be over 70 years of age. We are proposing to identify candidate genes by performing the first genome- wide association study (GWAS) of ARHI in mice and examining gene expression in the inner ear for sceQTL and network studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synthetic DNA-based nanoparticles possess the potential to develop advanced delivery tools for targeted therapies, but their behavior in the cytosolic environment remains poorly understood. Herein, we seek to address critical issues about the accessibility and breakdown of these nanoparticles within the mammalian cell cytosol and identify mechanisms of stabilization. Outcomes of the proposed project will enable the realization of more- biocompatible delivery systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 54% of adolescents report experiencing one or more adverse childhood experiences, making them over 1.5 times more likely to use substances; however, many adolescents with adverse childhood experiences deny substance use engagement. Using an innovative integrative model of ecological and laboratory approaches, the current study examines the role of affect in the link between childhood adversity and adolescent substance use. This research will advance NIDA’s strategic plan (Objective 1) by improving our understanding of factors that influence substance use behaviors and informing future interventions that aim to improve outcomes and reduce the health and economic costs of adolescent substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Overall Our Center for Neurodegeneration and Translational Neuroscience (CNTN) is transforming the translational neuroscience research environment in Southern Nevada. In Phase 1, the CNTN has developed robust research infrastructure that was leveraged by local investigators to carry out innovative biomedical research projects focused on neurodegenerative disorders (NDD). In Phase 2, we ambition to develop the resources and processes necessary to reach sustainability by utilizing the evaluation reports produced by our talented Assessment Unit to elaborate our strategy, monitor progress, and make eventual adjustments to our strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The over 44 million persons worldwide living with dementia are primarily older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) or related dementias (ADRD). The consequences of physical disability and death from AD combined with unclear clinical benefit of AD treatment motivate the search for targets of preventive intervention. We hypothesize that declining kidney health, which is a model of premature aging that relates to cognitive and physical decline long before onset of dementia and physical disability, is the source of modifiable biological mechanisms; thus, we propose to leverage data from over 22,000 older adults to identify kidney-related biomarkers that can inform prevention and prediction of age-related ADRD and physical disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Exhaustion of CD8+T cells is a major barrier to successful immunotherapy for cancer. In this proposal, we aim to investigate the molecular mechanism by which Znf740, a novel transcription factor, regulates effector function vs. exhaustion of CD8+T cells. Our studies could lead to new clinical trials to overcome the current limitations of immunotherapy for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Approaching a comprehensive account of behavioral, neural and genetic mechanisms for the precision and lastingness of learning-induced auditory system reorganization will lead the future of hearing-related medical practices to achieve effects of auditory training that are acoustically rich as well as long-lasting. Use of a small- molecule epigenetic approach is a tool for gene discovery that will also aid precision medicine to its full potential for therapeutics that can coordinate complex effects that likely involve families of interacting genes. HDAC- inhibitors may further succeed in producing robust auditory remediation on an individual-person basis, especially when sound exposure therapies alone fail to induce relief, as in cases of long-standing hearing problems, in the aged brain where cholinergic signaling is known to be disrupted, or in rehabilitation following extreme auditory disturbances including cochlear implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Clinical and Translational Research Core (CTRC)  The complex cascade of biochemical and neurophysiological changes occurring in Alzheimer’s disease (AD)  and Parkinson’s disease (PD)—the two most common neurodegenerative diseases of the elderly—requires new  research approaches that integrate information from multiple distinct but parallel sources including molecular  profiling, multi-modal brain imaging, and clinical assessments. The Cleveland Clinic Lou Ruvo Center for Brain  Health (LRCBH) and the University of Nevada-Las Vegas (UNLV) have been collaborating on the study of a  group of individuals with early stage AD and PD for the past 5 years, collecting a variety of clinical, biological,  and imaging data on these individuals each year. This research has been studied in a variety of innovative  projects and funding for the study has been used to develop the research infrastructure of southern Nevada. For  Phase 2 we plan to extend the study up to 10 years and look more specifically at the role of inflammation in  these two diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteric microbiomes contribute to immune development yet very little is known about the viral component. We will test the hypotheses that the infant enteric virome is vertically transferred, and the expanded enteric virome of infants born to mothers who are HIV-infected leads to accelerated immune ontogeny and activation. Understanding the factors that shape the infant gut virome and its consequent impact on immune ontogeny could facilitate the development of interventions to reduce infant morbidity and mortality, particularly for those that are exposed to HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Data Management and Statistics Core (DMSC) Derivation of novel insights and new knowledge is predicated on sound data management practices that allow for reliable validation and replication of results, thereby permitting new and innovative research to be built on existing information and providing a basis for training early investigators in practical data analysis and management. Consistent with the primary aims of the Center for Neurodegeneration and Translational Neuroscience (CNTN), the Data Management and Statistical Core seeks to advance the scientific process and the goals of the CNTN by providing content expertise in data science, informatics, and statistics, as well as, low- friction information technology solutions for managing, analyzing, extracting knowledge, and sharing research data. These functions are essential in order for the full value of public investment in research to be realized.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program will train new cohorts of demographers to study contemporary issues in population health and wellbeing. Demography is the study of population size, structure, and change. Most contemporary social problems have demographic components, as for example differential fertility rates, rising mortality rates, or changes in migration. By understanding dynamics of mortality, fertility, migration, marriage and divorce, we are better able to develop social policy that promotes child health and family wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A portion of patients with metastatic melanoma, and aggressive form of skin cancer, have durable responses to immunotherapies, but most do not. In this proposal we elucidate the role of an understudied axis with important roles in anti-tumor immunity and resistance to immunotherapies. We will use novel models, methodologies and a large cohort of patient biopsies to elucidate the molecular underpinnings of a specific mechanism of resistance to immunotherapies, test different therapeutic strategies to overcome this mechanism, and provide comprehensive high-resolution landscape of immunotherapy resistance in melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Brain Imaging Core The Center for Neurodegeneration and Translational Neuroscience (CNTN) COBRE Phase 2 Brain Imaging Core (BIC) will provide advanced neuroimaging technologies and data analysis methods to current and future COBRE projects and other interested researchers. The BIC will be committed to the training of junior investigators in advanced imaging methods and analyses, as well as advancing the sustainability of the Core and the CNTN. The proposed BIC is highly relevant to public health because it promotes training, access and usage of advanced neuroimaging technologies, and data analysis methods leading to better characterization of human brain function and thus will promote advancing understanding of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intersection of smoking and HIV/AIDS poses a serious public health threat in Vietnam. Vietnam is dealing with these two challenges with parallel rather than integrated plans. Using a computer-tailored texting intervention, in a sustainable manner, we seek to promote use of an underused, available, government-funded resource (quitline) and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) that the quitline provides, thus, promoting cessation among PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE COVID-19 disease has killed over half a million Americans but our present understanding of its pathogenesis remains based on observational studies that have not reached a clear consensus mechanism. To address this gap in knowledge we have engineered mice that become infected by SARS-CoV-2 virus in a manner that faithfully reflects the human disease, including lethal lung disease and hypoxemia, and in which we can prevent or confer infection of specific cell types to define their roles. We will use these new mouse models and infection of human and mouse lung slices to functionally determine the cellular mechanisms that underlie COVID-19 lung disease, an important step in designing new therapies and halting future outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Older adults with serious illness and their caregivers have high rates of anxiety and limited access to effective, non-pharmacological treatments. A recent National Academy of Medicine report recommended increased emphasis on disseminating and implementing evidence-based psychotherapies in order to have maximal public health impact. Through this work, I will identify a sustainable and potentially scalable dyadic intervention and delivery model to manage symptoms of anxiety in older adults with serious illness and their caregivers in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Typical development of both the optical and neural visual systems is dependent on the quality and alignment of images formed by the eyes. The goal of the proposed research is to understand how infants and young children are able to focus and align their eyes despite the immaturities in their vision, and how clinical conditions can disrupt this coordination. These studies are designed to understand typical and atypical development with the goal of improving clinical care and the prevention of strabismus and amblyopia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The renewal of the IRACDA at Rutgers – INSPIRE Postdoctoral Training Program - will support the training opportunities for INSPIRE Fellows, postdoctoral fellows who will be prepared to excel as the next generation of scientist-educators. INSPIRE postdoctoral training in research and education will be provided at Rutgers University, a public institution that trains over 700 postdoctoral fellows each year. Finally and most importantly, this Training Program will support the education and research environment at three public institutions, Medgar Evers College – CUNY, New Jersey City University, NJ, and William Paterson University, NJ, that have a demonstrated commitment to educating undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in biomedical research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Hearing loss is one of the leading causes of disability in America. Many profoundly deaf adults significantly benefit from cochlear implantation, but the hearing outcomes following this procedure are highly variable. The proposed study aims to investigate audiovisual integration and cortical plasticity in cochlear implant users to better understand and predict cochlear implant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Kansas State University will partner with three community colleges in southwest Kansas to continue a highly successful Bridges to the Future Baccalaureate program under the new T34 funding mechanism. The overall purpose of K-State's Bridges program is to increase the number of underrepresented students with baccalaureate degrees in biomedical, clinical, behavioral and social sciences, and to set into motion pathways designed to increase the number of PhDs, MDs, and other professional doctorates in those fields. Our proposal will provide authentic research experiences within biomedical science labs, additional research training and mentoring, and professional skills development in an inclusive and supportive environment in order to assist the National Institutes of Health in recruiting talented individuals with unique perspectives and experiences to the biomedical workforce.
