IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interaction between kelch-like ECH-associating protein 1 (Keap1) and nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)- like 2 (Nrf2), a key regulator of cellular redox homeostasis, has been studied as a potential drug target for neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s Disease, in which aging and oxidative stress play a central role. Current developments are limited by specificity, bioactivity, and pharmacokinetic properties, creating a need for clinically translatable Keap1-inhibiting/Nrf2-inducing therapeutics. This proposal seeks to address these challenges by utilizing a novel peptide delivery system that allows for the protected delivery of Nrf2 inducing peptides either alone or with the addition of other functional motifs through the protein-like polymer platform.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Robust data are required to investigate the impact of technology and digital media (TDM) use on preschool children’s health and development outcomes. Novel, passive, objective assessments of young children’s TDM use will be combined with state-of-the art measurements of children’s sleep and executive function tasks, to identify the influence of TDM use on children’s weight status, sleep, and development over the short- and long-term (12 months). Findings will provide stronger evidence to inform future guidelines for children’s TDM use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic instability is a hallmark of many disease conditions, including cancers, and is often caused by replication defects. Our work aims understand in greater detail the varied mechanisms by which cells respond to replication stress by studying the interplay between RNA dependent processes and DNA replication integrity. Adequately understanding these processes will improve our understanding of the molecular underpinnings of genome maintenance and provide critical novel insights that can be exploited in novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Fused in sarcoma (FUS) is an RNA binding protein that can form biomolecular condensates via liquid-liquid phase separation. Aberrant FUS condensates can seed pathogenic aggregation that leads to neurodegenerative diseases, ALS and FTD. Based on our recent finding that the RNA helicase DDX6 regulates FUS condensation in cells, I propose to apply a combination of single molecule, biochemical, and cell-based methods to determine the effect of DDX6 on wildtype and ALS/FTD-linked FUS mutant activity. Understanding the molecular mechanism behind FUS granule maintenance could help illuminate ALS/FTD pathogenesis and possibly lead to new routes of ALS/FTLD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Schizophrenia is a chronic and disabling psychiatric disorder, with modestly effective available treatments, and poorly understood brain mechanisms. Since the visual system is one of the most extensively studied neural systems in basic neuroscience, this study aims to understand the neural mechanisms of the visual impairments in schizophrenia, through behavioral experiments, computer simulations of the neural networks, and neuroimaging. Such a mechanistic understanding of schizophrenia could lead to novel targets for therapeutic interventions and potentially yield objective biomarkers of response to treatment and facilitate early detection strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A remarkable feature of epithelial stem cells is their ability to rapidly detect, respond, and endure environmental perturbations. This project aims to develop an integrative genetic platform to investigate how epithelial stem cells sense and adapt to inflammation by modulating immune cells to rebuild a new niche and by reprograming their metabolism to reduce inflammatory damage. The goal of this project is to understand how these adaptive functions of epithelial stem cells promote successful wound repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In normal perception, audiovisual interactions can have many beneficial perceptual consequences, including faster reaction times, more accurate judgments, or more rapid learning, while multisensory impairments such as audiovisual speech facilitation are an intermediate phenotype of psychiatric diseases such as schizophrenia and autism. Understanding the circuitry mediating audiovisual influences during early sensory processing is thus likely to lead to improved multisensory learning paradigms, improved neural prosthetics, or improved understanding of the biological bases of neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This implementation science planning grant aims to elicit preference-driven strategies to tailor contextually appropriate antiretroviral therapy (ART) packages, including long-acting injectables (LAI), for youth living with HIV (YLWH) in South Africa. The design will: (1) leverage the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) to qualitatively identify implementation barriers and facilitators and inform LAI delivery and messaging; (2) utilize a partial preference trial among YLWH 18-29 years to identify choices and trajectories around early LAI; and (3) conclude with microsimulation model of trial participants to assess the benefits of LAI vs oral ART (pills) for different subgroups of YLWH. Findings will provide clarity around which YLWH may most benefit from LAIs and which strategies should be delivered to those patients in a subsequent sequential multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) to optimize treatment for YLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed ROAM system objectively determines the duration and pattern of adherence to oxygen therapy on a minute-by-minute basis and provides feedback of usage metrics to patients and clinicians. The proposed SBIR Phase II research addresses an important public health concern by providing accurate assessment of patient adherence to oxygen therapy and promoting adherence to a treatment that many patients neglect. The ultimate impact will be to improve health outcomes and reduce the costs associated with expensive and preventable hospitalizations due to non-adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative The rapidly increasing prevalence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) in the US and worldwide represents a public health crisis and a key health disparity. Improved options for T2D prediction, prevention, and treatment are urgently needed. This proposal builds on a longstanding, highly productive collaboration between researchers in the United States, Finland, and around the world. We will discover and fine map genetic loci that influence risk of T2D and variability in T2D-related traits, and identify the causal variants, genes, and other functional units in the genome, and the mechanisms by which they act. Our ultimate goals are disease prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aging is the single most significant risk factor for cancer. Although there are many plausible age-related mechanisms that mediate the increased risk for cancer in the elderly, functional evidence is lacking for the majority of these mechanisms. This proposal will focus on the role of the aged microenvironment, particularly senescence, in promoting the formation of colorectal cancer (CRC), a common age-related cancer in the U.S.  Our group has recently shown that a senescent normal colon tissue microenvironment, which includes fibroblasts, immune cells, stromal proteins, and secreted proteins, can promote the neoplastic behavior of colon cells. Based on our preliminary data, we will study the effects of senescent fibroblasts that accumulate in elderly people and their secreted proteins to promote the tumorigenesis of colon epithelial cells that have acquired age-related oncogenic mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/LAY SUMMARY We have discovered that a protein called PD-L1, best known for regulating the immune system through interactions outside of cells, also acts inside immune suppressing T regulatory cells to promote their activity. We have found that intracellular PD-L1 suppresses anti-tumor immunity and promotes the progression of triple negative breast cancer, an aggressive subtype which stage for stage has worse prognosis than other subtypes of breast cancer. Our goal in this proposal is two-fold: 1) investigate how intracellular PD-L1 and the PD-L1 cytoplasmic domain influences T regulatory cell development and function and 2) test whether targeting PD-L1 inside of cells (as opposed to outside of cells where clinically available PD-L1 inhibitors act) can promote anti- tumor immunity to improve triple negative breast cancer therapy.

PHR: Project narrative  A major impediment to emergency department (ED)-based HIV/HCV screening success is that often ED patients at risk for, or later diagnosed with, HIV and HCV decline testing. In this R01 project, we will assess how well a promising, easy-to-use, one-time, minimal-training-needed, very brief persuasive health communication intervention (PHCI) increases acceptance of testing among adult ED patients who either currently, formerly or never injected drugs and initially declined HIV/HCV screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Haskell-KU Bridge project will diversify the scientific workforce by increasing the likelihood of American Indian / Alaskan Native students attaining baccalaureate degrees and future careers in biomedical, bioengineering, behavioral and health sciences. Our vision is for American Indian and Alaska Native students to see a place for themselves in bioscience careers, to build the skills and resources they need to succeed, and to create a compassionate community of mentors invested in the success of students. The program fosters interactions between Haskell Indian Nations University students and faculty and University of Kansas research mentors to prepare American Indian / Alaska Native students for a broad range of bioscience careers of particular relevance to the needs of Native communities, while increasing the degree attainment of one of the most under-represented groups in STEM fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  This proposal is focused on a major lung disease of older Americans, idopathic pulmonary fibrosis. In IPF, the lungs become stiff and patients experience increasing shortness of breath, often leading to lung failure and death within two to three years. We will explore whether simple drugs related to oils and fats that might be provided as part of the diet can maintain normal function in the lung and slow the progression of pulmonary fibrosis.

PHR: NARRATIVE Regulation of the cellular signaling pathways that control the actin cytoskeleton is essential in development and homeostasis. This application focuses on the LIM domain kinases, enzymes which are key regulators of the actin cytoskeleton, and their upstream kinases, the MRCKs. We aim to delineate the atomic-level mechanism of LIMK and MRCK control, to understand how the dual specificity kinases can phosphorylate a range of substrates, and how the LIMKs are recruited to the MRCKs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The last step in cell division, abscission, relies on a transient structure called the midbody, which resides inside the intercellular bridge between newly forming daughter cells. It consists of overlapping spindle midzone microtubules which are coated with electron dense material called the midbody matrix. Long conceptualized as a structural remnant subject to degradation following cytokinesis, emerging data suggest that midbody remnants (MBsomes) play instructive post-mitotic roles in establishing cell fate, proliferation state, tissue polarity, cilia formation, neuron function, and oncogenesis. However, very little is known about the functional significance of the electron dense material. My lab has uncovered a surprising novel function for this electron dense material in that it is a site of RNA storage and is a novel actively translating RNP granule with a uniquely complex life cycle comprised of both membrane-less and membrane-bound phases, that we are calling the MB-granule (for Midbody-granule). Our current research goals are to understand how the midbody behaves as a novel form of intercellular communication, to define distinct therapeutic targets for midbody-mediated human diseases that range from cancer to neurodegeneration.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of new metabolic connections between proteins and metabolites is ultimately expected to increase our range of treatable disease, which will lead to new therapeutics and increase healthy lifespan. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the overwhelming cause of death in solid organ tumors like colorectal cancer but remains poorly understood at the molecular level. We have discovered a critical role for the type 3 inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate receptor (ITPR3), a protein involved in controlling intracellular calcium signaling, in facilitating colorectal cancer metastasis to the liver. The proposed research will define the mechanisms by which ITPR3 allows colorectal cancer cells to overcome physiological barriers like extracellular matrix detachment to colonize distant tissues and test its potential as a therapeutic target, leading to innovative strategies to block cancer recurrence or progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinopathy of prematurity is a leading cause of childhood blindness worldwide. The fovea, a critical location in the retina determining visual acuity and visual function, and the blood vessels around it, are maldeveloped in infants with retinopathy of prematurity. However, how these blood vessels form during development of the human fovea remains unclear. This research will advance our understanding of the fundamental knowledge of how the blood vessels around the fovea form in infants, and how they change in diseased states such as preterm birth or retinopathy of prematurity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: Immunotherapy drugs are most effective when used in combination but can be very toxic. Here we propose a new approach to confine immunotherapy drugs to tumors, by binding the drugs to the most common vaccine adjuvant, alum. Alum-bound therapeutics can be injected intratumorally and stimulate an immune response that attacks cancer throughout the body, providing a promising strategy to create safer and more effective immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While it is clear that the microbiota play a key role in human health, we lack an understanding of the physiological processes that determine microbiota composition across the body. To address this gap, the the goals of this proposal are to i) identify relationships between host genes and mucosal bacteria and archaea, ii) identify non-prokaryotic elements of the human microbiome associated with human gene expression and ii) demonstrate causal relationships between the microbiome and host gene expression. Ultimately, the results of this project will inform our understanding of the relationship between the microbiota and host in health and disease and highlight areas of interest for novel, microbiome-based therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Response inhibition is a key aspect of learned behavior and is impaired in a variety of neurological disorders that involve impulsivity, including Huntington’s disease, Tourette’s syndrome, and obsessive-compulsive disorder. This project uses in vivo and ex vivo approaches in mouse models to investigate cortical and thalamic influences on the neural circuits of the dorsal striatum, an important site of sensory-motor integration and learning. The results of this project will further our understanding of the neural circuit mechanisms underlying learned response inhibition and have implications for understanding and treatment of impulsive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Title: Coordination of molecular motor activity in intracellular transport and assembly of cytoskeletal architecture. P.I. – Richard J. McKenney Project Narrative: The cytoskeleton of cells is a system of molecular filaments used as highways for the transport of cargo within living cells, a process critical for human health and disease. Molecular motor molecules actively move along these filaments carrying cargo to specific destinations within cells, but how this process is regulated for correct cargo transport is not understood. This proposal seeks to answer basic questions about how cells control this process, with a long-term goal to provide new avenues of inquiry into the mechanisms of the many diseases related to impaired cytoskeletal function, such as ALS, Huntington’s disease, and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treated categorically, anxiety and depression demonstrate high co-morbidity and poor discriminability and inter-rater reliability, likely stemming from their high genetic correlation and shared symptomatology along a distress subfactor of internalizing symptoms. The proposed research would provide a critical step in advancing our understanding of the neurodevelopmental signatures related to symptom dimensions of anxiety and depression. The innovative analytic and data acquisition approaches proposed stand to provide information to clinicians regarding neurodevelopmental biomarkers for individualized therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE 20 million Americans battle with substance use disorder, typically initiated during adolescence. This project will derive risk scores forecasting hazardous substance use in high school students through complex analyses of brain imaging, demographic, health, and cognitive test data. The proposed novel analysis will use two large, longitudinal, publicly-available datasets (National Consortium on Alcohol and Neurodevelopment in Adolescence and Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development) and if our forecasting is accurate, future studies can assess the potential of the risk scores for enhancing preventative care within precision medicine settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the spectrum of genetic mutations in myeloid leukemia has been comprehensively studied, the relevance of the diversity of mutations within a single patient remains a significant hurdle in delivering efficacious therapy to patients. The proposed research here will use mouse models to identify contexts in which oncogenic FLT3 mutations are necessary for disease progression. These studies will provide insights into improved therapeutic strategies for patients with FLT3-mutant acute myeloid leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Knowledge of human central nervous system (CNS) development has been significantly limited by the availability of human nervous tissues. This research will apply recent advances in stem cell-based in vitro models of human CNS development to investigate some key molecular and cellular events involved in early human CNS development. In addition to advancing knowledge of human CNS development, our research could assist in the rational design of differentiation protocols of human stem cells for CNS disease modeling and cell therapy, and in high-throughput drug and toxicity screens for prevention and treatment of CNS diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it aims to improve the quality and safety care delivered by providers in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs). The research is significant because it will improve neonatal patient safety by changing the way NICU provider workload is measured and used for workload management, organizational learning, and improvement. The project is innovative because it will use data readily accessible in electronic health records to develop a new multi-level model of workload for neonatal nurse practitioners and use this model to guide the design and development a future clinical decision support tool for provider workload management and safety improvement.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pathophysiology has been associated with impaired clearance of neuroinflammatory proteins, (e.g., amyloid-beta) and implicated in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, but the role of CSF dynamics in neurodevelopmental disorders remains unknown. This Career Development Award aims to address this gap by elucidating and contrasting trajectories of CSF characteristics in Down Syndrome (DS) and related disorders (autism spectrum disorder and Fragile X syndrome) across the first two years of life, to determine the relationships between CSF physiology and later neural and clinical features. Given that 50% of children with DS will go on to develop early-onset Alzheimer’s, CSF physiology can serve as a mechanistic pathway to aberrant brain and behavioral development and has the potential to guide the design of targeted treatment approaches for early intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The muscles of stroke survivors can fatigue faster compared to muscles in people who have not had a stroke, which can limit how long a person with stroke can perform tasks such as walking. This study will examine how blood flow is regulated to the exercising leg muscle post-stroke, because if the muscle does not receive enough blood flow it will become fatigued. Finally, we will use a safe and simple non-invasive intervention called ischemic conditioning, which has known effects to improve blood flow to exercising muscle and determine the effects on muscle fatigue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public health narrative. The United States has seen dramatic increases in fatal overdoses due to heroin, counterfeit prescription opioids, and cocaine adulterated with fentanyl or fentanyl-like compounds. The present project will address this issue by developing vaccines directed against fentanyl and fentanyl-like compounds, offering a safe and cost-effective strategy to reduce illicit opioid use and likelihood of fatal overdose in opioid users and individuals in professions at high-risk of accidental overdoses from occupational exposure to fentanyl and fentanyl analogs (e.g., law enforcement or airport personnel). We propose to develop fentanyl vaccines, and to perform studies that would allow them to enter clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of programmed cell death accompanies many disease states, where abnormal death leads to organ and tissue degeneration, while insufficient death leads to cancer. Patients with Huntington’s disease, aggressive cancers, progeria and laminopathies display morphological features of novel non-apoptotic Linker Cell-type Death (LCD) discovered in C. elegans. The discovery of mammalian LCD genes would have immediate applications, from development of new markers to distinguish when LCD is employed in vertebrate development and disease, to suggesting methods for inducing and inhibiting LCD, with a long-term goal of providing in-roads for therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aberration of the microtubule-associated tau protein is a pathological hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases collectively known as tauopathies that include Alzheimer's disease (AD). Despite overwhelming evidence implicating defects in mitochondria in general and mitochondrial Complex I in particular in tauopathies, mitochondria and Complex I have not been the focus of therapeutic development targeting tauopathies. This project will test a novel hypothesis on how pathogenic tau may affect mitochondrial Complex I function and has the potential to validate a new therapeutic target for tauopathies and possibly other brain diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence (IPV) affects 1 in 4 American women, and surveys of victims suggest that physical child abuse occurs in 30-60% of homes with IPV, but these data have not resulted in the routine evaluation of physical abuse in children exposed to IPV. IPV may serve as a “sentinel” event and may provide an opportunity for early recognition and secondary prevention of physical abuse in a child who is exposed to IPV. In this study, we will identify barriers to and facilitators of the screening of IPV-exposed children who have been reported to a local child protective services agency for exposure to IPV, perform intervention mapping to develop and implement a Family-Centered Care (FCC) model for children and caregivers living with IPV, and finally, conduct a pilot trial of the FCC model to assess its acceptability and feasibility.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a major public health problem. The Dementia Risk Pooling Project (DRPP) will pool and rigorously harmonize 11 prospective observational cohorts to develop an accurate and personalized, dynamic dementia risk prediction model to identify high risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Antibodies against factor VIII (inhibitors) occur in 20-30% of patients with severe hemophilia A following life- saving factor VIII replacement therapy, rendering treatment less effective, with no current therapies available to prevent their formation. Type I interferons are cytokines that play a role in the initiating immune steps of inhibitor development and are an attractive potential therapeutic target for decreasing inhibitor formation and/or predicting those patients at risk of developing inhibitors. The ability to prevent or predict inhibitor development will reduce the public health burden associated with the increased morbidity/mortality, decreased quality of life, and significant expense associated with the treatment of hemophilia A patients with inhibitors. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender individuals have higher rates of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections than cisgender individuals. Transgender men or transmasculine individuals were assigned female sex at birth but identify along the masculine spectrum, and testosterone is often administered to transgender men and other transmasculine persons as part of the treatment for gender reassignment. The goal of this project is to characterize the changes that occur in the vagina as a result of testosterone exposure using a model of vaginal tissue that has been constructed from the cells found in the vagina that will allow us to mimic transmasculine physiology and determine if testosterone alters the tissue in such a way that the immune response is impaired, increasing the risk of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Cognitive decline is a clinical hallmark of late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD), costing millions of elderly individuals’ quality of life years. Synapse loss is highly correlated with cognitive decline, and seen early in LOAD and aging; while potential neuronal-microglial interactions mediating this loss have been identified, it remains unknown how these interactions are triggered in aging and confer vulnerability to LOAD. This proposal will elucidate specific upstream, age-related neuronal calcium and mitochondrial dysregulation that may trigger synapse loss, providing potential key therapeutic targets to preempt cognitive decline, and thus extending the number of healthy, active years of life.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood obesity and asthma are major public health problems for U.S. children but effective strategies to prevent these problems are not available. Leveraging genetic, microbiomic, and clinical data from thousands of demographically diverse children in the NIH ECHO Program, we will examine the causal role of the early-life microbiome in the development of obesity and asthma. This research has the potential to offer a strong evidence base for the future development of targeted microbiome interventions to prevent childhood obesity and asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Research Narrative. Brain function requires the coordinated action of hundreds or thousands of intermingled neurons. These neurons form groups to encode sensory perception and motor actions. We will use new technology to see how these groups of neurons influence each other during visually guided actions in a way that has never before been possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Michigan Center for Contextual Factors in Alzheimer's Disease (MCCFAD) focuses on the social and behavioral contexts in which Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) are experienced. MCCFAD will lead a coordinated effort to advance diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility in health research focusing on three priority areas: ADRD epidemiology, health economics, and culturally sensitive care as it seeks to diversify the research in and workforce dedicated to ADRD and advance social and behavioral ADRD research among underserved and underrepresented communities. The Center engages directly with Middle Eastern and North African (MENA) and Latino communities, and links with African Americans through its partnerships with Michigan NIA Centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are important in the progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD), but how they are regulated is not well understood. Recent studies indicate that the microbiome may regulate astrocyte activation, and the proposed research will utilize innovative imaging and RNA sequencing technologies to fully understand the profile of astrocytes upon microbiome perturbation in a mouse model of AD. Sequencing data will be leveraged to understand whether modulation of astrocyte pathways can alter AD pathology and represent a therapeutic strategy for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Sleep is vitally important for brain function and survival, yet its core process remains one of the most poorly understood features of life. We will apply novel methods to reveal generalizable principles about the role of sleep/experience in shaping neural circuits in the brain. In the long term, our results will enhance an understanding of the contribution of sleep to healthy cognition and the mechanisms by which disrupted sleep worsens neurodegenerative and mental health disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Candida auris are major causes of antifungal resistant infections worldwide, which carry high mortality rates. We hypothesize that bloodstream and other invasive infections by C. auris are caused by mixed populations of genetically and phenotypically distinct strains, rather than a single strain as long believed. In this project, we will characterize genetic and phenotypic diversity of C. auris strains recovered from blood cultures of individual patients, and implicate specific genes in antibiotic tolerance and resistance, and in virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is a leading cause of disability in the United States, often leading to acquired language deficits that affects one’s personal and financial wellbeing due to the barriers it places on participation in social and professional activities. Current treatments can promote some limited recovery, but residual disability remains a problem. This research will meet a public health need by investigating whether treatment outcomes can be enhanced with transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS), an approach that has been successful in promoting rehabilitation from stroke-induced deficits affecting motor processing as well as other neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Scientific and Public Outreach of Cell Type Taxonomies (SPOCTT) initiative is to increase accessibility of brain cell types and taxonomies to the general and scientific communities by improving associated web resources such as tutorials and documentation, supporting cross-consortia collaboration, offering live and webinar training, and supporting educational and general public outreach. This initiative aims to set reference Allen Institute and BICCN taxonomies as industry standards by consolidating and disseminating resources for their standardization, comparison, and exploration. In essence, the SPOCTT initiative will ensure that more people understand and utilize the exciting cell type findings coming from high impact BICCN- and BICAN-funded projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging Asian and Pacific Americans (APAs) face risks for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), stress from immigration and acculturation, as well as pandemic-related social isolation. The Resource Center for Alzheimer’s and Dementia Research in Asian and Pacific Americans (RCASIA) will identify, mentor, and elevate underrepresented scientists to conduct AD/ADRD-related behavioral, social, and economic research in disaggregated APA populations to improve their brain health, care, and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Stem Cell-Derived Exosomes, MrgD and Vascular Cognitive Impairment in Aging Narrative This proposal tests a novel hypothesis that in aging individuals stem cells interact with blood vessels in the brain via secreting nanovescilces and induce dysfunction, which eventually causes cognitive decline. The proposal furthermore tests if a peptide called Alamandine can reverse dysfunctions induced by aging stem cells and prevent cognitive decline. If carried out successfully, this proposal will provide proof-of-concept for a novel therapeutic target for the treatment of aging- associated cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nuclear stress imaging is a common test ordered for older patients presenting with symptoms of ischemic heart disease (e.g., chest pain or dyspnea), however the results of the stress test often do not lead to evidence-based changes in treatment for older patients. In the current study, we aim to understand older adults and caregiver perspectives on how they make treatment decisions after a stress test, whether age-related impairments in function or cognition would affect their decision making and identify which outcomes are most valuable for them; and study how physicians currently incorporate these factors and the imaging test result into treatment plans and how choice of treatment affects patient outcomes. The results of this study will be used to develop decision aids to help older patients make decisions regarding stress testing and choose treatments which can improve outcomes they most care about.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The exploding field of radio-theranostics makes nuclear imaging a central tool and redefines its performance requirements. Nuclear imaging technology is undergoing a paradigm shift focusing on utilizing timing information to enable a leap in image quality. Biomedical researchers need new simulation and experimental tools to develop these fast radiation detectors, which this project proposes to develop and apply with AI-based optical simulation software.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a mechanistic prospective study to define biomarkers that differentiate the pain response in OA patients to naproxen, duloxetine and placebo, three agents with different mechanisms and sites of action. With this information, we will define responder phenotypes for each of these agents which will then allow for personalized medicine, providing the therapeutic intervention most likely to be effective for relief of pain, thus also reducing the risks of exposure to non-effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Development of effective vaccines is the time-tested approach for controlling infectious diseases. The proposed work will improve mouse models of human immunity to vaccines and has the potential to develop vaccines that stimulate potent immunity to influenza virus and SARS-CoV-2. The findings from the proposed work are expected to have broad implications in the development of vaccines against respiratory viruses of humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Although young adult-born neurons (ABNs) have been shown to play an important role in memory and emotion processing under physiological conditions, their function and therapeutic potential in degenerated AD brains remain largely undefined. Our recent study showed activation of a small population of SuM-enhanced ABNs is sufficient to restore memory and reduce anxiety/depression-like behaviors in AD mice. This proposal aims to decipher the mechanisms underlying these beneficial effects using two complementary AD mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Host cells play an important role in virus infection. When the SARS-CoV-2 virus infects lung cells, then the activities of lung cells cause the inhibition of synthesis of two viral proteins, e.g., ORF1a and spike protein. This proposal wants to uncover the mechanistic insights of this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work aims to investigate the temporal relationships between mtDNA alterations and midlife brain health. This study will also examine childhood risk factors preceding mitochondrial dysfunction. Knowledge gained from this study may contribute important insights into the biology underlying brain health and provide novel strategies for the targeted prevention of mitochondrial dysfunction and its brain health sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project is to develop and validate a new cardiac magnetic resonance imaging method to measure the amount of oxygen extracted from the blood into the heart. We will validate this new noninvasive artificial intelligence-assisted imaging method, which requires no intravenous contrast, by comparing it with information obtained from invasive catheter-based measurements in preclinical models. We will also compare our new technique to Positron Emission Tomography (PET), a standard nuclear imaging technique, in patients with heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Completely noninvasive neuromodulation using transcranial ultrasound stimulation (TUS) offers the promise of precisely stimulating specific targets deep in the brain, such as the nucleus accumbens for substance abuse disorders, at low and safe power levels commonly used for diagnostic imaging studies. However, a current concern in the use of TUS in human studies is the potential for an auditory effect to confound the results, especially in studies susceptible to the placebo effect or attention effects. The purpose of this proposed research is to enable more rigorous, and therefore successful, TUS studies for the treatment of SUDs and other neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES, UNIVERSITY OF GHANA
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnancy in sickle cell disease (SCD) is a life-threatening complication associated with 23-fold increased odds of maternal death and a maternal mortality ratio of 2,393 and approximately 4,300 deaths per 100,000 live births with and without multidisciplinary care in low and middle-income countries; compared to the general maternal mortality rate of approximately 23.8 and 8 deaths per 100,000 live births in the USA and Northern Europe, respectively. In Ghana, a multidisciplinary SCD obstetrics program at an academic hospital reported a dramatic reduction in maternal and perinatal mortality rates; unfortunately, this academic facility caters to less than 20% of pregnant women with SCD in the Greater Accra Region. This mentored award is focused on initiating a hybrid type 1 study for multidisciplinary SCD obstetrics care program in a resource-limited non- academic hospital, a strategy that is expected to decrease maternal mortality in women with SCD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk for stroke is two-fold higher in people with HIV (PWH) compared to people without HIV, despite antiretroviral therapy (ART) and viral suppression, and without many of the traditional stroke risk factors, suggesting ongoing HIV-associated inflammation as a potential driver of stroke risk. Adherence to ART sufficient to suppress viral loads to below the clinically-relevant threshold of 200 copies/mL may not be adequate to suppress viremia completely, with ongoing HIV-associated inflammation. We will conduct a comparative observational study in virally suppressed PWH presenting with stroke compared to PWH without stroke to obtain preliminary, exploratory data on the association between stroke and imperfect adherence to ART, viremia and the viral reservoir, and exploratory proteomic biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is accompanied by changes at the organ as well as at the systemic level; one hallmark of aging is decline in immune function and increases in inflammation that hinder the immune response. Because there is great heterogeneity in aging trajectories, there is a need to understand what factors cause certain individuals to age faster, and in recent years research has shown that the social environment may affect the pace of aging. By using a non-human primate model that has similar aging trajectories to humans, this project will investigate if and how accumulation of social adversity may induce aging-related changes in immunity (both at baseline and in response to a stimulation), making social adversity a key component in the development of aging-related diseases and a possible target of behavioral interventions to prevent or mitigate them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Project Narrative  Given the health crisis presented by neurological conditions that develop as we age, it's important to understand the mechanisms underlying both normal and pathological cognitive change in order to develop scalable, evidence-based prevention and intervention strategies. This project will support the expansion, use, and widespread dissemination of the Mobile Toolbox Research Platform, an adaptable, open-source research ecosystem to enable remote smartphone-based cognitive and behavioral assessment. The ability to easily collect and share a broad spectrum of data from large and diverse participant samples can substantially improve aging research methods, have a meaningful impact on clinical outcomes, and ultimately improve the lives of older adults and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the world population is aging, living with more than one chronic condition (multimorbidity) is the norm rather than the exception and yet, older adults are often excluded from clinical trials based on multimorbidity or their age alone. Here we propose studies to understand the contributions of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic, inflammatory disease on survival, development of geriatric syndromes such as frailty, body composition, and quality of life in older adults with cancer. The goal of this research is to risk stratify older adults with RA and cancer at highest risk of mortality and development of geriatric syndromes and ultimately develop tailored approaches (based on this risk stratification) to improve their quality of life and potentially survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Given the insufficiency of current interventions to reduce or prevent the lifelong morbidity and mortality associated with neonatal herpes simplex virus (nHSV) infection, there is a critical need to develop new therapies. A promising strategy is to use monoclonal antibodies to recapitulate the protection associated with maternal antibodies whose placental transfer is capable of both virus neutralization and eliciting effector functions of the innate immune system. The development of effective vaccines and therapeutic antibodies for nHSV infections will benefit from a fuller understanding of antibody mechanism(s) of action that can prevent this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorder (SUD) and HIV are synergistic epidemics (syndemics) disproportionately affecting Black Americans, but SUD among Black people living with HIV is often undiagnosed and untreated. Therefore, we will implement and evaluate multi-level interventions including electronic patient portals for SUD screening and the Collaborative Care Model for SUD treatment to decrease structural barriers to SUD care. Our goal is to achieve health equity in SUD screening and treatment among Black people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health The identification, recruitment, selection, and mentorship of scientists from diverse backgrounds to conduct research on Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) (i.e., AD-RCMAR Scientists) and to launch their independent research careers will enhance the diversity of the aging research workforce. The work of the AD-RCMR Scientists and the San Diego Alzheimer’s Disease Resource Center for Minority Aging Research will promote critical advances in our understanding and ability to target multilevel factors and interventions to address ADRD inequities among Hispanics/Latinos, limited English proficient (LEP) and refugee communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Autonomic ganglia in the pelvis originate from neural crest progenitors during development although  little is known about the regulatory mechanisms that control diversity of neuron types in these ganglia, which are essential for control of bladder contractility during urination. We propose novel  experimental approaches using a newly developed mouse model that has defects in neural crest  development to determine the genes and mechanisms that are required for formation of the normal  complement of neuron types in pelvic ganglia. These studies will provide greater understanding of  how defects in development of the peripheral nervous system predispose children to abnormal  bladder function while establishing a framework of gene networks that can be used to promote the  formation of normal pelvic neurons for treatment of lower urinary tract disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Understanding how memories of past experiences are stored and retrieved in the brain is a question with immediate relevance to conditions that affect memory such as Alzheimer's disease, epilepsy, stroke and normal aging, but also to disorders such as schizophrenia and autism for which there is increasing evidence of a link between memory-processing brain systems and functions such as thinking, planning and imagination of future experiences. This proposal aims to take fundamental steps toward establishing a model of memory storage and retrieval, in terms of the way brain cells signal to each other both during active behavior and during rest states. We will perform causal tests of how specific sequenced patterns of activity called "replay" contribute to memory, causal tests of how different circuits are involved in producing these patterns, and advanced measurements of how sequenced patterns in different circuits are synchronized, to provide new insight into a fundamental mechanism of memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The molecular mechanisms that drive disease pathogenesis in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) have not been unequivocally identified, and new molecular targets potentially involved in the etiology of AD continue to emerge. We found that levels of GDAP1, a poorly understood protein that regulates cellular redox and mitochondrial morphology in response to oxidative stress, are significantly reduced in the brains of AD patients and AD human induced neurons (iNs), which is consistent with a putative role for GDAP1 in oxidative damage in AD. We will test the hypothesis that GDAP1 detoxifies the toxic product of lipid peroxidation 4HNE,and that reduced GDAP1 levels predispose cells affected by AD to oxidative damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This trial will evaluate the CATSystem - a web-based, system-level intervention that addresses persistent gaps in cervical cancer care by facilitating guideline-adherent services to optimize the cervical cancer screening and treatment cascade of care. Cervical cancer is preventable, thus innovative approaches are critically needed in Kenya to improve cervical cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Narrative This project explores strategies to identify and resolve disparities associated with risk score-based eligibility criteria for medication therapy management (MTM) services in the Enhanced MTM program for Medicare. This project is highly relevant to public health because its long-term goal is to improve health outcomes among the diverse older adult population by reducing disparities in medication utilization. Further, since initiatives by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services usually spur national changes, our study can exert an impact beyond Medicare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Carbohydrate binding proteins (CBPs) are a broad category of proteins involved diverse biological processes that either guard against disease or that promote it. These proteins are involved in cancer, infectious disease, immunity, autoimmunity, diabetes, and fibrosis, to name a few. This project will develop technologies that enable rapid discovery of CBP inhibitors, which would enable us to treat disease and to untangle the complex web of CBP functions that are currently poorly understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental conditions determine if and how individuals interact with one another; yet the complexity of the nervous system of mammals such as mice and humans has limited a mechanistic understanding of how environmental influences shape sensory processing and social behavior. This project is designed to leverage natural variation in the simple nervous system of Drosophila to reveal the mechanistic basis of environmental control over social behaviors. The work will help inform our understanding of neuropsychiatric conditions such as depression, autism and schizophrenia, characterized by the deficiency to appropriately process environmental cues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Project Narrative The University of Southern California’s Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias Resource Center for Minority Aging Research (USC AD/ADRD RCMAR) brings a distinct capacity for integrating theories and tools from myriad disciplines including but not limited to economics, sociology, and gerontology, using large, complex data sets, and applying rigorous panel data and quasi-experimental methods to generate innovative AD/ADRD disparities research. Our interdisciplinary faculty have the support and expertise to advance research in our focus area: pathways by which social, behavioral and economic factors, and policies and health systems affect disparities in risk of AD/ADRD, and affect disparities in the health, health care and economic outcomes of persons living with dementia. We build upon our successful 10-year history and bring together the infrastructure, leadership, interdisciplinary expertise and resources to: (1) increase the number, diversity, and scholarly achievements of scholars of dementia health equity research and; (2) develop new, innovative lines of research to advance dementia health equity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sympathetic nervous activity alters the function of all major organ systems and impairments in sympathetic function are involved in the leading causes of death in the US (heart disease, cancer, diabetes). Recent work indicates that the autonomic and immune systems closely interact. This proposal will test the hypothesis that macrophages, a type of immune cell, are critical in controlling sympathetic activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this project is to build an integrated computational and experimental platform for mapping functional dynamics within tissue to a high-resolution atlas of its molecular and cellular composition. Such a method will link structure with function at both high breadth in coverage — measuring a large fraction of all single cells in a given tissue region — and high molecular depth, by leveraging complementary genomic datasets to guide adaptive rounds of increasingly detailed imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are emerging environmental pollutants in drinking and groundwater and the EPA estimates that the drinking water of more than 110 million Americans may already be contaminated with PFAS. Epidemiological studies have shown that the occurrence of PFAS in humans is probably linked to a high incidence of thyroid disease, high cholesterol, ulcerative colitis, kidney cancer, testicular cancer, and pregnancy- induced hypertension. TDA Research, Inc (TDA) proposes to develop an adsorption-based system for removing PFAS from drinking water down to EPA prescribed limits of 70 ppt and the even lower limits (10 ppt or less) expected in the future. 15

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extended periods of musculoskeletal disuse and unloading, such as found during paralysis, bedrest, and or spaceflight, increase the risk of bone and muscle weakness and fragility fracture. Treatment options for patients with fractures during musculoskeletal disuse are limited because very little is known about how mechanical loads (or lack thereof) are sensed by different bone cell populations to regulate healing. This project seeks to use a controllable muscle and bone loading platform to identify what mechanical interventions and molecular mechanisms are necessary to improve fracture healing and muscle strength during extended disuse.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the prevalence of skin diseases are very high in LMICs, especially in children, dermatological services in LMICs are lacking mainly due to lack of clinical skills, and further, ways to document and store clinical course which is important for individual patient follow-up do not exist. If there is a field-adapted platform for data collection and sharing for skin conditions allowing clinical decision support for healthcare providers onsite, and remotely through teledermatology, this could serve as a breakthrough to management of skin diseases in this underserved populations. In this project, we will complete the development and optimization of a powerful and comprehensive, but easy-to-use smartphone / tablet application tool that addresses these gaps, envisioning Skin Health for All.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The burden of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) falls disproportionately on the populations of older adults who are from under-represented backgrounds. Research on minority aging to understand racial/ethnic disparities in AD/ADRD and to develop interventions and preventive strategies to reduce cognitive impairment and dementia risk is urgently needed. A goal of this renewal Johns Hopkins Alzheimer’s Disease Resource Center for Minority Aging Research application is to train and support early- stage investigators from diverse backgrounds who are carrying out ADRD-relevant research that supports cognitive health and well-being in older adults from under-represented backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the prevalence of fentanyl continues to rise, there is an urgent need to better understand how we can successfully engage more people in treatment that decreases morbidity and mortality related to opioid use disorder. The work described in this K23 application will investigate the initiation of buprenorphine in the setting of fentanyl use from both the patient and provider perspectives. We will utilize novel methods to develop and pilot a buprenorphine initiation toolkit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: RELEVANCE Ischemic stroke accounts for the vast majority of acute stroke cases and constitutes a leading cause of deaths among adults and permanent disabilities in survivors. The overall narrow treatment windows and potential risks largely limit the patient eligibility for the current thrombolytic therapy and mechanical thrombectomy, and thus identification of new drug targets is urgently needed to innovate and diversity the treatment of this devastating emergency. The proposed research will develop novel drug-like antagonists for the EP2 receptor, an emerging therapeutic target for brain ischemia-promoted neuroinflammation, and may lead to a new strategy to treat ischemic stroke and subsequent behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracortical microstimulation (ICMS) is a versatile tool to study the fundamental physiology of the nervous system and restore sensation in neuroprosthetics; however, the basic neurobiological mechanisms, with relation to which cell types are activated, in what spatiotemporal activation, and how they contribute to therapeutic efficacy remain poorly understood. There has been an increased appreciation of astrocytes' contribution to regulating proper coordination of neural activity during sensory processing, but it still remains unclear how astrocytes respond to ICMS on a network level and how their activation modulates neuronal activity. Using a combination of two-photon microscopy, mesoscale imaging, and optogenetics or genetic manipulation of astrocyte calcium activity, this proposal aims to determine the dynamic relationship between astrocyte and neuronal calcium activity during ICMS and understand how astrocytes respond to and may contribute to the therapeutic efficacy of ICMS paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will validate the clinical accuracy of an ab-initio physiomarker measured by flexible, wearable sensors in predicting aneurysm growth and dissection. It will allow health care practitioners to more accurately and safely make clinical decisions in recommending treatment for a patient's developing aortopathy; this will reduce the risk of sudden aneurysm rupture and potential mortality incurred by a reactive diagnostic strategy. Moreover, validating the accuracy of the stand-alone wearable sensor platform in measuring the physiomarker may lead to a new paradigm of at-home aneurysm monitoring, as well as enable screening for this aortopathy during patients' routine health checkups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic (R&E) minoritized persons with Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD) often receive poorer quality care than White patients, including lower rates of advance directives, reduced receipt of anti-dementia medications, and increased end-of-life hospitalizations. Although governmental and institutional policies influence R&E diversity in medical education/training and work environments, little is known about how R&E diversity in medical education, residency training, and health system leadership affect R&E disparities in AD/ADRD care. Applying innovative quasi-experimental methods to the nationally-representative comprehensive data on patients, physicians, medical schools, residency programs, and health systems, the proposed study will elucidate the effect of R&E diversity and cultural competency of medical school student bodies, residency programs, and health system boards on R&E disparities in AD/ADRD care and outcomes, providing new, policy-relevant information to develop interventions that could effectively eliminate such disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RESEARCH NARRATIVE Post-surgical pain causes significant suffering to patients, but physicians still lack an effective non-opioid therapy. We aim to determine if human birth tissue products can be developed to treat post-surgical pain and unravel a dual mode of drug action: reducing excitability of primary sensory neurons and hastening wound healing. We envision that these complementary drug actions may lead to a lasting pain relief and a potential “cure” for post-surgical pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Frontotemporal dementia is a major presenile dementia and shares common pathogenic mechanisms with the motor neuron disease ALS. GGGGCC repeat expansion in C9ORF72 is the most common genetic cause of both FTD and ALS. We will use cryo-electron microscopy and high-resolution template matching (HRTM) to investigate structural mechanisms of ribosomal defects in C9ORF72 patient neurons. If successful, these studies will open a new paradigm for developing novel therapeutic approaches for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Humans and other animals are constantly perceiving and interpreting events from their surroundings and using this information to choose appropriate behaviors. Exactly how the brain's neurons process sensory information and integrate information from different senses, however, remains unclear. Our work involves monitoring all of the brain's neurons simultaneously while the senses are stimulated, providing detailed and complete maps of the circuits that detect, process, and integrate sensory information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hydroxyurea (HU) is underutilized in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) like Nigeria due to barriers of adoption at the provider level. Using a mixed-methods implementation design, we will conduct our study in four sequential phases: Based on the Exploration, Preparation, Implementation, and Sustainment (EPIS) framework, and determine the inner organizational context, outer context, and implementation processes likely to influence SIM (Screen, Initiate, and Maintain) adoption of HU by providers at SPARC-NEt clinical sites to improve health outcomes for patients with SCD using the evidence-based TASSH TCP implementation strategy. The findings of this study have the potential to identify effective strategies for improving the management of SCD in Nigeria and other LMIC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a worsening health epidemic, incurring significant medical and societal costs. In this proposal, we will investigate rare variations in Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY) genes in the multi-ethnic Mount Sinai BioMe Biobank and the UK Biobank, with the goal of identifying novel associations to type 2 diabetes and MODY. The results will help inform diabetes prevention, diagnosis, and management, ultimately leading to improved personalized diabetes care in multi-ethnic populations.

PHR: Project Narrative Parasitic infections inflict a tremendous toll on human health, both nationally and globally. The Gordon Research Conference on Host-Parasite Interactions is the most prominent venue for scientific exchange at the leading edge of modern parasitology research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 40 million people across the globe are now living with HIV-1, of which the substance users constitute a disproportionate and “key population”, yet there is no cure or vaccine on the horizon. Using our recently developed bacteriophage T4 artificial virus vector technology, this proposal will establish a novel and affordable in vivo HIV cure platform that can be easily administered to substance users through one or two infusions. The HIV cure “drug” will target stem cells and introduce genetic modifications that confer resistance to HIV infection and then, by repopulating the body with HIV-resistant blood cells including resistant T cells, it replaces the HIV reservoir and leads to functional HIV cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The field of lipoprotein metabolism remains one of the most dynamic areas in biomedical sciences for both basic scientific inquiry and translational research, especially given the role of lipoproteins in modulating risk of cardiovascular disease and other metabolic disorders. The 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Lipoprotein Metabolism will feature emerging themes and cutting-edge concepts that can ultimately be translated into clinical benefit for the millions of patients whose risk of lipoprotein- associated cardiovascular disease cannot be adequately addressed by existing therapeutic strategies. The GRC and GRS – both premier, multidisciplinary scientific meetings – will provide a unique forum in which diverse scientists spanning from trainees to established investigators can enrich their knowledge base, engage in new collaborations, network, and advance the field of lipoprotein metabolism.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The existing research on obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is heavily focused on individuals of European ancestry and performed by researchers who are also primarily of European descent. In this project, we request funds to provide travel awards for underrepresented minority (URM) trainees to attend a conference specifically focused on OCD in Latin America. The conference will feature career development and mentoring sessions designed to increase the representation of URM trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Disruption of biological timekeeping is known to contribute to a range of disorders and the biomarkers used to diagnose disease and the effectiveness of treatment are strongly influenced by biological clocks. The 2024 Society for Research on Biological rhythms Meeting will bring together scientists from a wide range of fields, working on a diversity of model systems and at many different levels of biological organization. The goals of this meeting are to: (a) feature the latest research findings and methodological advances in the field; (b) showcase the emergence of Circadian Medicine; (c) support the professional development of trainees and junior faculty; and (d) broaden participation in the field of biological rhythms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The non-malignant stroma cells and extracellular matrix surrounding the tumor are essential for tumor progression and drug resistance. The meeting in Madison, WI will bring together clinical and laboratory-based scientists and trainees across the Midwest states to discuss their research progress and identify the critical challenges and emerging opportunities in the field. The primary objective is to foster collaborations among established scientists, early-stage investigators, and trainees and support the training of the next generation of scientists for careers focused on the tumor microenvironment.

PHR: Public Health Relevance The 7th International Enteric Nervous System Development Meeting: Connection, Cross-talk and Collaboration brings together cutting edge bench scientific research with current bedside clinical management, and includes a diverse group of geneticists, molecular and cellular biologists, physiologists, pathologists, physicians (gastroenterologists and surgeons), and stem cell researchers, who all share a common interest in the development and function of the enteric nervous system (ENS) as well as the treatment of neurointestinal diseases. A major goal of this conference grant is to increase the participation of young investigators, especially from groups traditionally under-represented in science such as women and minorities. This grant will support Travel Awards and Scientific Merit Awards for these bright young scientists and foster mentoring relationships that will give them invaluable opportunities and improve their likelihood of future success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application requests partial support for the 2024 FASEB Summer Research Conference on Cell Signaling in Cancer: from Mechanisms to Therapy, which is focused on the genetic, molecular, and biochemical mechanisms of cellular signal transduction in malignant transformation and proof-of-concept or clinically tractable means to translate these discoveries. Both basic/translational scientists and clinicians at this conference will be exposed to the emerging concepts in the cancer cell signaling field, including but not limited to including but not limited to Structure and Function of Signaling Complexes, Signaling in Space and Time in Cancer, Systems Biology and Proteomics, Nutrient Signaling and Metabolic Processes, Tumor Microenvironment, Modeling of Cancer and Chemical Biology. Together, participants will be encouraged to explore deeper mechanistic understanding of the contribution of dysfunctional cellular signaling networks to tumor initiation and progression, which was critical for the translation of drugs used clinically today, with the long-term goal of bringing precision medicine to cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Protecting our nation from chemical threats, whether industrial or existential, is the central mission of the NIH CounterACT Network, and this Annual Symposium is the main venue for the presentation of exciting new science and for the exchange of ideas across the network. The Symposium is also designed to allow the incorporation of new ideas from outside the current countermeasure community to help accelerate the program’s ability to address current threats and to lay the groundwork for identifying and interdicting emerging and future threats. Enlarging, and maintaining this particular community, as well as innovating across the field, are vital components of the mission of this 17th Annual CounterACT Network Symposium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Major advances in neuroscience have arisen through studies of diverse species with different brain organization, including invertebrates (e.g. nematodes, fruitfly) and vertebrates (e.g. fish, rodents, primates). Cephalopods represent the largest brains in the animal kingdom outside of vertebrates, but have been under-studied due to technical limitations. Several recent advances have accelerated the pace of research in cephalopod neuroscience over the past few years, and the proposed meeting will be the first ever to bring together this emerging and rapidly growing community.

PHR: The goal of the proposed State of the Science Meeting Series: Health and Safety of Gulf Coast and U.S. Caribbean Fishers is to disseminate unique occupational safety and health management strategies to benefit commercial and artisanal fishermen in the coastal Gulf South and the U.S. Caribbean. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNITED STATES ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF PAIN, INC.
PHR: Pain continues to be a significant health care problem because of its prevalence, its impact on those who suffer, and the absence of consistently effective therapeutic options devoid of deleterious consequences. To begin to address this problem, the USASP holds an annual scientific meeting that serves to facilitate dialog and interactions between pain scientists, health care providers and patients, disseminate and implement the latest findings, and facilitate the development of the next generation of pain scientists. As the connections made early in a career pay dividends over the long term, support for early career pain investigators is desperately needed to ensure safe and effective pain management in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “Modeling Hearing and Balance Disorders in Mice: The HEar@JAX Workshop” highlights the unique strengths of the laboratory mouse as a model to study human auditory and vestibular function in health and disease. Animal models are critical to the development of effective new therapeutic approaches for treating hearing loss and balance disorders. Explaining and demonstrating how mice can be used for that goal is also important for the correct public perception of animal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative DNA damage contributes to the development and progression of chronic human disease including cancer, cardiovascular, neurodegenerative diseases and aging. DNA repair is an essential cellular processes that removes the DNA damage and efficient DNA repair is essential to prevention of these chronic diseases. This symposium will bring together DNA repair researchers to discuss their newest research, to exchange ideas and to develop new collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Buelow, Hannes E. Project narrative The C. elegans Topic Meeting: Neuronal Development, Aging, Synaptic Function, and Behavior" is the cornerstone meeting for the worm neuroscience community. To enrich the C. elegans neuroscience research community the meeting will support and promote gender diversity, underrepresented groups and trainees and faculty from low- to middle-income countries. Lastly, to foster interactions between the C. elegans neuroscience and aging and metabolism community we will organize a joint session with the C. elegans Metabolism, Aging, Pathogenesis, and Stress on the first day of the CeNeuro2024 meeting focused on the neurobiology of aging, metabolism and neurodegeneration.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The Miami Pediatric Nephrology Seminar is entering its 50th anniversary year as a sustaining landmark conference for the sub-specialty of Pediatric Nephrology as well as its many affiliates to be held March 15-17, 2024, in Miami Beach, Florida. The seminar is seen as a unique opportunity for pediatric and adult nephrologists, renal pathologists, neonatologists, pediatric urologists, transplant surgeons, nurses, nutritionists, and allied health professionals from all over the United States and the world. This is accomplished by the inclusion of diverse outstanding faculty, permitting extensive discussions and exchange of ideas and serves to stimulate young trainees in areas of research development, to foster interest in pediatric nephrology as a career choice and develop international collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this conference is to improve definitions and innovations for identification and prevention of postoperative opioid-induced respiratory depression (OIRD) by developing working definition(s) of postoperative OIRD, outlining frameworks for the design of future clinical trials, and identifying opportunities for technology development to improve wireless monitoring and detection of postoperative OIRD and use AI to detect patterns that predict patient deterioration events in real-time. The conference will include a unique combination of industry partners and thought leaders from device technology and other stakeholders from healthcare information technology who will come together with clinician scientists and experts from data regulation to understand the challenges and opportunities from big data that comes out of wireless continuous ward monitoring. Participants will seek to build a consortium to advance science and improve patient safety in the context of a multi-pronged approach to OIRD prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Many neurological disorders involve abnormalities in cell physiology that unfold and progress over prolonged durations, ranging from days to years. Understanding these cellular processes in healthy and diseased states, as well as under pharmaceutical interventions, requires long-term readout of cell physiology in the living brain. The proposed work aims to develop novel technologies to enable such a long-term readout across living brains and to make these tools widely accessible to both basic and translational research communities.
