IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: AcademyHealth Annual Research Meeting Narrative AcademyHealth’s Annual Research Meeting (ARM) is the premier event for more than 3,000 health services researchers to disseminate their research and to enhance their careers by learning about new methods and networking with fellow researchers and users of their research. With 575 research presentations in sessions and 1,600 poster presentations, the ARM strives to synthesize, summarize, and communicate health services research findings to a broad range of individuals and organizations that have the capacity to use the information to improve health policy and clinical practice. The ARM’s objectives successfully complement and support AHRQ’s mission to improve the quality, safety, efficiency, and effectiveness of health care for all Americans.

PHR: PA-21-151 UCB PI: Seth M. Holmes PROJECT NARRATIVE The “Social Medicine Cases for Health Equity” conference is focused on reducing health disparities through rigorous interdisciplinary dialogue between the social sciences and medicine. It will consist of experts in clinical medicine and experts in the social sciences integrating the methods and theories of their disciplines in the analysis of case studies of real patients from minority - including immigrant - communities. Findings from this conference will be disseminated in the “Case Studies in Social Medicine,” which has already been accepted for publication in The Lancet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application requests partial support for the 13th International Copper Meeting: From Mechanisms to Therapy, which is focused on focused on genetic, molecular, and biochemical mechanisms underlying copper biology and chemistry in normal physiology and disease and proof-of-concept or clinically tractable means to translate these discoveries. Both basic/translational scientists and clinicians at this conference will be exposed to the emerging concepts in the copper field, including but not limited to advanced tools to study copper biology, structural biology of cuproproteins, copper at the host pathogen interface, intracellular and organismal copper trafficking and storage, and inherited diseases and somatic diseases associated with alterations in copper homeostasis. Together, participants will be encouraged to explore deeper mechanistic understanding of the links between copper homeostasis and human diseases with translational relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This application seeks funding to support Trainee-focused workshop and travel support for pre- and post-doctoral scholars to attend the upcoming 31st annual meeting of the American Society for Neural Therapy and Repair. This meeting will promote introductions and ongoing interaction between young and senior scientists in academia and industry, as well as clinical professionals, to jointly discover and develop new treatments for neurological disorders. This interactive approach between basic scientists and clinicians cultivates a safe and inclusive culture of translational learning, research and career development across all stages and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic kidney disease, the leading cause of kidney failure, results from high blood glucose damaging the blood vessels in the kidneys. This damage includes glycation of extracellular proteins, which results in accumulation of advanced glycation end products (AGEs), triggering vascular dysfunction, fibrosis, and loss of kidney function. Revel Pharmaceuticals is developing a novel class of therapeutics designed to enzymatically eliminate AGEs thus removing a significant driver of DKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Iowa Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention, in collaboration with premier scientists locally, nationally, and internationally, will expand our leadership role in investigating environmental exposures and gene variants for major birth defects. Our research will provide important insights into understanding the combined roles of exposures and variants in preventing or reducing adverse consequences of major birth defects. Findings will be shared with scientists, healthcare providers, policymakers, and families with the goal to develop appropriate prevention interventions and resources for families affected by major birth defects.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Iowa CBDRP Comp A: BD-STEPS Core

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to improve mining safety and health training in the western United States and support efforts to reduce mining injuries, illnesses and fatalities. Despite continued improvements over time, mining injuries and fatalities continue to occur in the mining industry, and reducing occupational illnesses remains challenging. Building on our past mine training grants, we will expand and enhance the Learning Laboratories program to be more responsive to the specific health and safety challenges that each operator faces and greatly improve collaboration through three-way partnerships with industry, academia, and government agencies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Western Mining Safety & Health Training Resource Center: Facilitating Research to Practice through Learning Laboratories

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Colorado School of Mines (CSM) Energy, Mining and Construction Industry Safety (EMCIS) program will provide a comprehensive approach intended to meet the safety and health training needs of the Western mining industry by providing a high quality, interactive training experience that targets mine workers and underserved audiences throughout the Western states, including safety and health professionals, mine management and supervision, contractors, consultants, suppliers, equipment manufacturers, and academia (faculty, staff and students). Through the training and educational activities offered by CSM, trainees will be exposed to critical concepts using best industry practices and adult learning techniques to facilitate the development and retention of fundamental skillsets essential to advancing safe and healthy work practices and the ability to identify and eliminate hazards. Future benefits of these efforts are to provide mine workers with the core values and knowledge necessary for positive, life-long improvements to the mining industry, as well as proactive practices and tools vital for reducing the risk associated with injuries and illnesses.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Enhanced Safety and Health Training for Western Mine Workers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative While birth defects are the number one cause of mortality, disability, and medical expenditures within the first year of life, their etiology is unknown in most affected individuals, and most research in the U.S. has focused on populations with relatively limited diversity (e.g., primarily non-Hispanic white subjects). To address this gap, the Texas Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention proposes to contribute our diverse population to BD-STEPs, as well as our team’s experience and resources as one of the largest birth defects registries in the world, and as national leaders in birth defects surveillance, research, and training of the next generation of birth defects epidemiologists. By growing our ongoing collaborations with our partners at the CDC and NBDPS/BD-STEPS Centers, we expect to identify modifiable genetic and non-genetic risk factors for birth defects with important implications for future prevention strategies designed to reduce risk for birth defects and improve health among affected individuals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Comp A: Texas BD-STEPS III Core

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Birth defects are the leading cause of infant mortality in the US. Birth defects also have enormous associated emotional and fiscal costs. With this new funding opportunity (BD-STEPS III), the California Center, both independently and in collaboration with other Centers, will conduct studies that will identify potential modifiable risk factors for selected birth defects to reduce the public health burden of birth defects in the US.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Comp A:  CALIFORNIA CENTER OF BD-STEPS III FINDING CAUSES AND PREVENTIVES OF BIRTH DEFECTS

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will build innovative models for evaluating multifaceted influenza interventions across the US and engage with the CDC Modeling Network to establish a culture of collaboration and diverse evidence base for influenza prevention and control. By elucidating immune-mediated competition between viruses and the population-level impacts of new antiviral regimens, our models will enable the optimization of targeted vaccine, antiviral and non-pharmaceutical interventions strategies. We will leverage our new visualization platform and longstanding collaborations with public health officials to translate modeling results into actionable insights for mitigating seasonal and pandemic influenza and for addressing socioeconomic and geographic disparities in influenza burden.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, Modeling toolkit to evaluate multifaceted control strategies for seasonal and pandemic influenza

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Birth defects are a leading cause of infant mortality and childhood disability, with the majority of birth defects having an unknown origin. Given that half of pregnant people report medication use, the prevalence of chronic conditions (such as obesity, diabetes, and hypertension) is increasing during pregnancy, the global spread of infectious diseases (such as COVID-19 and Zika virus), and the racial/ethnic and social disparities in the burden of birth defects, it is imperative to prioritize research on how these factors affect birth defect risk. The New York State Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention will do so by building on our experience with NBDPS and BD-STEPS, using innovative exposure assessment and analytic methods to better understand birth defect causes and inform prevention strategies that will reduce the public health burden of birth defects.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: New York State BD-STEPS: Component A and B

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: The objective of this proposal is to advance the science of modeling and contribute novel methods and data analytics tools that will increase the understanding of seasonal and pandemic influenza in the context of the network of modeling teams coordinated by the CDC. To address these challenges, we plan to develop a novel global modeling framework, contribute new data and methods for improve the accuracy and validation of flu modeling approaches, and evolve successful methodologies to advance the analysis of layered intervention with artificial Intelligence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-20-003, FluMod - Center for the Multiscale Modeling of Pandemic and seasonal Flu Prevention and Control

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This research will produce models of influenza that can be used by the public and policy makers to prepare for and prevent influenza outbreaks. By making the prediction of influenza as accurate and valuable as weather forecasting, we should be able to predict the impact of individual behaviors and public health interventions to prevent and treat seasonal influenza and reduce the potential harm of pandemic flu.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP20-003: Individual-based Simulation of Seasonal and Pandemic Influenza Epidemics - supplement Emergency Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Component A: BD-STEPS Core at the NC Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention Birth defects affect approximately three percent of all births yet account for 20 percent of infant deaths and contribute substantially to childhood morbidity and long-term disability. The North Carolina Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention (NCCBDRP) is a long-standing partnership between the Department of Epidemiology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the North Carolina Birth Defects Monitoring Program at the North Carolina Division of Public Health. The NCCBDRP will implement the multi-site, population-based Birth Defects Study To Evaluate Pregnancy exposureS (BD-STEPS) in a demographically diverse 33-county area of North Carolina to identify novel epidemiologic and genetic risk factors for major structural birth defects and to advance public health strategies for birth defects prevention.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Component A: BD-STEPS Core at the NC Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focuses on the continued participation of the Arkansas Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention in the multisite, population-based study, BD-STEPS, so that we can continue to recruit cases and controls for the study, identify modifiable maternal exposures in early pregnancy using pooled data in collaborative studies that may be amenable to early prevention, and train future generations of researchers. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the CDC's, Healthy People 2030 and other strategic priorities in Maternal, Infant, and Child Health focus area to reduce the rate of fetal (MICH- 01), infant (MICH-02) and child deaths (MICH-03) in the US.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Birth Defects Study to Evaluate Pregnancy exposureS (BD-STEPS) Core? Arkansas Center and Stillbirth

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because of the need for modeling tools to guide more effective, rapid responses to both influenza pandemics and seasonal influenza epidemics. We propose to integrate data and models from the individual to the population level using highly-detailed information from longitudinal cohort and clinical data. These models will evaluate vaccination, antiviral distribution, and non- pharmaceutical intervention strategies to be employed for pandemic mitigation at the population level. This research is relevant to the mission of the CDC Influenza Division in that it will inform efforts to guide vaccination and treatment policies and improve initiatives to prevent and treat influenza infection.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: IP20-003, Data driven transmission models to optimize influenza vaccination and pandemic mitigation strategies - COVID-19 Supplement

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
ORG_NAME: MASSACHUSETTS STATE DEPT OF PUB HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The activities and projects proposed in this application are designed to test or generate specific hypotheses of considerable etiologic importance, with the ultimate goal of informing clinical and public health prevention messages and interventions to reduce the occurrence of birth defects. The vast majority of pregnant women take medications, yet in regard to risks of birth defects, we know little about the safety of most of these medicines; given this critical knowledge gap, many of our proposed projects focus on detailed analyses of maternal illnesses and medications as risk factors for birth defects. We will employ novel approaches such as assessing medications by their mode of action and discerning if increased risks are due to the underlying infection, its treatment, or both.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Massachusetts Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention: Birth Defects Study To Evaluate Pregnancy exposureS (BD STEPS Core and Stillbirth)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Early onset osteoarthritis (OA) is a major concern after ACL reconstruction. This project will develop a predictive model of cartilage degeneration after ACL reconstruction using a novel combination of mechanical factors, biological factors, demographics, and clinical characteristics. This information is critical to developing new targets aimed at OA prevention after ACL reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pre-pregnancy obesity is associated with significant adverse health outcomes for the mother including increased risk of gestational diabetes and hypertension, preeclampsia and infection. Recent studies from our laboratory revealed significant changes in immune cell function in blood samples collected from obese women at week 37 of gestation. Since immune cells play a critical role in anti-microbial defense as well as the development of chronic inflammation, this application will carry out an in-depth investigation of maternal pre-pregnancy obesity- driven changes in the functional, transcriptional, and epigenetic landscape of blood immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Structure-function analyses of the gene therapy vector, Adeno-associated Virus (AAV) will lay a key foundation for the design of more efficient and specific vectors with improved safety profiles. Specifically, atomic-level analysis of AAV’s interactions with host cell receptors will provide a basis for modulating cell targeting, as treatments for wide-ranging disease predispositions are developed. Analysis of antibody interactions will provide a foundation for designing entry-viable immune-evading vectors, lowering therapeutic doses and a tangible risk of immuno-toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The activation of dioxygen by heme and nonheme metalloenzymes plays a critical role in many fundamental biological processes, including biosynthesis, detoxification, metabolic processes, and energy transfer, all of which directly or indirectly impact human health. The proposed studies focus on the synthesis and reactivity of small-molecule analogs of metalloenzyme active sites that process and manipulate various forms of oxygen. These efforts will provide fundamental knowledge relating to enzyme mechanisms which are implicated in a variety of diseases, including arthritis, cancer, genetic and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dioxins in Agent Orange (AO) and burn pits in the Middle East are associated with many types of cancer and other health problems. AO is the best studied wartime exposure in Veterans, and though AO is no longer used, it remains relevant as it persists in humans for decades. More recently, Veterans were exposed to chemicals in burn pits, which contain dioxins that may cause similar health problems. Our translational research aims to 1) use genetic and clinical data to predict the risk progression to lymphoma as well as 2) compare the clinical charts and biopsy tissues of Veterans who developed blood cancers with and without environmental exposures. We hope to determine if dioxin-induced differences in the regulation of cancer-promoting genes might be causing differences in the clinical course of exposed and unexposed Veterans. Our studies may identify actionable targets for treatment of dioxin-related lymphoid malignancies in future precision oncology clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of individuals are blind due to corneal opacity but their vision cannot be restored with a corneal transplant due to their body's rejection of transplanted tissue or because of the inability to obtain donor tissue. Previously we developed bioengineered corneal tissues that use a patient's own adult stem cells, so that barriers to restoring corneal vision due to shortage of donor tissue or rejection can be greatly reduced. The goal of this current work is to further improve the mechanical and optical properties of these tissues and to continue translation of this technology toward the clinic by validating restoration of vision using an in vivo model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to engineer cells to detect disease-associated molecular cues and respond with a therapeutic output could furnish transformative cell-based treatment solutions for a variety of currently irremediable diseases. However, because existing approaches for engineering signal transduction pathways do not incorporate phosphorylation, and therefore do not operate according to the same design principles as native signaling networks, it is challenging to engineer, fast, precise, multi-input sensing of disease-associated molecules. We propose to address this deficit by developing a signaling pathway engineering platform that allows researchers to construct cell-based devices with custom sense-and-respond programs capable of accurately perceiving diseased tissue environments and responding via secretion of therapeutic factors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Our laboratory has discovered that the protein endothelin-1, a secreted product of prostate cancer cells, stimulates bone formation once prostate cancer cells have metastasized to bone. Bone metastasis is a painful complication of advanced prostate cancer that afflicts the male Veteran population. Agent Orange exposure, common in Vietnam Veterans, doubles the risk for prostate cancer and increases the risk of prostate cancer bone metastasis at initial diagnosis. African-Americans, who make up a higher percentage of Veterans than the general population, are also at a substantially increased risk of prostate cancer. Veterans are more likely to have other serious coexisting conditions at diagnosis resulting in more treatment-related complications. This proposal is aimed at understanding mechanisms of prostate cancer bone metastasis in order to develop superior and novel therapies aimed at reducing the pain and morbidity of advanced prostate cancer in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is directly relevant to the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities’ mission to improve health equity by reducing the burden of tobacco use, tobacco exposure, and chronic disease among racially/ethnically diverse populations living in federally subsidized housing. We will conduct a wait-list cluster randomized controlled trial of our adapted smoke-free home intervention among racially/ethnically- and linguistically-diverse populations residing in federally subsidized housing, and leverage housing staff as lay health workers to support cessation behaviors among residents. This proposal has the potential to inform development of evidence-based strategies to increase implementation of smoke-free policies and smoking cessation services that can be brought to scale in federally subsidized housing in order to reduce tobacco- related health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our microbiomes, or the collections of trillions of micro-organisms that live on and within us, play important roles in our health, and when disrupted, have been implicated in human diseases including infections, allergies, cancers, diabetes, liver, kidney, heart, and neurological disorders. Recently, new technologies are enabling exploration of our microbiomes in unprecedented detail, and exciting advances have been made in developing therapies that alter the microbiome with the objective of treating diseases. I propose to build new computational tools to analyze rich microbiome datasets as well as carry out integrated biological experiments, with the goals of both providing freely available tools to the research community for increasing fundamental knowledge of how our microbiomes affect us, and for purposes of accelerating development of therapies that target the microbiome for treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: The science proposed here takes advantage of the unique scientific opportunity created by the coronavirus pandemic, to study the interaction between a definable and time-limited risk-inducing environmental event (exposure to the virus) and genomic variation, on the occurrence of cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) in large cohorts of older adults from underrepresented minorities in the USA and ancestral groups in Africa and South America. The leading investigators have extensive experience directing international consortia and longitudinal cohorts. We have pilot ascertainment of cognitive impairment end-points in newly recruited older adults of Amerindian ancestry. We will investigate interactions between whole-genome sequence variations and COVID-19 on the risk of cognitive decline in 4,300 individuals recruited in Texas, New York, Washington State, Ibadan (Nigeria), and Jujuy (Argentina). Participant assessments will include neurological, cognitive, imaging and blood-based biomarker evaluations using harmonized protocols and at 3 time points. Three highly integrated Projects will be supported by 4 equally integrated Cores. All projects involve integrated multidisciplinary teams within a consortium of institutions in the US, Nigeria and Argentina. Resources and study expertise will be tightly coordinated across multiple sites and Cores, and integrated to the National Institute of Aging Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project and National Alzheimer’s Coordinating Center which will help ensure optimal sharing of the acquire data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Treatment of large, third degree burns presents a number of challenges including the low availability of remaining healthy skin for grafting, delayed wound closure and extended hospital stays. Although rapid closure is associated with lower mortality and less scarring, available treatments require extensive manufacturing times, delaying closure. This project seeks to improve outcomes for burn patients by developing technologies to facilitate regeneration of full-thickness skin on the patient’s body without culture, leading to rapid wound closure and reduced scarring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) have been recognized as an important cause of clinical dementia. The goal of the MarkVCID consortium, of which the University of Southern California is a participating site, is to be perform rigorous validation of imaging and fluid-based biomarkers for small vessel VCID to be ready for large scale clinical trials to evaluate novel interventions of VCID.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Drug-drug interactions (DDIs) involving oral anticoagulants can lead to serious harm. To reduce harm from these dangerous combinations, creative solutions are needed that both increase the involvement of patients and harness the power of interoperable electronic health records. The purpose of this project is to disseminate a novel approach for DDIs that enhances shared decision making by providing a visual display of the potential for harm from anticoagulants and other medications, taking into account a patient’s unique attributes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementation of DDInteract: A Shared-decision Making Tool for Anticoagulant Drug-Drug INTERACTions

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Equipping parents with skills-based strategies to protect children will fill a large gap in primary child sexual abuse (CSA) prevention efforts. Smart Parents – Safe and Healthy Kids (Smart Parents) is a parent-focused, CSA-specific, skills-based module that can be added in a single session to evidence-based parent education (PE) programs used by state-supported parent service agencies across the U.S., including Parents as Teachers. Moreover, by leveraging existing PE implementation infrastructures well-supported by federal funds (i.e., Family First Prevention Services Act), the sustainability and scalability of Smart Parents is greatly enhanced, thereby maximizing the potential for public health impact and a move toward the reduction of rates of CSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because electrostatic field effects and multinuclear active sites are thought to be critical to the ways in which metalloenzymes function. An improved understanding of these factors is expected to lead to new classes of drug inhibitors, insight into the genetic origin of diseases, and new biotechnological catalysts. Thus, the research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission pertaining to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to elucidate the mechanisms by which enzymes function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Once diagnosed with lung cancer, a patient typically undergoes diagnostic bronchoscopy and/or therapeutic surgery. These procedures carry a 40% failure rate due to missed tumors, positive margins, un-identified lymph nodes, and synchronous cancers. Our Project will address this problem using near- infrared optical imaging technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant application develops new and innovative technologies for applications in lung cancer bronchoscopy and surgery. The main goal is to aid the clinician in delineating tumor margins, identifying diseased lymph nodes and micrometastases, and determining if the tumor has been completely resected. A cocktail of innovative targeted optical contrast agents for lung cancer is expected to generate a major impact in the diagnosis and treatment of this disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This grant application develops a combination of four optical contrast agents that can be used to visually image lung cancer cells during lung cancer procedures. All prior attempts at intraoperative imaging of lung cancer have been limited to imaging a single target. This proposal will broaden this approach by creating a library of tracers that can be utilized to visualize a host of targets on lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The rapid pace of discovery about breast cancer biology has given rise to survival gains and new precision screening and treatment approaches. The overarching goal of our application is to use collaborative computer modeling to inform translation of precision oncology evidence to clinical guidelines and policy by evaluating strategies to further decrease mortality, understand survivor quality of life, and reduce disparities. We will use six breast cancer simulation models as a virtual laboratory to inform policy and clinical decisions by evaluating the impacts on mortality, quality of life, harms, and costs of disseminating these evolving precision cancer control paradigms.

PHR: Bridges to Baccalaureate students would be recruited and provided educational readiness by Prison to Professionals while still incarcerated, transition to a 2-year associates granting school (Baltimore City Community College, BCCC), be provided skills and methods development during their 2-years at BCCC, participate in a 10-week STEM research internship at Howard (HU) University, then transition to a 4-year Bachelors granting school, HU. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposed program is to develop an end-user informed HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) technology as an Acceptable Multi-user Biodegradable Extended Release (AMBER) implant. The AMBER implant offers the following beneficial features for delivery of novel PrEP agents: user independence, long-term protection (≤1 year), and discretion of use, biodegradation, and retrievability, if needed, for the duration of drug delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Imaging Core (Core B) provides state-of-the-art imaging facilities to the Projects in this application. Our focus is on the development and implementation of imaging protocols for fluorescence imaging of tumors in situ, calibration and testing of new imaging systems, and the development of back table imaging protocols to aid in the detection of tumor margins, micrometastases and cancerous lymph nodes. Core B also supports both large animal (canine) and small animal (mouse) imaging to facilitate translation of the cocktail of imaging agents into surgical applications in patients with pulmonary cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastasis is the major cause of mortality in human breast cancer. The mechanisms that allow tumor cells to move from the blood into the tissue at a distal site, survive and grow are of intense scientific and clinical interest. This Program Project will use novel methodologies to explore exciting new hypotheses about tumor cell behavior during the late steps of metastasis, and will have important implications for the clinical treatment of metastatic disease in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor metastasis is the major cause of mortality in human breast cancer, and understanding the biological mechanisms of metastasis is crucial for improving cancer treatment. The Class I PI 3-kinase, PI3Kβ, is a signaling protein and plays critical role in tumor cell invasion, and in the stromal cells that support tumor cell invasion. Existing clinical trials with PI3Kβ inhibitors have focused on the inhibition tumor growth. However, studies defining the mechanisms by which PI3Kβ mediates tumor invasion may refocus future trials on the treatment of patients with metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (Project 2) Metastasis is the main cause of cancer death. While we have significant understanding of biological events occurring in the primary tumor and at the early steps of metastasis, much less is known about how late steps of metastasis at distant organs are regulated. The proposed work will study how key stem cell factors promote these late steps of metastasis. Our findings will help develop strategies for preventing and/or treating metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Mid-Career Investigator Award aims to develop a formal mentoring program, expand high-quality patient- oriented research on frailty and outcomes of medical and surgical interventions, and cultivate Dr. Kim's capacity as a mentor and leader in aging research. This is relevant to public health because the growth of well-trained clinician investigators and new evidence will accelerate adoption of frailty in clinical decision-making for medically complex older adults. Thus, it accomplishes the National Institute on Aging's missions and initiatives by promoting personalized care to improve the health status of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic disease, the most common cause of breast cancer-related mortality, is mediated by cancer cells capable of disseminating and colonizing distant organs. We will determine the signaling events required for emergence of disseminating cancer cell phenotype (invasive and stem) during cancer cell extravasation. We will also determine if stem program is required for re-dissemination of these cancer cells from metastatic foci, a process that may perpetuate metastases even after the removal of the primary tumor. Since most patients with metastases are treated with chemotherapy, we will determine the effect of chemotherapy on these two processes. To capture the true biology of the tumor microenvironment we will employ novel technologies for in vivo imaging of large volumes of tissue along with our novel biosensors in the lungs, with single cell resolution, and over many days. The findings will enable us to identify molecular targets for future therapies that could be combined with chemotherapy to improve outcomes for patients with metastatic disease which is responsible for 90 percent of cancer related mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The reason why some develop granulomatous diseases, such as the scarring lung disease sarcoidosis, while others do not, and why some develop more severe forms of this disease and in others disease resolves, is not well understood. This proposal will define factors that may explain why some people get sarcoidosis, while also defining new proteins, genes, biomarkers and potential mechanisms important in the development of this and other similar diseases, as well as helping us understand their disease course. In future studies, these factors may be tested clinically as diagnostic tests or predictors of disease and ultimately even targets for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The Yale Cancer Prevention and Control (CPC) Training Program aims to educate, train and mentor pre- and post-doctoral fellows in five thematic areas critical to CPC: cancer etiology, cancer outcomes, lifestyle behavioral interventions, implementation science and community-engaged research. These five areas were selected because they are critical domains in the spectrum of CPC research, they leverage strengths of our faculty, and they will ensure that T32 trainees with diverse interests will achieve pivotal growth through the program and become leaders in novel, impactful CPC research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Protein folding is a key step in the expression of the genetic information; thus, failure to fold correctly leads to misfolding and aggregation associated with many pathological states. The long term goal of this Research Program is to understand how newly translated proteins fold in eukaryotic cells and elucidate how chaperones mediate the folding of newly synthesized proteins. Our proposed experiments are aimed at obtaining functional, mechanistic and structural insights into the role of chaperones in de novo folding through the close integration of in vitro and in vivo approaches with computational biology analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The Advanced Imaging Core provides, in eight core services, the staffing, expertise, equipment, and interpretive skills needed to evaluate and test mechanisms of metastasis at the secondary site of the lung. The Core centralizes unique equipment, and the knowledgebase for its proper validated utilization, in a way that grants prioritized access to the members of this Program Project Group and ensures the rigor and reproducibility of all of the experiments. Without the services provided by Core A, our understanding of these processes would be derived from model systems and/or end-stage assays that only approximate the physiology of lung metastasis. In contrast, our approach is uniquely able to provide the information about mechanism of in vivo behavior at the single cell level.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Language performance of children with cochlear implants (CI) lags behind that of normal-hearing children, and is highly variable. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Monitoring an individual's eating behavior will provide detailed understanding of the causal relationship between the eating activity and conditions such as problematic eating and obesity. Manual self-reports are often erroneous and biased. The availability of wearable video cameras makes it possible to objectively capture the eating activity. However, manually observing video frames to obtain the objective measure of eating is burdensome. Additionally, wearable video cameras pose privacy concerns in real-world settings. To overcome these challenges, we are developing an automated eating detection system to monitor real-time eating behavior via a privacy-conscious wearable device that individuals will wear. We will confirm eating activities in real time. Such automatic and privacy-conscious real-time eating detection will allow us to advance our understanding of the eating activity, laying the foundation for future interventions to change problematic eating behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bisphenol exposure in human populations is nearly universal and there is evidence that prenatal exposure to bisphenols is linked to negative neurodevelopment and behavior outcomes in children that continue throughout life. The proposed research will examine the biological mechanisms underlying the long-term effects of prenatal bisphenol exposure, including estrogen receptor signaling and DNA methylation changes, in the developing brain in rat models. Findings from this research project could help propose more targeted and effective interventions for children with prenatal bisphenol exposure to reduce risk of disease and promote healthier outcomes later in life.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: ASSOCIATION OF FOOD AND DRUG OFFICIALS
PHR: AFDO Application for RFA-FD-22-008 - Retail Food Safety Regulatory Association Collaboration PROJECT NARRATIVE The Association of Food and Drug Officials proposes to build on the foundational work started in the original cooperative agreement and to collaboratively work with the other associations awarded in this new cooperative agreement to further advance retail food initiatives to improve retail food safety, identify opportunities to reduce the occurrence of foodborne illness risk factors, and improve foodborne outbreak investigation. The highlights of our plans for this cooperative agreement are outlined here but described in detail in the Research Strategy. AFDO will conduct another series of state retail food safety interviews and will include specific questions about key criteria for risk-based inspections and how they have been implemented within each state. We will use the information gathered to develop some key measurements and comparability among the states. We will add data to the Data Analytics project including data from additional jurisdictions and years of data, completing further analysis. Focus will be on analysis of key areas related to foodborne illness risk factors and the frequency of “not observed” in these areas. Further, we anticipate comparing the inspection results with the frequency of foodborne illness risk factor violations and type of certified food protection manager training required by the state. The state surveys will also include questions about barriers to Food Code adoptions and what tools could be helpful for state programs to complete adoptions of more recent Food Codes including key provisions. We will create a webinar on completing regulatory adoptions, which was cited as one of the key barriers to Food Code adoption. We will also maintain the interactive maps developed during the initial cooperative agreement, including changes to contact information. AFDO will continue identify and to promote food borne illness outbreak investigation tools and best practices for posting on the Collaborative website. In the area of Active Managerial Control, AFDO will put on a series of train-the-trainer courses developed under the initial cooperative agreement for corporations, develop and disseminate guidance documents, infographics, and best practices through data from an industry survey, and create a training resource for smaller/regional food industry operators. We will continue to deliver the Root Cause Analysis course developed under the first cooperative agreement to lead food safety regulators and industry professionals and continue offering Environmental Sampling courses which were determined as a need from CDC After Action Reviews. AFDO pledges to share all information received and tools developed with the other associations in the Collaborative.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Retail Food Safety Regulatory Association Collaboration

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Antimicrobial use is the major driver of the emergence of antimicrobial-resistant infections, a significant threat to human and companion animal health. Measurement of antimicrobials is critical to improve antimicrobial use for dogs and cats, however, efforts to collect this data are hampered by the nature of diverse pet health records and lack of resources and technical expertise in veterinary practices. This project will overcome barriers to tracking antimicrobial use by 1) utilizing a low-tech point prevalence survey approach to gather a snapshot of antimicrobial use in veterinary facilities across the country, and 2) establishing an electronic surveillance system for antimicrobial use that incorporates collection of uniform data across varied electronic health record platforms without the need for information technology expertise in participating practices.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Representative, scalable, and sustainable surveillance methodologies to track companion animal antimicrobial use

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative State and territorial health agencies, along with other governmental agencies, help regulate food preparation, sale, and distribution, in addition to being primary responders to outbreaks of foodborne illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that 48 million people get sick, 128,000 are hospitalized, and 3,000 die from foodborne diseases each year in the United States. This demonstrates a serious strain on the food safety system and has led the public health community, including the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), to launch a Retail Food Safety Initiative to help achieve a better coordinated prevention-oriented food safety infrastructure. Through the activities in this proposal, ASTHO will further align its goals to that of FDA’s Retail Food Safety Initiative and work collaboratively with the Retail Food Regulatory Association Collaborative and help facilitate long-term improvements to the national food safety system.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening Retail Food Regulatory Programs and Reducing Foodborne Illnesses through National Partnerships

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Project Narrative: While acute kidney injury remains a major driver of morbidity and mortality in the perioperative period, the ability to accurately identify patients at risk for this complication remains limited despite decades of clinical research. The role of genetic information in predicting acute kidney injury remains largely unknown and requires large scale electronic health records and genomic datasets. We hypothesize that integrating patient data generated in the perioperative period into the most advanced predictive genomic algorithms, will enable a novel and personal risk assessment for postoperative acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The COVID-19 pandemic forced explosive growth of telehealth—synchronous virtual visits between patients and clinicians—under crisis conditions, but it is now essential to generate robust evidence regarding when telehealth’s benefits outweigh its risks in oncology practice; how to ensure that telehealth provides highly effective, efficient, and equitable care; and how to identify best practices for telehealth implementation. The MATCHES (Making Telehealth Delivery of Cancer Care at Home Effective and Safe) Telehealth Research Center will bring together investigators and trainees from multiple disciplines to meet these challenges by 1) conducting pragmatic and pilot trials across our integrated network of outpatient oncology practices; 2) leveraging our substantial cache of observational data to build the evidence base necessary to establish best practices for telehealth-supported cancer care; and 3) to investigate concerns about safety and addressing the risk of exacerbating disparities in access to high quality healthcare. Our Center’s theme focuses on developing data science methods to integrate telehealth data with other complex data streams to measure outcomes and quality of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This program aims to train graduate students on the path to obtaining their PhDs to become translational research scientists and engineers who can integrate human biology and engineered systems to investigate and develop new technologies, diagnostics, and experimental therapeutics in patients and model disease systems. This competing renewal of our pre-doctoral training program in translational regenerative medicine remains a logical extension of the ongoing collaborative multidisciplinary research of the institute's outstanding faculty. WFIRM's unique infrastructure provides pre-doctoral trainees' access to RM experts and state-of-the- art facilities, allowing these trainees to be properly educated in the multidisciplinary field of RM, from basic science to translational applications, including the development of Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The Pacific Island Partnership for Cancer Health Equity (PIPCHE) represents the next step in augmenting a Hawai‘i-Guam-USAPI cancer research infrastructure by investing in Pacific Island Populations leaders, Early Stage Investigators, community partners, and community-informed disparities research. As a result of the 17- year commitment, PIPCHE is also well positioned to increase the diversity of the biomedical cancer science workforce and research leadership that better reflects the Hawai‘i-Guam-USAPI larger racial/ethnic representation and to stimulate new areas of disparities and translational research. PIPCHE has assembled dedicated academic and community partnerships needed to synergistically accelerate disparities research into a sustainable forum that pursues cultural and environmental appropriate solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms by which the gastrointestinal microbiota influences host immunity remain poorly characterized. The intestinal epithelial cells integrate information from the microbiota, and relay these signals to the downstream immune system, therefore playing a key role as intermediaries in the effect of the microbiota on the entire body. In this project, we propose to study how the microbiota regulates intestinal epithelial cell death and how this can influence disease susceptibility and infectious disease outcomes with the goal of furthering our understanding of epithelial cell function, which will aid the design of new therapies to restore host immune function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a case-control study of 300 liver fibrosis cases and 300 matched controls among Chamorros in Guam. Liver fibrosis, a well-established precursor of liver cancer, as well as liver steatosis as a secondary outcome, will be measured by transient elastrography (Fibroscan). We hypothesize that oral dysbiosis and sleep/circadian rhythm disturbance contribute to liver fibrosis through glucose and lipid dysmetabolism and the potential modifying effect of other exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative The neonatal thymus microenvironment consists of multiple stromal cell types which are critical for the development of T cells that protect newborns from infectious diseases and autoimmunity. The cellular and molecular differences between neonatal and adult thymic stromal cells and the mechanisms regulating the transition from neonatal thymus growth to adult homeostasis are not understood. This program project will use single cell RNA sequencing, advanced imaging and other cutting edge approaches to identify cellular and molecular changes in stromal cell subsets in the mouse and human thymus during the neonatal to adult transition, determine the molecular pathways that regulate these changes and evaluate the ensuing effects on T cell function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long term potentiation (LTP) is an important mediator of memory consolidation in the hippocampus. Understanding the differential roles that dopamine and norepinephrine contribute to LTP is of fundamental importance to understanding memory circuitry and its modulation. The results from this study will provide unprecedented insight into physiological memory consolidation, and potential implications for neuromodulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pacific Islanders are one the fastest growing ethnic groups in the US, found in every state. The work of the Pacific Island Partnership for Cancer Health Equity’s (PIPCHE) Community Outreach Core (COC) directly addresses the disproportionately high rates of cancer incidence and mortality found among Pacific Island Populations (PIP) in Hawai‘i and Guam. Using community-engaged approaches, the Community Outreach Core will work to support, enhance, and disseminate the PIPCHE’s research to better understand the determinants of cancer in this group. The COC’s activities will also serve to reduce the burden of preventable cancers found in PIP living in Hawai‘i and Guam, which may be applicable to groups found elsewhere in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Surgical skill develops over the entire duration of a surgeon’s career, and well beyond their supervised training period. Currently, no methods for objective assessment of skill performance exist to identify and accelerate improvement in skill and, in turn, improve patient outcomes. This project develops a novel usable video-based personalized surgical learning platform, automated using artificial intelligence methods, for surgeons to effectively improve their skill.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer biology research within this institutional, multidisciplinary training program is aimed at elucidating the molecular mechanisms responsible for initiation and progression of human cancer. Translational research is also directed at improving diagnosis and therapies for this terrible disease, and our training faculty have made discoveries that have led to new cancer therapies. Both pre- and postdoctoral trainees participate in rigorous didactic as well as state-of-the-art laboratory and/or computational research training with the earliest cadre having now established academic careers in cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The long-term goals of this project are to develop a patient-specific 3D cardiovascular tissue model and autonomous-flow (self-driven) microfluidic culture platform to assess the effects of pharmaceutical drug exposure on human myocardium in vitro and conduct fundamental studies of real-time cardiomyocyte-endothelial cell-extracellular matrix interaction for cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, and atherosclerosis. The central hypothesis is that combining 3D cardiovascular tissue derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells with an autonomous-flow microfluidic device will create a patient-specific, physiologically relevant model that facilitates in vitro study of functional human myocardium. The primary impact of this work is the development of a targeted, single source cardiovascular tissue model that is more representative of the general population and will increase the efficiency of effective drug discovery by reflecting human response to the therapeutic while reducing the use of costly animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pilot Project 2: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer survival is highest among Asian Americans relative to other races, but it is not the same across all Asian subethnic groups. Given the importance of the Asian American population’s heterogeneity when studying cancer, our pilot project will examine tumor characteristics and treatment care by Asian subethnic group to clarify ovarian cancer’s ethnic-specific survival disparities. The findings of this work will shed light on the underlying factors driving the ethnic-specific differences observed to inform strategies for addressing this highly fatal disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: ERPS Project Narrative Abstract The Bureau anticipates participation in this cooperative agreement will result in significant enhancement in the quality of inspections and inspectors egg and bio-security knowledge for Iowa's egg handling facilities. This will be obtained by achieving and sustaining full conformance with the Egg Regulatory Program Standards (ERPS), engaging in the annual face-to face meeting (if applicable) and participation in committees supporting ERPS, and working with FDA to establish the foundation for pursuing regulatory action based upon the findings of state inspections at state egg handler facilities. We intend to attain full conformance with the ERPS within 3 years and to put into place the tools necessary to allow continuous improvement and to ensure continued compliance once the funding is discontinued.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelin is essential for rapid nerve signaling and its loss in diseases like multiple sclerosis or after injury causes severe disability in patients. We propose to harness innovative tools and methods we developed to increase our fundamental understanding of how myelin forms normally during vertebrate central nervous system development, using both in vivo and primary cell culture approaches. These studies will contribute knowledge toward our ultimate goal of promoting remyelination in patients to reduce the burden of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The DiPersio Unit strives to optimize immunotherapy, including allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (alloHSCT), for treating hematological malignancies. Dr. DiPersio’s research program over the next several years will use our strengths in preclinical modeling, cancer genomics and the design and execution of early phase clinical trials to (1) develop novel methods for hematopoietic stem cell mobilization and treatment of graft-versus-host disease; (2) define the genetic and epigenetic changes that contribute to AML relapse after alloHSCT; and (3) perform clinical trials testing bispecific antibody or chimeric antigen receptor T cell (CART) therapies to treat hematological malignancies before or after HSCT. I serve as a laboratory-based scientist to accomplish the goals of Dr. DiPersio’s cancer research program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Viral pneumonia progressing to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) represents a significant public health concern given the constant threat of emerging, highly pathogenic respiratory viruses (SARS-CoV-2 / COVID-19) as well as increased vulnerability of elderly and immunocompromised individuals with even mild seasonal influenza strains. The purpose of this proposal is to identify the molecular mechanisms required to achieve effective regeneration of the capillary endothelium, and how signals from the regenerating endothelial cells themselves promote alveolar epithelial repair. Ultimately these studies will facilitate more targeted therapies / approaches to lung vascular repair to reduce mortality and promote recovery from ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Displaced populations experience an elevated burden of mental disorder alongside very limited access to mental health services. As forced displacement continues to rise to unprecedented levels (over 84 million people in 2021), innovative strategies to improve reach and retention in mental health services for hard-to- reach displaced populations, such as migrants in transit, are needed to reduce the global burden of mental disorders. By leveraging participatory methods in implementation science, human-centered design, and systems science, this research aims to discover novel approaches to improving access to care for migrants in transit, which will facilitate innovations that may be translated to improving mental health service delivery in other settings and hard-to-reach populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Release of histones by affected organs and tissues during trauma or severe inflammation leads to profound microvascular endothelial damage and organ failure, but cellular mechanisms of endothelial dysfunction induced by circulating histones remain poorly understood. This project investigates new receptors by which extracellular histones target lung microvascular endothelium and cause sustained endothelial dysfunction. Identification of new pathways of microvascular endothelial cell death caused by extracellular histones may lead to development of new inhibitory compounds targeting histone-activated cell receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis and its cardiovascular consequences are the number one killer of both men and women in the United States, placing a considerable burden on US health care delivery and its costs. The mechanisms leading to accumulation of lipids in arteries are unclear. This project aims to open an entirely new field of inquiry by investigating the mechanisms of monocyte lipid uptake and will identify previously unknown therapeutic targets to inhibit atherosclerosis promoting lipid entry into the arterial wall.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 4B3 is a devastating complex axonal neuropathy which onsets very early in life and features neurodevelopmental delay, central nervous system involvement and musculoskeletal defects. The gene responsible for CMT4B3 is Sbf1, which encodes Myotubularin- Related Protein 5, a hypothesized regulator of endo-lysosomal trafficking and autophagy in neurons, two processes that are critical in early development. This project will therefore examine the specific molecular mechanisms of axon degeneration in Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Type 4B3 due to mutations in MTMR5 and will seek to identify robust cellular phenotypes that can be used for identification of therapeutic targets and genetic therapy validation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Urination is critical for waste removal, but also causes a huge pathological burden for many people who struggle with lower urinary tract problems. The lower urinary tract depends on mechanical signals from the urothelium and the nervous system to function properly, but the mechanisms by which mammals detect these mechanical cues, like bladder stretch, are not well defined. I seek to understand how mechanosensing functions in the urinary tract at the molecular, cellular and physiological level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We will use MRI to measure brain blood flow and energy demand in infants with and without brain injury to determine whether anesthesia compromises their ability to meet their energy demand. We will identify changes in brain blood flow and energy demand that increase the risk of adverse cogitative outcomes in infants exposed to anesthesia. We will also compare two popular anesthetic agents to determine which one best protects infants against changes in blood flow and energy demand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative To successfully navigate its environment, an animal must be able to perceive both the orientation of its body in space and how its body moves through space; this perception requires integrating vestibular, somatosensory, and visual input in a contextually relevant manner. The proposed research will investigate how the parieto-insular vestibular cortex (PIVC) of non-human primates performs this multisensory integration and facilitates higher- order vestibular functions such as the perception of self-motion. This research will vastly improve our basic understanding of vestibular cortical function; in turn, this research will provide clinically relevant insight to physicians treating human patients who are experiencing dysfunctions related to vestibular cortical injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Insulin is an essential and effective therapeutic for the treatment of diabetes. Nevertheless, there remain serious limitations with currently available therapeutic insulins, including relatively slow biological activity following subcutaneous injection, instability, and co-stimulation of biological pathways that promote tumor growth. This proposal seeks to gain mechanistic insights that will inform efforts to develop improved therapeutics that overcome these limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Hemostasis and blood clot formation is thought to be driven primarily by coagulation factors, platelets, and fibrinogen and intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) treatment paradigms focus on optimizing these components to minimize ongoing bleeding. However, outside of their known role of oxygen delivery, there is evidence that erythrocytes, otherwise known as red blood cells (RBCs), also play a role in hemostasis and blood clot formation. This project will explore the independent contribution of RBCs on both hemostasis and cerebral oxygenation after ICH in efforts to identify novel treatment targets to improve ICH outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal substance use can have lasting consequences on child development; however, the vast majority of research in this area has focused exclusively on how prenatal substance use can impact child neurocognitive outcomes. The proposed study will be one of the first to examine how prenatal and continued household exposure to maternal substance use may affect child neurocognitive development in early adolescence, recognizing that maternal substance use does not happen in isolation and the role of other psychological risk factors will be addressed. Findings will be critical to informing our understanding of how prior and continued maternal substance use, alongside psychological risk factors, affect child neurocognitive development and will inform intervention and treatment programs for families in the context of maternal substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-academic partnerships are commonly formed to address environmental health concerns in environmental justice communities. Increasingly, these teams attempt to use low-cost air sensors to understand air pollution exposures, but the appropriate use of these devices requires specific training. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite notable advances in our understanding of hazardous compounds over the past century, there are many compounds or hazards for which there is little or no regulatory guidance. As industrial hygienists and those in related fields must often make immediate decisions regarding how to assess and manage these hazards on a daily basis, it is imperative that they have access to the most current information available regarding management of these hazards. In this project we will provide this information for prospective graduate students, graduate students, and career professionals via development of online courses, online laboratories, and in- person research training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Consequences from heavy alcohol use build through mid-adulthood yet the factors that predict chronic alcohol problems in this age range are under-studied and therefore not well understood. The proposed research will leverage data spanning development from adolescence through mid-adulthood to test hypotheses about how risk for negative alcohol outcomes may change over time and differentially for adults with and without childhood ADHD -- a frequently diagnosed psychiatric illness that carries risk for alcohol problems and alcohol use disorder in adulthood. Identification of the dynamic and transactional processes that may underlie risk for alcohol problems for adults without and without a history of ADHD will aide in the development of personalized treatment targets to ultimately decrease alcohol use problems in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The choroid plexuses (ChP) provide a critical blood-CSF barrier whose breakdown is implicated in several neurological and psychiatric disorders. The goal of this study is to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which GPCR-cAMP signaling regulate permeability of the blood-CSF barrier. Successful completion of this project will provide a roadmap for the molecular mechanisms regulating ChP barrier integrity, targets which can be exploited to improve therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory input interacts with hard-wired genetic programs to change the way brain cells in the central nervous system wire together through synapses, however, a comprehensive and principled understanding of neural circuit plasticity is not yet available because current experimental technologies only offer small glimpses of this complex process. It is also unclear to what degree molecular changes within diverse brain cell types precede or follow changes in synaptic connectivity. Here, I utilize cutting-edge methods in single-cell genomics and viral barcoding to systematically map how auditory input changes gene expression and local synaptic connectivity relationships within the primary auditory cortex of mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative:  Environmental contexts and associated drug cues can elicit craving, and subsequent drug-seeking behaviors after prolonged abstinence periods may contribute to the recurrent chronic relapsing nature of alcohol addiction (O’Brien et al. 1992, O’Brien et al. 1998). There is a critical need for therapeutic treatments for alcohol-seeking behaviors. This project's long-range goals will help to understand mechanisms that underlie 5-HT7 receptors' ability to suppress (agonist) or potentiate (antagonist) conditioned cue expression of alcohol-seeking and would contribute to establishing 5-HT7 agonists are viable pharmacotherapeutics to reduce alcohol craving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Recent advances in dynamical systems theory suggests that the best way to understand the mechanism of neural computation may not lie at the level of individual neurons, but instead through the dynamics of neural populations. To leverage this new perspective, we need tools that can model the dynamics of neural circuits, but the best models currently available have significant limitations that make their dynamical estimates inaccurate, and therefore poorly suited to give interpretable insight into neural computation. I propose a novel neural network architecture that could solve this problem, allowing computational models to learn accurate dynamics from neural data arising from single or multiple interacting neural circuits and helping us infer how neural computations are built by populations of neurons in the brain.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: We propose to develop an integrated toolbox to provide the necessary scientific, technological, and regulatory contextual understanding for a continuous production of monoclonal antibodies, via an experimentally validated process model. Such an approach will enable both industry and the FDA to make more science- and risk-based decisions with respect to continuous bioprocessing. We will work closely with our network of industrial partners and with NIIMBL, vendors, and the FDA to maximize overall success.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing continuous biomanufacturing of monoclonal antibodies using an experimentally validated modeling platform

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative “Modeling the disease burden and cost-effectiveness of screening and treatment for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in type 2 diabetes patients” will provide a better understanding of an under-recognized yet common comorbidity of patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) in the US. As part of this project, we will develop and validate a computer-based model that can be used to estimate and project the burden of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in T2D patients. We will then apply the model to identify the most cost-effective medications and the optimal screening strategy for NAFLD, in order to improve the medical care and quality of life for millions of patients suffering from diabetes and NAFLD.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Modeling the Disease Burden and Cost-Effectiveness of Screening and Treatment for Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease in Type 2 Diabetes Patients

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal immune tolerance is essential for fetal development, but the regulatory mechanisms underlying fetal immune cell development remain largely undefined. Built upon our recent novel discovery of the maternal MDSC-IFNγ axis at the maternal-fetal interface orchestrated by the gut microbiome, we propose a multidisciplinary approach to interrogate how the gut microbome modulates fetal immune regulation via regulation of the MDSC-IFNγ axis. The findings from our studies will provide the framework for future studies of targeted manipulation of the gut microbiome to modulate these immune pathways to promote fetal immune cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Respiratory viral infections are a leading source of infectious complications in children undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation and solid organ transplantation. The current diagnostic methods do not distinguish true disease or predict patients at risk for progression to severe disease. We will use a multi-faceted approach focusing on the virus and the host response to define biomarkers that risk stratify patients and generate evidence- based pediatric guidelines for personalized management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this R01 study is to conduct a comprehensive and state-of-the-art meta-analysis of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Relapse Prevention, and other Cognitive-Behavioral Intervention (CBIs) efficacy, moderated efficacy, and mediating processes when delivered to populations with alcohol or other drug use disorders. The project will incorporate a range of methodological advancements in meta-analysis and will inform clinical and methodological recommendations on: 1) CBI implementation and delivery, 2) optimal endpoints for measuring CBI effect, and 3) defining and understanding recovery in the context of evidence-based treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although approximately 130 million babies are born every year worldwide, we have limited understanding of how normal term labor progresses. This project will use a recently developed technology (Electromyometrial Imaging, EMMI) to build the first-ever "normal term atlas" describing the detailed electrophysiology of uterine contractions during normal term labor. In the long term, EMMI holds great potential to monitor labor and test the effectiveness of strategies to reduce labor complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cell transplantation is a promising treatment option to replace nonfunctioning hormone secreting organs like endocrine pancreas. We propose a prevascularized encapsulation platform with local sustained immunosuppression to protect transplanted islet from immune rejection, avoiding adverse effects of systemic immunosuppression regimens, while providing an environment conducive for successful engraftment. This system has potential for a breakthrough in islet transplantation to significantly improve care and quality of life of patients with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are a novel class of RNAs representing up to 80% of the genome, though only a handful of lncRNAs have been demonstrated with function in the most common and deadly brain tumor, glioblastoma (GBM). I have identified a novel lncRNA, linc02454, upregulated by GBM chemotherapy, that modulates the chemosensitivity of GBM. I plan to characterize the manner by which chemotherapy increases linc02454, and the manner by which linc02454 affects treatment sensitivity, to better understand the role of lncRNAs following adjuvant therapy, while acquiring the training in transcriptional regulation necessary to develop as a surgeon-scientist.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive alcohol use is the 5th-leading risk factor for premature death and disability. Unfortunately, recent societal phenomena might contribute to worsening alcohol use disorder recognition and care. PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because it introduces a robust new approach of using smartphone-based training to scale up tobacco control evidence-based interventions (EBIs). By delivering training through smartphones, the potential reach of the EBIs is multiplied over what can be achieved with in- person training. PHR: The goal of this research is to use machine learning algorithms to work out which  genetic differences in the genomes of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients might have  caused their disease. The proposed study will discover what genes,  pathways and molecular mechanisms are involved in AD, which will provide novel  therapeutic targets for AD patients.
