IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, consuming contaminated foods is the annual cause of 47.8 million illnesses, 128,000 hospitalizations, and 3,000 deaths just in the U.S., more than half of foodborne illness outbreaks are associated with food from restaurants. More than 3,000 state, local, territorial, and tribal (SLTT) agencies have primary responsibility to regulate the retail food and foodservice industries in the United States. If this project is funded, NACCHO and CFP will work collaboratively with the Retail Food Safety Regulatory Association Collaborative to further the capacity of SLTT agencies to improve retail food safety and reduce foodborne illness across the U.S.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Extremely premature neonates, who are at a critical stage of central nervous system development, endure the highest risk of being exposed to chorioamnionitis and develop cerebral palsy. I have identified that chorioamnionitis-induced perinatal alterations of Heme-oxygenase-1 (HO-1) pathway in the developing rat brain correlate with neuroinflammation and my proposed studies will investigate how these alterations contribute to immune-mediated perinatal white matter injury. By gaining insight into this previously not studied pathway in perinatal white matter injury, defining novel molecular mechanisms, innovative diagnostic and therapeutic interventions will be possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Over 1.7 million people are diagnosed with cancer in the United States every year. We strive to understand how these cancers develop by studying how mistakes are made when cells duplicate their genetic material. The detailed knowledge of the mechanisms that prevent these mistakes, may contribute to the development of future cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organ formation and tissue patterning requires collective cell behaviors driven by planar cell polarity (PCP), a conserved biological pathway essential for early human development. Deficiencies in PCP function contribute to severe developmental disorders such as spina bifida and congenital heart defects, and patterning defects of the inner ear and skin. The proposed program of research will uncover fundamental mechanisms of PCP regulation and reveal how mutations in PCP components contribute to human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Men who have sex with men and are living with HIV bear the greatest burden of anal cancer. Treatment of the anal cancer precursor, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL), has proven effective for preventing cancer, and research on how to best implement screening and treatment of HSIL is key to mitigating the risk of anal cancer in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) such as Nigeria where HIV is highly prevalent. This work will yield a systematic strategy for evaluating HSIL screening and treatment implementation in an HIV care setting and provide generalizable knowledge on context-specific adaptation of a complicated evidence- based intervention in a challenging LMIC environment that will benefit the broader field of implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine is the fastest growing drug of abuse in the U.S., representing 800,000 emergency department visits and nearly 35,000 deaths annually. The proposed project addresses the urgent need for a safe, rapidly acting therapeutic to treat methamphetamine overdose. Such an antidote would save lives, improve patient outcomes, and relieve burden on already strained hospital resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The descending auditory efferent pathway may be involved in supra-threshold hearing, but a comprehensive understanding of how the efferent system develops in humans is lacking. The proposed work will investigate the development of the temporal aspects of efferent mechanisms in children. It is clinically and scientifically relevant, as the knowledge gained can be used to develop objective tests for assessing auditory function, guide intervention efforts and may be applied for designing hearing devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This renewal grant application represents a deepened extension of the current grant (DE25681) focusing on the bone-enhancing effects of microRNA (miR)-335-5p, first identified and characterized in our laboratory. Our recent studies have demonstrated that miR-335-5p has important dual-effects: inhibiting osteoclastic bone resorption and promoting osteoblastic bone formation, therefore miR-335-5p is a potent pharmaceutic agent for treating osteoporosis and its related bone disorders, where the balance between resorption and formation is disturbed. Applying our recently generated miR-335-5p gene knockout and overexpressing transgenic mouse lines our newly developed, cutting-edge targeted nanoparticle system will be used for the first time to precisely deliver miR-335-5p to the distinct cell types to modulate both bone anabolic and metabolic pahways, which will allow this translational study to shift the paradigm in understanding, treating and ultimately curing osteoporosis and its related bone disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High-throughput spatial technologies are poised to become ubiquitous and transformative in precision medicine, including the diagnosis, prognosis, and therapeutic response in disease. However, researchers who aim to appropriately interpret these data face new challenges with increasingly complex data and experimental designs, such how to harmonize and jointly analyze multiple spatial samples simultaneously with images and omics data, or how to identify spatial-dependent difference across experimental groups, such as healthy and disease states, each group with multiple donors or adjacent tissue sections. Our long-term goal is to address these questions by developing statistically-rigorous computational tools for spatial and long-read technologies with increased statistical power to detect spatial domains or differences in spatial-dependent gene expression in large atlas-scale spatially-resolved transcriptomics data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite South Africa having the largest antiretroviral treatment program in the world HIV incidence remains high and epidemic control will not be reached without an effective complementary prevention program. The daily provision of combination antiretroviral medication to HIV negative individuals at substantial risk of HIV infection has proven highly effective at preventing HIV infection (known as ‘pre-exposure prophylaxis’ - PreP), but even where PrEP is available uptake amongst key populations has remained sub optimal. The behavioral economic framework provides a unique lens to examine why at-risk individuals are not initiating and persisting on PrEP and in doing so will provide evidence to develop alternative, low cost approaches to encourage optimal decision making around PrEP use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of the adult brain to undergo plasticity is limited than that observed in young, but some sensory deprivation paradigms can effectively produce plasticity in the adult primary visual cortex (V1). Here we will examine how visual and auditory deprivation differentially alters adult V1 to enhance either contextual or visual inputs, respectively. Our results will not only elucidate the mechanisms of adult cortical plasticity, but will also provide means to selectively enhance specific functionality of the adult V1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal seeks to improve HIV outcomes among pregnant and postpartum women living with HIV and their infants in sub-Saharan Africa. We will develop a novel risk calculator to better identify pregnant women who should be the highest priority for intervention to prevent treatment failure and dropouts from HIV care. Next, we will engage women and lay health workers in adapting a promising evidence-based intervention (Problem Management Plus) to address psychosocial stressors and reduce treatment failure and loss to follow up and then pilot the intervention to test its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy. This study will contribute to the overall goal of achieving optimal health outcomes for women living with HIV and their families in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Statement The two emerging ‘hallmarks of cancer’ are deregulating cellular energetics and avoiding immune disruption. By integrating cell metabolism and immune function, the principal investigator has consistently made important contributions to our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of immunometabolism and its impact on cancer, especially in dissecting the interplay between immune signaling and metabolism and synthesizing systems immunology with immunometabolism. The project described in this application will provide an integrative view of immunometabolism, and how it relates to cancer and cancer therapy, with an excellent path to bench-to- bedside translation and clinical development for innovative therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drinking in adolescence is common, but the persistent consequences of excessive drinking during adolescence are not well understood. The NADIA Administrative Core coordinates the efforts of eight Research Components and one Scientific Core to determine the consequences of binge-like adolescent alcohol exposure on adult brain physiology, structure, chemistry, maturation and behavioral indices of affect, motivation and/or cognition. This information will be important to guide public health policy and develop better tools for the prevention of risky behavior in adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer researchers grounded in the field of pathology are critically needed if basic insights into the pathobiology of cancer are to translate into improved patient treatment and better patient outcomes. To address this need, the Oncopathology Training Program at Brigham and Women’s Hospital will provide physicians trained in the field of pathology with the comprehensive mentored research and didactic training experience that is needed to prepare them for careers as cancer investigators. We seek to train future leaders in pathology who not only provide new insights into the cause of cancer, but also bring innovative approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of cancer to the clinic, to the benefit of cancer patients and their families.
PROJECT_TERMS: Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Oncopathology Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The U.S. has more health science STEM jobs available than qualified workers to fill them and lags other OECD nations in math and science, with major achievement gaps and STEM workforce under- representation among women and students of color. With its successful Phase I SBIR results, Parametric Studio Inc (PSI) proved the functionality, feasibility, and usability of MiMICRE, a game-based project platform that uses collaborative bioengineering projects to help address STEM deficiencies, promote 21st-century skills, and reduce under-representation in the future health science and STEM workforce. The PSI team now proposes a Phase II project that will allow the PSI team to complete full development of MiMICRE with all fully tested/validated STEM- related features and capabilities needed for commercial investment and deployment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one million babies die annually in low and middle-income countries due to a brain injury caused by inadequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the neonatal brain, a condition known as hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy. “Milking” the umbilical cord, a method used to transfer blood from the placenta into the baby before the umbilical cord is clamped, may result in decreased death and brain injury due to lack of blood flow to the brain. This intervention may prevent some conditions or disabilities that have lifelong consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A major advance in using immunology to treat disease has been giving patients T cells that have been expanded in the laboratory and are specific for an antigen associated with the patient's medical condition, using either naturally antigen-specific T cells or using gene transfer to make the T cells specific for a particular antigen. Not all patients benefit from these therapies partly because the administered T cells must also have the right machinery to go to the site where they are needed. Antigen displayed on the lining of the local blood vessels normally can direct T cell homing to the right sites and, in this application, we will determine if the same process can also direct homing of expanded T cells, and if so, how to make it more efficient.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic overuse at hospital discharge is common, costly, and harmful. Despite evidence that discharge- specific stewardship interventions can improve antibiotic prescribing, these interventions are not feasible for most hospitals. To address this need, we will conduct a 40-hospital cluster randomized trial to evaluate the effectiveness and understand factors influencing implementation of the Reducing Overuse of Antibiotics at Discharge (ROAD) Home intervention, a participatory intervention that helps hospitals select strategies to improve their discharge antibiotic prescribing based on their needs, context, and capacity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Overuse of Antibiotics at Discharge: The ROAD Home Trial
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this application is to understand the different types of skeletal stem cells in the skull vs. long bones, and how they contribute to bone formation and repair. We will also study the effects of Wnt1 signaling and anti-sclerostin therapy on this population and during repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell genomics has recently advanced the lineage tracing field, enabling fine-resolution tracking of individual cells. Unfortunately, these methods have limitations in their reliance upon multiple experimental interventions for cell labeling, causing bifurcation events to be missed, and limitations due to transgene silencing of the components of the single-cell lineage tracing system, making single-cell lineage tracing inapplicable in valuable model systems such as pluripotent cell differentiation. My preliminary results indicate that a CRISPR- Cas12a-guided cytidine deaminase can function as an editor to accrue mutations constantly over time to record lineage, and the application of this editing will create robust lineage tracing systems that can mitigate transgene silencing and dispense with the need for multiple rounds of cell labeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Enabling Rational Design of Drug Targeting Protein-Protein Interactions with Physics- based Computational Modeling. A network of protein-protein interactions (PPIs) is at the core of cells’ and viruses’ abilities to perform their functions and regulate their life-cycles. Developing drugs to modulate these interactions will result in new classes of antivirals and antibiotics, and new therapies to fight diseases characterized by an imbalance in the interaction network, such as some forms of cancer. We propose to use physics-based simulations to develop key missing computational tools that will enable the rational designing of these new classes of antiviral and antibiotic drugs and cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Centenarian cognitive superagers have exceptional cognitive function despite extreme exposure to the strongest risk factor for cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease, aging. The “Resilience/Resistance to AD in Centenarians and Offspring” (RADCO) Study gauges cognitive resilience among centenarian cognitive superagers and their offspring using cognitive testing, neuroimaging, blood biomarkers, and neuropathology and translational studies will identify protective factors and underlying mechanisms that confer resilience or in some cases, even resistance against cognitive decline and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Substance abuse disorders are a chronic human condition where initial consumption leads to long-lasting behavioral changes, driven in part by initial, and then progressive resistance to the intoxicating effects of alcohol as tolerance develops. The results of the proposed studies will provide valuable mechanistic insight into the way initial ethanol exposure causes these long-lasting behavioral changes. This will highlight novel targets for therapeutic intervention with alcohol addiction, which are largely lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Project Narrative Post-transplant cyclophosphamide (PTCy) has lowered the non-relapse mortality after allogeneic BMT to less than 10% even in the mismatched setting. This proposal will study the period after allogeneic BMT as a unique time to study maintenance therapy to reduce relapse. In addition, the now near universal availability of the procedure, enabled by the favorable safety and cost profile associated with PTCy, opens up examining alloBMT for unique applications, such as solid tumors and HIV.

PHR: NARRATIVE Veterinarians play a central role in protecting animal and human health by preserving the efficacy of the antibiotics that their use for their patients. We have created a partnership among a public university, private veterinary hospitals, and a leading industry partner to collect information on how antibiotics are being used in cat and dog practices across the country with no disruption to the participating hospitals. The data will support FDA’s commitment to promoting antimicrobial stewardship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. New approaches to fight Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are desperately needed. We have already generated a monoclonal antibody to the conserved essential protein EF-Tu and shown it to be able to decrease colonization in a murine model of acute P. aeruginosa pneumonia. Here we will screen spleen cells from immunized mice and blood from humans with high titer antibodies to EF-Tu at single cell level using flow cytometry and an innovative nanoculture microfluidic array, respectively, to generate additional monoclonal antibodies to EF-Tu with even more efficacy based on in vitro binding assays, opsonophagocytic killing, and mouse challenge studies, as a first step to develop novel reagents to treat infections caused by this opportunistic pathogen.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because visual object recognition and learning is implicated in broad array of cognitive tasks in early the learning of first words, reading and learning the symbol systems of mathematic; the continued risks of children treated for amblyopia and strabismus in perceptual, cognitive and school achievements and the nexus of disrupted visual learning and lexical development in children with Developmental Language Delay and Autism. Understanding infants self-generated active visual experiences is expected to give rise to new diagnostics and behavioral interventions for at-risk infants. Thus, this proposal is relevant to NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental discoveries and innovative research strategies as a basis for ultimately protecting child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  The lung alveolar epithelium is exposed to the environment and pathogens and is thus highly susceptible to injury. Repair of the alveolar epithelium requires the activation of alveolar epithelial stem cells by signals from their surrounding niche. In this proposal we address a novel mechanism of bioactive lipid mediated interaction between lung microvascular endothelial cells and alveoli epithelial cells in the reparative niche, and hope to throw new light on the fundamental mechanisms driving lung repair after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients have cardiac outflow tract defects frequently requiring medical intervention. The affected cardiac outflow tract structures include cardiac septum and semilunar valves derive from embryonic progenitor cells in neural crest tissue and endocardium. This research project will determine the molecular and cellular mechanisms downstream of the 22q11.2 deleted region that regulate the functions of these progenitor cells to form the cardiac outflow tract.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative As acquisitions of primary care practices by private equity (PE) firms accelerate nationwide, this proposal focuses on the specific mechanisms by which PE firms may alter provider behavior under different financial incentives in Traditional Medicare and Medicare Advantage, which together cover primary care services for nearly 60 million Americans. We apply newer statistical methods to estimate PE's effects on quality of care and patient outcomes, as well as to assess heterogeneous treatment effects across different patient populations and impacts on health care equity. Findings will provide novel, timely, and comprehensive quantitative assessments of this growing trend of PE practice ownership, helping to inform ongoing state and federal policy efforts to support access to high-value primary care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Private Equity Acquisitions in Primary Care: Effects on the Medicare Program

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the genomic basis of human milk composition is key to developing precision nutrition for preterm infants and other clinical populations of interest. We will take a multi-omic, systems-level view of the mother-milk-infant triad, identifying novel relationships linking maternal and infant health to milk composition. To accelerate milk biosystems discovery, our findings will be shared with the research community through creation of a web-based portal and corresponding data visualization tools.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging HIV treatment and prevention formulations have the potential to expand choices for young people, who face unique challenges to access and use of existing options. Concerns about cost may limit both offering and uptake of new treatments in many settings with severely constrained budgets. We propose to adapt and expand the structure of an adolescent-focused HIV simulation model and to assemble the necessary data to identify the most effective and cost-effective medications and monitoring strategies for the treatment and prevention of HIV among adolescents and young adults in South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine whether mast cell mediated histamine release triggered by focal neurogenic inflammation is a fundamental mediator of the acute bone resorption precipitated by muscle paralysis. While this intercellular signaling cascade has not previously been implicated in bone, its individual components are well explored in other contexts. Critically, this pathway holds substantial potential to be targeted by antihistamine therapy as a novel strategy to prevent bone loss induced by paralysis or direct neuromuscular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fragile X syndrome (FXS), the most common inherited form of intellectual disability and a leading genetic cause of autism spectrum disorders (ASD), is caused by the loss of functional fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP). Recent technological development of 2D and 3D culture derived from human iPSCs provides a new platform to investigate human brain development in a dish, otherwise inaccessible to experimentation. This multi-project Center aims to establish a framework to understand the FMRP-mediated regulation of human brain development at molecular, cellular and system circuitry levels that will enable the development of therapeutic approaches to treat FXS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will leverage the Asian Bipolar Genetics Network (A-BIG-NET), an international collaboration of investigators from the U.S., Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, India and Pakistan, to carry out a molecular genetics study of bipolar disorder in East and South Asia. It will establish a valuable genetics resource with 4x low-pass whole genome sequence and rich phenotype data that will dramatically increase the worldwide diversity of genetics data on bipolar disorder, an important step to accelerate gene discovery in this disorder and advance global mental health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Sulfur mustard is one of the most important chemical threats with a devastating impact on human health. Despite its ruinous history for over 100 years, there are inadequate countermeasures to treat the acute and late effects of the chemical agent. This program brings together an interdisciplinary team of scientists and clinicians to take basic findings into a clinical setting, which will facilitate our understanding and treatment for SM injury of the skin and eyes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE The risk of breast cancer for any individual can vary significantly. We have identified complex cell types in human breast tissue that are associated with breast cancer risk factors. In this proposal, we will establish patient-derived breast organoid cultures from normal and precancerous breast tissue to develop strategies to prevent precursor cells from developing into aggressive cancers, to determine who might benefit from these cancer prevention strategies, and ultimately to contribute to the development of a future adaptive platform trial for breast cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in ABCA4 are the most common form of inherited retinal degeneration causing central vision loss that can occur in children as well as in adults. Accumulation of toxic byproducts of the visual cycle can lead to cone, rod, and retinal pigmented epithelium disease and death. Using a canine model of ABCA4 early-onset disease, we will exploit a nanoparticle vector technology, already proven to efficiently target photoreceptors and RPE in rodents, to optimize treatments to permanently prevent disease onset or arrest progression at patient-relevant disease stages.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early nutrition critically influences growth, neurodevelopment and morbidity among infants born of very low birth weight (VLBW), but current feeding protocols do not optimally support these vulnerable infants. The Opti-NuM Project will leverage the world’s most comprehensive clinical nutrition database and biobank for VLBW infants to analyze the nutrient and non-nutrient components of human milk consumed by this population. We will apply a unique systems biology approach combining multi–omics technologies and machine learning to develop a “precision nutrition” approach for human milk-fed VLBW infants to optimally support their short- and long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This is a Phase III clinical trial to establish the efficacy of progressive high-intensity, endurance treadmill exercise to slow the progression of the signs of Parkinson's disease (PD). If successful, this study will have a significant impact on the quality of life of people with PD and their caregivers as well as public health since it will slow progression of the signs of PD. Establishing high-intensity endurance treadmill exercise as a means to slow the progression of the signs of the disease would mark a significant breakthrough in treating PD and would have a significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In utero exposure to maternal inflammation caused by environmental factors, such as diet, affects offspring susceptibility to neurodevelopmental disorders; yet, the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. High-fat diets alter the functional composition of the gut microbiome, which is emerging as a major influence on host physiology, including fetal immune maturation and neurodevelopment. The goal of this project is to understand whether and how high-fat diet-induced dysbiosis of the maternal gut microbiome during pregnancy contributes to abnormal fetal epigenetic programming underlying neurobehavioral dysfunction across multiple descendant generations, and to determine the potential for therapeutic modulation of the maternal gut microbiome during pregnancy to prevent adverse neurobehavioral outcomes in descendants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: In this project, we use precise genome editing to generate novel mouse models, recapitulating p63 mutations that cause human EEC syndrome (Ectrodactyly-Ectodermal Dysplasia-Cleft Lip/Palate). We will use systems biology tools to examine gene regulatory networks affected by these p63 mutations during skin development and hair morphogenesis. Knowledge gained from the proposed studies will help to identify the mechanisms associated with human birth defects caused by p63 mutations and provide new insights into how point mutations in the DNA binding domain of a transcription factor selectively affect enhancer functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lupus nephritis, an autoimmune kidney disease characterized by a T and B lymphocyte infiltrate, is associated with significant morbidity and mortality yet no targeted treatments exist. This proposal will investigate the function of kidney-infiltrating B lymphocytes and determine how B lymphocyte survival and function are influenced by the high sodium concentrations found in the kidney tissue environment. The work will utilize both animal models and human kidney biopsies and will help identify kidney-specific targets for the treatment of lupus nephritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Information from this project will enhance our understanding of how to effectively treat skin blistering and secondary immune reactions after exposure of sulfur mustard to the skin. There is a need for novel drugs that can comprehensively treat both the chemical burn and life-threatening internal organ damage. This highly translational approach blocks and dampens hyper-reactive immune responses using novel topical and systemic treatments to promote repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Stem cells have the unique ability to replenish both themselves and the specialized cell types of our organs. Dysregulation of this balance leads to diverse diseases, such as fibrosis and cancer, that lack effective treatments. We use novel microscopy approaches to study this balance in the skin in live animals, which allows us to discover previously unknown mechanisms that sustain our organs, how these mechanisms go awry in disease, and potential therapeutic strategies to restore balance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco taxes are widely used and demonstrably effective in reducing mortality and morbidity including cancer related outcomes, but they may exacerbate tobacco-related socioeconomic disparities. The findings of this project will elucidate a novel tax proposal designed to reduce tobacco dependence and tobacco-related disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE When autologous tissue is not available or split thickness skin grafts alone are used, full thickness skin loss may not heal or will heal by contracture of the surrounding skin. Current treatment approaches including engineered off the shelf products have significant limitations, including slow, inconsistent, and inadequate tissue formation, hence impaired wound healing. The commercialization of DermiSphereTM is expected to improve clinical practice in surgical fields where full thickness skin loss is common including, but not limited to, trauma, burns, and post- oncologic reconstructive surgery, by significantly decreasing the time required to achieve a healed wound, as well as increasing the thickness of the regenerated dermis in a scenario of full thickness skin loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Information obtained from this project will validate and define key biomarkers in response to mustard gas exposure. The innovation for this project is the experimental setup that permits testing with discarded human tissue coupled with insights drawn from clinical medicine. The findings will enable the translation and discovery of new countermeasures for mustard gas injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our sense of light touch underlies our ability to detect and discriminate a wide range of tactile stimuli, but the mechanisms by which the central nervous system integrates inputs from primary sensory neurons remain elusive. This proposal will advance our understanding of tactile perception through exploration of how somatosensory signals are organized within the dorsal column nuclei (DCN) of the brainstem for output to brain regions with distinct functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  The Bridges to Doctorate program between the California State University, Fresno (Fresno State) and the University of California, Davis (UC Davis) will offer a range of curricular, research, and co-curricular activities for five Bridges graduate scholars each year to develop a pipeline for graduate students to successfully get accepted into Ph.D. programs in biomedical sciences. Fresno State is in the San Joaquin Valley (SJV) in California's Central Valley, one of the most rapidly growing culturally and ethnically diverse yet underserved areas in California. By working together with the faculty, members in the College of Science and Mathematics at Fresno State and faculty from UC Davis will create a highly interactive program to promote access to research careers to under-represented ethnic minorities and ease the transition of these students into Ph.D. programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Calcium signaling plays a central role in pancreatic β cell function, and alterations in β cell calcium signaling are observed in both major forms of diabetes. Ryanodine receptors are large-conductance calcium release channels in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane. The proposed research will define how ryanodine receptor dysfunction in the β cell contributes to diabetes pathophysiology and will test the hypothesis that the ryanodine receptor serves as a critical hub in the pancreatic β cell, regulating calcium dynamics, insulin secretion, and cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a common and life-threatening response to infection that commonly leads to severe injury to the lung, known as the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). We have identified a genetic variant in the gene for haptoglobin that predisposes sepsis patients to develop ARDS. This proposal will define the mechanisms of this increased risk of ARDS with the goal of developing new therapies to prevent ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synaptic signaling is based on a complex interplay between neurotransmitters, such as GABA and glutamate, and neuromodulators, such as neurotrophic growth factors. We propose here to identify the molecular mechanisms by which a neurotrophin receptor (TrkB) and a metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR5) are able to mutually regulate each other to drive a unique form of crosstalk-dependent synaptic plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative To understand the mechanism underlying seizures associated with alcohol withdrawal, we propose to investigate the novel hypothesis that altered neuronal activity and connectivity of hippocampal newborn neurons underlie development of alcohol withdrawal seizures. Using state-of-the art methods, we will map neuronal and functional connectivity, as well as activity of neural circuits that are responsible for alcohol withdrawal seizures. Outcomes of this proposal will provide molecular, cellular, and neural circuitry mechanisms by which hippocampal newborn DGCs impact on local and global neural circuits that underlie alcohol withdrawal seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventive interventions for college student risky drinkers are well established, but the needs of emerging adult risky drinkers who live in disadvantaged communities and are not fulltime college students have been neglected, and they often have more limited access to rewarding opportunities, activities, and adult roles that present alternatives to heavy drinking. Guided by behavioral economics, this randomized controlled trial will address their needs by evaluating an evidence-based behavioral intervention aimed at increasing future orientation and engagement in pro-social alternatives to drinking and will be delivered using a peer- driven sampling method and digital platform well suited for accessing emerging adult social networks. The study will be the first to test a web-based alcohol reduction intervention focused on behavioral economic principles and has high potential for reach and scalability with under-served community risk groups.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: NARRATIVE. Most Veterans are diagnosed with prostate cancer when the disease is confined to the prostate and amenable to cure. However, a significant proportion of localized tumors display aggressive features associated with a high risk of recurrence following definitive treatment (e.g. surgery or radiation). Our ability to predict which patients with high-risk prostate cancer will develop lethal metastasis is limited. We will leverage the VA healthcare system and assemble a massive dataset of digital images from diagnostic prostate biopsies and magnetic resonance imaging linked to standard clinico-pathologic factors and social determinants of health variables. Application of artificial intelligence (AI) approaches and integration of digital biomarkers with other variables will yield a “superclassifier” to quantify the likelihood of metastasis-free survival and determine treatment intensification interventions to reduce metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Plastic and chemical pollutants are pervasive in the environment and an emerging human health concern. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will establish a novel model system to rigorously and reproducibly study exposure to nanoplastic and environmentally relevant chemical pollutant mixtures. Once such strategies are developed, there is a potential for significant advancement in understanding the cellular and molecular basis of combined nanoplastic-chemical mixture impact on physiology and thus possible risks to human health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Effective treatments of many neurological diseases rely on the understanding of the functional networks in the deep brain, which presents technical challenges in terms of neural interface devices. Our proposed studies aim to address these challenges by developing a spatially expandable, multifunctional fiber-based probe for large volume, deep brain interfacing. These studies will have the potential to provide new insights as well as new therapeutic strategies for various neurological diseases, and provide a powerful tool for advancing the fundamental study of the microcircuitry and functional network in both animal and human brains.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: National Environmental Health Association (NEHA) PROPOSAL FOR FUNDING OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENT RFA-FD-22-008 Project Narrative This proposal builds on the foundational principles of food safety, focusing on preventative measures at the retail level that will lead to higher rates of compliance with current food safety requirements and standards, thereby reducing foodborne illness. This collaborative approach with other retail food safety associations leverages resources and collective expertise to 1) identify gaps in existing support for the retail food safety workforce; 2) highlight best practices, tools, and resources; and 3) develop new, modern, and accessible materials. Together, we will advance and strengthen the retail food safety workforce and empower industry and regulatory members to improve existing practices and reduce foodborne illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The research themes of the Center deal with some of the nation’s biggest health challenges and opportunities. In each of these areas, the potential for scientific findings that improve health outcomes is significant. The themes of Center research are: (1) health trends and inequalities, (2) data analytics, information technology and health care decision-making, (3) the economics of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, (4) the dynamics of the health care ecosystem, and (5) medical innovation and the value of health care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Children born to obese mothers are at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes at a younger age and preclinical models demonstrate the presence of worsened pancreatic beta cell dysfunction in males when compared to female offspring, but the mechanistic pathways underlying this observation are unclear. The goal of this proposal is to delineate the role of Reg3g-mediated heparan sulfate polymerization as a mechanistic pathway amenable to treatment of sex-specific islet dysfunction in offspring of obese mice. This proposal will address a critical gap in our understanding of the developmental programming of offspring islet dysfunction induced by maternal obesity and has the potential to inform novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Problematic substance use during adolescence predicts morbidity and mortality across the lifespan, suggesting the urgent public health need to prevent the escalation of use during this developmental period. The proposed project will examine the feasibility and effectiveness of implementing a preventative intervention aimed at improving decision making processes among adolescents in a traditionally underserved community. Targeting mechanisms of problematic substance use using transportable and scalable methods will set the stage for future, large-scale prevention efforts among low-resource populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as there is still a gap in understanding maternal-infant pharmacology. The UCSD MPRINT Center of Excellence in Therapeutics will bring together basic and data scientists, pharmacologists and clinical researchers in a highly collaborative fashion to understand the impact of infant exposure to maternal antibiotic treatment via breastmilk on the metabolism of the drugs, microbiome and immune function. The proposed research will help create a national resource for expertise in maternal and pediatric therapeutics and is relevant to NICHD’s mission by furthering the field of pediatric developmental pharmacology and in working towards ensuring that “all children have the chance to achieve their full potential for healthy and productive lives”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it contributes to a program of research focused on significantly improving the communication abilities of individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders, including females with idiopathic autism spectrum disorder (iASD) and females with fragile X syndrome (FXS). Through a rigorous, longitudinal design, the proposed study will examine both language and executive function using well validated measures including experimental tasks, standardized assessments, parent report, and naturalistic language sampling to successfully achieve our three specific aims. Given the prevalence of iASD (1 in 54 children), and the significant overlap between FXS and iASD, this project directly addresses the NIDCD's mission to improve the lives of individuals with communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Speech and language disorders are major health issues. Speech perception requires a listener to compute linguistic units from variable acoustic signals, and where and how these computations happen in the human auditory cortex remains speculative. Using invasive human electrophysiology, we propose to study the neural encoding and computational underpinnings of the acoustic and linguistic features that enable speech perception; investigating this process in various auditory areas at high resolution will extend our knowledge of human speech perception and produce new insights into the mechanisms of speech and language disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of new strategies to slow or prevent the progression of prediabetes to type 2 diabetes would have a significant health benefit to millions of individuals worldwide and would reduce related economic burden on healthcare systems. Zinc supplementation may represent an efficacious, safe, and inexpensive way to improve insulin action and reduce fasting glucose, hemoglobin A1c, and lipid levels in subjects with prediabetes. The proposed research will provide novel insights regarding the utility of zinc supplementation in those with prediabetes, prospectively characterize genetic variation that impacts zinc transport, and ultimately provide justification for future mechanistic studies and larger clinical trials of zinc supplementation to prevent or delay onset of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is common complication of acute lung injury that is associated with a high mortality. We propose a multimodality imaging approach for evaluation of activation of an enzyme in the lung that has been shown to play an important role in disease progression. We will use this same imaging approach to also assess a novel drug delivery system for local inhibition of this enzyme in the lung to prevent the progressive lung injury associated with ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The study of lactate racemase and its newly discovered nickel-pincer nucleotide (NPN) cofactor is highly relevant to public health because the enzyme is present in many microorganisms associated with the human microbiome and in numerous pathogens. The racemase enzyme produces D-lactate that is required for biosynthesis of the cell walls and responsible for vancomycin resistance in some microorganisms. This project will elucidate the steps of NPN cofactor synthesis and define its roles in metabolism beyond lactate racemization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Bleeding symptoms in female Hemophilia A carriers are underrecognized and poorly understood, leading to adverse health events and outcomes. Current methods of assessing bleeding risk in males with Hemophilia A are inadequate when applied to female Hemophilia A carriers, and no formal classification consistent with their bleeding risk exists. To improve the identification and risk stratification of this large group, we will develop and validate a multivariate risk prediction model, perform mechanistic studies to evaluate the underlying molecular basis for bleeding, and evaluate additional modifiers of hemostasis to further refine risk prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement There is an urgent need for effective diabetes self-management interventions that are convenient, scalable, sustainable, and able to meet the needs of diverse patient populations including those with limited health literacy. Designed with user feedback and sensitivity to patients' literacy levels and developed with the ability to integrate into a variety of electronic health records, the My Diabetes Care (MDC) patient portal intervention has demonstrated the potential to fill this critical gap. The overall objective of this proposal is to: (1) expand MDC's display of user's diabetes health data beyond hemoglobin A1C, blood pressure, cholesterol, and flu vaccination status to include microalbumin and BMI and enhance access by creating a Spanish-language version; (2) evaluate the effects of MDC on diabetes-related outcomes while demonstrating its scalability by integrating it into another health system and conducting a pragmatic randomized controlled trail in an ethnically and racially diverse patient population; and (3) examine how the effects of MDC arise by studying causal mediators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TET DNA demethylases are essential for revising the DNA methylation patterns and are required for gene regulation and cell differentiation. TET enzymes are indispensable for human health, as TET mutations are frequently found in blood cancers and are associated with immunodeficiency and childhood cancers. Our proposed studies will provide critical mechanistic insights into how TET regulates gene expression and cell differentiation and identify potential therapeutic targets for treating immunodeficiency and cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The overarching goal of our Center proposal entitled “Translational Medicine and Mechanistic Studies of Brain Neurophysiology in Fragile X Syndrome” is to utilize highly interrelated research strategies with two primary aims, advancing translational medicine approaches (biomarker development, drug challenge studies, resolving illness heterogeneity) and expanding the mechanistic understanding of Fragile X syndrome (FXS) biology. The goal of this work is to foster the development of new, more effective therapies. We propose to pursue these aims through the establishment of integrated, interdependent research programs from patient-centered research to in vivo animal experiments to cellular sub-type specific and molecular models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of this project are to determine the developmental and clinical outcomes of infants with early parent concern for autism via telehealth, and to identify the material and psychosocial factors that support engagement and satisfaction with telehealth-mediated assessments. We propose to use a promising telehealth protocol for evaluating infants’ development, the TEDI, to prospectively follow 100 infants 6-12 months from diverse community settings through 36 months of age. Successful completion of these aims will increase the capacity to identify infants with elevated likelihood of autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders particularly in rural and low-resource areas, and will ultimately help to increase access to high-quality interventions and improve the developmental outcomes of many more underserved children with autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of people with Alzheimer’s dementia confirmed at autopsy—around 80%—are found to have one or more additional brain pathologies, including Lewy bodies, vascular brain injury, and TDP-43. A complementary and necessary strategy conventional case-control Alzheimer’s disease (AD) genetic studies is to perform genome-wide association studies (GWAS) using data from autopsies and distinguishing between research participants exhibiting “pure AD” and those with mixed AD pathology. The overarching goal of this proposal is to address this knowledge gap and further scientific understanding of the genetic influences of these differences by integrating detailed autopsy-derived data together with state-of-the-art statistical approaches and variety of omics data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is among the top ten most common and fatal cancers in the U.S, of which about 75% are non- muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) characterized by exceptionally high risks of recurrence and progression. The proposed study is seeking to identify molecular signatures of NMIBC, with a goal to develop and validate tools to address the two most urgent challenges in clinical management of NMIBC: identifying high-risk patients for early and aggressive treatment and identifying patients who will be unresponsive or intolerant to Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG), the mainstay adjuvant treatment for NMIBC, in favor of other treatments. Given that our study will be using data and specimens from a population-based, prospective cohort of NMIBC patients diagnosed within a large U.S. health care system, we can rapidly translate the findings into clinical practice to help improve NMIBC patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 6 million children in the United States have asthma, causing more than 14 million missed school days and billions of dollars in healthcare costs annually, with most poorly controlled asthma symptoms attributable to difficulties taking a daily inhaler that helps to control asthma. The proposed research program will evaluate Asthma Link, a school-supervised asthma therapy intervention tailored for real-world settings, that ensures children receive their daily inhaler at school. This intervention fills an unmet need for the families, pediatric practices and schools that support children with poorly controlled asthma and has the potential to dramatically improve childhood asthma outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: ZIP8 is a poorly understood transmembrane metal importer of iron, zinc, and manganese that appears to be important in multiple organ systems, including the lung, spleen, and placenta. We propose to study the functions of ZIP8 during bacterial and fungal lung infection, red blood cell recycling and iron processing by the spleen, and delivery of essential micronutrients to the developing fetus. Our findings will inform the clinical management of important public health issues, including infectious pneumonias, blood disorders, and pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SAPAP3-deletion mouse models recapitulate the prevalent and debilitating neuropsychiatric condition, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD), by evidence of their shared striatal dysfunction, behavioral validity (anxiety and compulsive grooming), as well as treatment validity (serotonin reuptake inhibitor). Within the SAPAP3-lacking striatum, we home in on a newly characterized dysregulation of the crucial striatal neuromodulator, Acetylcholine (ACh), and the cholinergic interneurons (ChIs) which release ACh, as we test the functional determinants of ChI dysregulated output and the ability of ChI directed treatment to modify OCD- like behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial/ethnic minority (REM) researchers, who may be uniquely poised to address racial/ethnic disparities in mental and physical health, are underrepresented at all levels of the biomedical and behavioral sciences. Our Manhattan-Bridge program seeks to enhance the number of REM students in biomedical and behavioral sciences research by bridging the path from a minority-serving community college (Borough of Manhattan Community College) to a baccalaureate degree in a STEM field at a minority-serving senior college (The City College of New York). Manhattan-Bridge includes a coordinated system of faculty mentoring, peer mentoring, peer support, diversity training, STEM coursework, laboratory training, tutoring, and supplemental instruction to address and overcome the obstacles known to impede REM students from success in completing their baccalaureate degrees and launching careers in biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The purpose of this grant is to supplement the funding of three conferences (“Vestibular Disorders: From Cause to Cure”, “Post-pandemic Innovations in Connected Audiology”, and “Multi-Sensory Approaches to Auditory Rehabilitation”) to be hosted by the National Center for Rehabilitative Auditory Research between 2021 and 2025. The aim of these conferences is to improve auditory research and clinical practice by sharing the knowledge and perspectives of patients, clinicians, scientists and health policy stakeholders to alleviate the burden of auditory and vestibular deficits on function and quality of life. This conference is unique in its multidisciplinary, multiple stake holder approach to providing specialized training in clinical innovations, identification of the critical gaps in research, and appreciation of the health system barriers to advances in the field.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Overall project narrative: Repeating sequences of nucleotides in the Fragile X gene variably cause as set of human diseases (Fragile X Syndrome, Fragile X associated Tremor Ataxia Syndrome, and Fragile X primary ovarian insufficiency) for which we have no effective treatments. Our expert group will investigate the mechanisms by which this repeat causes disease in the broader context of its normal genomic functions while also identifying genes that modify the expressivity of Fragile X associated disorders. By using an integrative approach to understand how repeats work normally and how they elicit dysfunction, we hope to achieve a breakthrough in therapy development for Fragile X.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The locus coeruleus is one of the first sites of abnormal forms of Alzheimer's disease-related tau proteins in the brain, and from there it is assumed to spread through brain connections, altering its ability to coordinate large- scale networks. The proposed study aims to characterize the patterns and genetic features underlying locus coeruleus-related functional networks that facilitate tau spreading and cognitive decline as well as those that provide resiliency in the face of pathology. This project has important public health implications and is relevant to part of the NIH's mission as it will provide insights into the selective vulnerability of the locus coeruleus in Alzheimer's disease and can provide new targets for treatment early in the disease trajectory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasminogen activators are the only approved pharmacologic intervention for acute, life-threatening, thrombotic events, despite unfavorable pharmacokinetics resulting in a poor benefit/risk ratio. In order to solve this longstanding issue, this proposal will apply a novel, physiologically attractive strategy to prolong the circulation of plasminogen activators, namely coupling to albumin-binding ligands to co-opt the endosomal salvage pathway mediated by the neonatal Fc receptor. By delineating mechanisms underlying half-life extension, this research ultimately seeks to not only improve treatment strategies in acute thrombosis, but also guide rational development of pharmacokinetically-optimized protein therapeutics across a range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Chemotherapy leads to peripheral neuropathy (PN) in 90% of patients and is linked to disability and falls; however, we know little about the patterns and predictors of PN and subsequent falls. The knowledge gained from this study could provide clinical practice with best practice strategies to prevent falls in persons with PN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep wake disturbances occur in over 50% of the 50,000 children surviving traumatic brain injury (TBI) hospitalization each year and lead to poor quality of life, though few interventions exist to treat this important morbidity. Children with TBI also suffer cognitive impairments that could be compounded by poor sleep, particularly with respect to executive functions like memory and attention that are vital for academic achievement and optimal development. This proposal will determine the relationship between sleep wake disturbances and important executive functions after TBI, as well as test an early sleep management intervention as a target to improve outcomes in these vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Methods to monitor acute cannabis effects in real-time could reduce potential cannabis-related harm by raising a person's awareness of possible cannabis-related impairment, for example, on psychomotor performance (e.g., slowed response). Toward this goal, this project will collaborate with individuals who use cannabis for therapeutic purposes in monitoring, using their smartphone, the acute therapeutic and adverse effects of cannabis use, and will combine this fine-grained data with follow-up over 1-year because cannabis effects may differ at shorter (daily) and longer time scales (over months). In line with NIDA priorities, this project's novel combination of smartphone symptom monitoring and longer-term follow-up will guide the creation of real-time interventions to reduce cannabis-related impairment and harm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application uses new mouse models of Barth syndrome generated in our laboratory through editing a patient’s TAFAZZIN gene mutation into the mouse genome, as well as a floxed Tafazzin conditional knockout mouse to identify and characterize novel signaling pathways responsible for impaired cardiovascular function in this frequently lethal X-linked mitochondrial disease. Our patient-specific and heart-restricted approach to the study of Barth syndrome is designed to enhance our understanding of Tafazzin’s role in cardiomyocyte morphogenesis, non-compaction cardiomyopathy, metabolic reprogramming during both in utero and postnatal mitochondrial dysfunction and heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this grant application, we will develop a novel intracoronary imaging catheter system combining two complementary optical modalities for tissue characterization. The proposed system will be able to simultaneously assess structural and biomolecular changes in coronaries arteries that are associated with atherosclerotic plaque progression and sudden cardiac events. This approach will allow interventional cardiologists to detect plaque that may cause future major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with coronary artery disease – the leading cause of death in the US. Results from this study will support the advancement of new paradigms that could utilize the hybrid catheter system to guide interventional decision making in the catheterization lab, thus patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention may benefit from personalized treatment of these plaques and improved outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Inequities in depression and its diagnosis and treatment among rural-dwelling minority seniors, which are often rooted in place-based social and environmental factors (e.g., economic insecurity, histories of trauma, and gaps in health and social services), present a major public health burden. This K99/R00 application proposes to integrate my expertise in participatory qualitative research and implementation science with new knowledge in rural mental health research, quantitative and mixed-method designs, and intervention development, in order to enhance my independence as a researcher focused on addressing these social and environmental causes of health disparities, which the National Institute of Minority Health and Health Disparities has identified as a major priority. The proposed R00 research will elucidate how place-based vulnerabilities and protective factors shape experiences of depression among rural American Indian and Latinx elders in New Mexico, and contribute to the development of a plan for a community-driven place-focused intervention to reduce mental health disparities in this and other marginalized populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Inhibition of intestinal mucosal growth occurs commonly in patients who undergo massive gastrointestinal surgical resections and disrupted epithelial adaptation by inhibiting mucosal growth impairs gut barrier function and leads to the translocation of luminal toxic substances and bacteria to the bloodstream. Effective therapies to preserve the gut epithelium integrity are limited, because of poorly understood mechanisms underlying the regulation of gut mucosal renewal in stressful environments. Studies proposed this project will identify the roles of altered function of Paneth cell/intestinal stem cell niche by RNA-binding proteins and long noncoding RNAs in the control of gut mucosal growth/adaptation in patients with critical surgical disorders and will create a fundamental basis for development of new therapies to protect the gut epithelium integrity in the clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral contraceptives increase risk for the formation of blood clots in pre-menopausal women. This proposal will examine how oral contraceptives interact with genetic and non-genetic factors to alter the biochemistry of blood coagulation using biochemical studies, and cross-sectional and longitudinal clinical cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic sleep deprivation is a crisis and growing epidemic both nationally and globally, the cardiovascular consequences of which need further investigation according to the American Heart Association. This proposal aims to investigates both short sleep duration and sleep irregularity as potentially modifiable risk factors for vascular inflammation and visceral adiposity (a known contributor to cardiometabolic disease risk) measured using novel, multi-modality imaging. The long-term goal is for Dr. Kundel to become a successful independent investigator in sleep research, elucidating mechanistic pathways linking sleep deprivation to cardiovascular disease, and developing preventative strategies and therapeutic interventions (i.e., sleep extension trials) to gain deeper insights into mechanisms by which sleep modulates inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Growing pre-clinical and clinical evidence indicate that fasting for several hours each day can reduce cancer risk, but the mechanisms by which fasting decreases cancer risk are not understood. We propose to use both animal models and human samples to test how daily fasting optimizes mitochondrial function to reduce cancer risk. Since nearly 40% of all men and women will be diagnosed with cancer at some point in their lives, and daily fasting is an easy lifestyle intervention that can be readily adopted by most individuals, the proposed research project is highly relevant to NCI’s mission to reduce the incidence of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is the leading cause of hospitalization among adults aged 65 years and older in the United States, and individuals in this population experience significant functional limitations, intense physical and psychological symptoms, and decreased quality of life. The objective of this proposal is to develop and test LiveWell-HF, a psychologically informed palliative rehabilitation model designed to simultaneously address the psychosocial and functional needs of older adults after heart failure hospitalization. Findings from this proposal will be used to optimize LiveWell-HF for a next phase randomized control trial to evaluate its impact on quality of life in this vulnerable population.

PHR: Project Narrative RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH: This proposal contributes to improving reproductive health by focusing on a new ion channel complex and its modulation and how it may help keep the uterus relaxed during the progression of pregnancy. Understanding the expression and activity of this complex may contribute knowledge as to how the uterus becomes more contractile over the course of pregnancy. Knowledge gained from this proposal will help determine whether this complex modulates uterine function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  The CAV1 gene encodes the caveolin-1 protein which is associated with glaucoma, the second leading cause of blindness worldwide. The expression of caveolin-1 is also elevated in retinal inflammatory diseases such as diabetic retinopathy and autoimmune uveitis, but the function of caveolin-1 in the retina remains elusive. Understanding the function of this ocular disease-associated gene is likely to lead to novel therapeutic strategies for inflammatory eye disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current sepsis treatment guidelines and quality measures recommend immediate administration of antibiotics to all patients with suspected sepsis, but there is growing recognition that respiratory viruses are a common cause of sepsis and that many patients with viral sepsis may suffer harm from unnecessary antibiotic treatment. The proposed research will describe the burden of viral sepsis in a nationally representative dataset, investigate current antibiotic prescribing patterns and associations with outcomes in this population, and evaluate whether antibiotics can be safely withheld in patients with viral sepsis and low procalcitonin levels. These objectives will have major clinical and public health impact by illuminating the magnitude of potential risk associated with current sepsis treatment guidelines, identifying opportunities for sepsis care improvement, and informing practical strategies to reduce unnecessary and prolonged use of antibiotics in patients with viral sepsis.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Antibiotic Utilization Patterns and Impact on Outcomes for Patients with Respiratory Viral Sepsis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The overall goal of this proposal is relevant to public health because it seeks to prevent permanent hearing loss by linking behavioral, physiological and pharmacodynamic data in patients taking ototoxic antibiotics. The project will evaluate methods to detect ototoxicity by using individualized estimates of drug exposures and novel, newly developed hearing assessment tools to detect and predict ototoxicity. The overall goal of this proposal is relevant to NIH’s goal to foster fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a chronically painful condition and a leading cause of global disability. OA is characterized by articular cartilage deterioration and other joint pathologies including meniscus/ligament damage, synovitis, bone spurs and joint pain. None of the currently approved treatments alter disease progression by slowing articular cartilage degradation and/or promoting joint regeneration. Phlpp1 and Phlpp2 are cellular enzymes that limit cell proliferation and matrix production and are overexpressed in OA cartilage. In this project, we explore the mechanisms of Phlpp1/2 action in osteoarthritic joints and determine how Phlpp inactivation modifies articular cartilage quantity and quality, as well as pain, after injury and during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subjects with type 1 diabetes (T1D) have high risk of fracture that cannot be explained by bone mineral density (BMD) alone. Therefore, it has been hypothesized that bone quality and its microenvironment, including bone marrow adiposity (BMA), should play an important role on bone fragility in T1D. However, little is known about bone quality and BMA in T1D. This study proposes to assess 24-month changes in bone microstructure at the distal radius and distal tibia, and in BMA at the proximal femur in subjects with long-standing T1D compared to age-, sex-, and body mass index-matched controls without diabetes. Improving our understanding of the associations of T1D with bone density, quality, BMA, and strength could lead to the development of novel therapeutics to slow down or prevent bone loss and microstructural deterioration, and ultimately prevent fractures in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The proposed studies are designed to gain a detailed understanding of the critical role of amelogenin phosphorylation in the regulation of enamel mineral formation in vivo, using novel mouse models and advanced characterization techniques. The successful completion of this work will provide new insights into how hard tissues like bones and teeth form and aid in our understanding of inherited enamel diseases and factors that, for example, influence dental caries susceptibility. The successful completion of this work will also provide new insights for the development of improved methods for the regeneration of tooth enamel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite advances in screening and identification of modifiable risk factors, the incidence and mortality of colorectal cancer (CRC) remains high, as does the incidence of obesity, which is a well-established risk factor for CRC. Lack of understanding of the biological pathways linking obesity and associated risk factors to CRC is a major limiting factor in the development of new strategies for CRC prevention. If successful, our project will identify novel pathways for CRC prevention and will establish methods for integrating metabolomic and other biomarker data and dimension-reduction approaches to identify pathways underlying risk factors for cancer and other chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart diseases including heart rhythm disorders, in part due to abnormal sodium and calcium cycling in the heart, remain leading causes of morbidity and mortality in the US. This proposal seeks to gain new insights into how regulation of sodium channels inside the heart muscle cells regulates calcium cycling in normal and the diseased hearts. Information gleaned from these studies will be used to develop new therapeutic approaches to treat heart rhythm disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to achieve understanding of mechanisms underlying sepsis-induced ARDS due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) bacteremia. The novel premise is that PA causes endothelial pore formation, therefore endothelial barrier failure. The goals are to achieve new mechanistic understanding of these processes, and to evaluate pore-inhibiting strategies as possible cures for ARDS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses upon the kisspeptin-neurokininB-dynorphin (KNDy) hypothalamic circuitry in monkeys and man. The contributions of various components of the KNDy system to normal reproductive development and function will be explored using receptor agonists and antagonists. PHR: The Pathways in Biological Sciences (PiBS) program trains a select group of PhD students to prepare them for their future careers while they conduct their graduate research on the most pressing problems in modern biology. PiBS ensures the acquisition of critical scientific, leadership, and communication skills, while instilling a strong and proactive sense of inclusion and diversity. PiBS trainees will benefit society through their career- long contributions to a variety of biological endeavors, including research, industry, education, communication, and policy.
