IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The glucose-lowering effect of metformin and the underlying mechanisms have been extensively studied, but the effect of metformin on hepatic lipid metabolism and the action site of metformin warrant further research. To fill in the knowledge gap, we will perform liquid chromatography-high resolution mass spectrometry-based lipidomics, metabolomics, and 13C isotope tracing analysis, employ synthetic metformin probe and intestinal AMPK alpha 1 knockout mice, to quantitatively characterize the connections between metformin-induced metabolic alterations in intestine and hepatic lipid metabolism and to identify molecular targets of metformin. The findings of this study will unravel the role of metformin actions in intestine in modulating hepatic lipid metabolism and provide significant insights into strategies to prevent or treat dietary-induced fatty liver diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Effective antiretroviral therapy is critical during pregnancy for women living with HIV (WLHIV) for the health of both the mother and the fetus, but there are knowledge gaps in pharmacology of new HIV drugs, ways to assess adherence, and safety in pregnancy that prevent efficient and effective deployment of our most promising new HIV drugs in pregnant women. The objective of this proposal is to advance our knowledge of the pharmacology and safety of several new HIV drugs -- tenofovir alafenamide (TAF), bictegravir, and doravirine--in pregnant and post-partum women, using innovative tools, such as pharmacometrics and physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) modeling. Research goals include describing TAF pharmacokinetics (PK) and adherence benchmarks in pregnancy, characterizing the risk and implications of TAF-associated metabolic syndrome in pregnant WLHIV, and predicting bictegravir and doravirine PK in pregnant women and their fetuses, with the overall goal of optimizing HIV therapeutics for pregnant WLHIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL The overall goal of this Developmental and Hyperactive Ras Tumor (DHART) SPORE is to implement effective targeted therapies for neoplasms and cancers characterized by mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene (TSG) by conducting integrated, mechanistically based translational research. Using novel genetically engineered mice, patient derived xenografts, and robust Omics, we will delineate mutations that contribute to cancer pathogenesis and uncover new biomarkers of drug response and resistance that will inform the development of “next generation” treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – ADMINISTRATIVE CORE (CORE A) The DHART SPORE currently encompasses three highly integrated projects and three cores with the goal of implementing effective targeted molecular therapies for neoplasms and cancers characterized by NF1 mutations by conducting integrated, mechanistically based translational research. The goal of the Administrative Core is to provide scientific and administrative oversight for all the program components of the DHART SPORE. The core will provide the overall organizational framework by which researchers communicate and interact, manage finances, coordinate the review of progress of the research projects, scientific cores and developmental programs (DRP & CEP), consult with the members of the External and Internal Advisory boards, coordinate the overall data integration and analysis of the DHART SPORE, and continue to refine our infrastructure to enable sharing of data generated by our studies with other internal and external NF-collaborative consortiums.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synthetic oxytocin infusion, the current standard clinical method used to induce labor, has important shortcomings. Breast nipple stimulation triggers the pulsatile release of endogenous oxytocin hormone in the brain to induce spontaneous contractions, stimulates lactogenesis, and has other physiological benefits. Therefore, the current proposal seeks to examine whether inpatient nipple stimulation therapy via electric breast pump during labor induction results in a greater likelihood of spontaneous vaginal delivery, improves the frequency of exclusive and sustained lactation postpartum, and is more cost-effective than synthetic oxytocin infusion without nipple stimulation among nulliparas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative  Early diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is still challenging, because of the subtlety of the microstructural changes it initially causes in the brain and the difficulty of identifying them with traditional neuroimaging techniques such as PET or CT, and MRI (1.5T, 3T) scans. Recent evidence has revealed that one of the neurodegeneration hallmarks of AD, amyloid-beta plaques is associated with iron accumulation, which can be quantified in vivo through susceptibility MRI techniques. In this proposal, we bring forward a new alternative framework using ultra-high resolution, MR neuroimaging at 7T, wherein this approach will enable the analysis of pathologic markers in AD patients and bring novel insights in our understanding of the mechanisms of AD onset and progression.

PHR: Narrative (public health relevance statement): The grim prognosis and lack of therapeutic options for glioblastoma highlight the urgency of not only working towards developing novel treatment modalities but, in parallel, working on enhancing the efficacy of existing radiation and immunotherapy. By using a genetically engineered immunocompetent model of glioblastoma subtypes and primary human PDX models, this application aims to establish whether IL-1β serves as a compelling novel GBM anti-edema and anti-neoplastic therapy that is devoid of the severe side effects of DEX and anti-VEGFA; thus, it will have a significant impact on this disease.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the regulation of hair follicle stem cells and progenitors during the hair cycle is a crucial requirement for future hair regenerative therapies. We will systematically define the functions of the follicle- lining dermal sheath, a largely overlooked and understudied cell population, in regulating follicle regression. This work will expand our knowledge of stem cell and progenitor regulation by dermal sheath cells, which may be useful for the development of HF regeneration approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (Project 2) Individuals with NF1 have a high incidence of glioma. Also, the NF1 gene mutation is present in approximately 20-25% of sporadic high-grade gliomas. These NF1 mutant gliomas are aggressive and have no effective treatments. Through the use of sophisticated experimental models and molecular profiling of clinically annotated patient tumor biopsies, we will explore unique features of NF1 mutant gliomas also leveraging recent advances in PNST treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sharing the brain images and genomic data from stroke patients provides a unique resource to discover new treatments that can reduce the injury caused by strokes, if we can make the images findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR) so that investigators from around the world can study them. With prior NIH support we built the Cerebrovascular Knowledge Portal (CDKP) to share genetic data. We now propose to build the imaging CDKP (iCDKP) to enable investigators to study these data for insights that will someday lead to new treatments that can prevent strokes, reduce the damage a stroke causes, or help the brain recover from a stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurobiological mechanisms underlying symptoms of withdrawal are poorly understood despite the fact that they serve as potent triggers for relapse in individuals attempting to remain abstinent from alcohol. While our recent work uncovered a role for the rostromedial tegmental nucleus (RMTg) in regulating withdrawal symptoms, the broader neural circuitry that governs this effect remains unknown. The proposed project will interrogate the mechanistic involvement of input from the lateral habenula to the RMTg in symptoms of withdrawal and in doing so provide an opportunity to identify new potential therapeutic targets for the development of drugs to treat withdrawal symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PRPOJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this translational research project are to develop new treatments the target the molecular pathways that cause juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML). This aggressive cancer responds poorly to chemotherapy and is much more common is children with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). In addition to treating JMML patients with targeted inhibitors, we will investigate the molecular mechanisms of response and will seek to validate candidate biomarkers of response and resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)—which affects 1-4% of adults—is a severe mental illness that causes people to eat an insufficient volume or variety of food and puts them at risk for nutritional deficiencies, low weight, psychiatric comorbidity, and suicidality. This multidisciplinary study offers an important opportunity to examine how underlying abnormalities in endocrine signalling and neural circuitry contribute to phenotypic presentations in adults. This innovative project has significant potential to reduce the public health burden of ARFID by informing pathophysiology and identifying mechanistic treatment targets hormonal agonist/antagonist medications and for brain stimulation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the Developmental and Hyperactive Ras Tumor (DHART) SPORE Developmental Research Program (DRP) is to support innovative pilot projects to advance the diagnosis and treatment of early stage tumors and advanced cancers characterized by germline and somatic NF1 mutations. The DRP will accomplish this goal by funding rigorous translational research in the areas of population science, therapeutics, and mechanisms of and by facilitating collaborative interactions between DRP-funded scientists and other SPORE investigators. The translational studies supported by the DRP have the potential to replace SPORE projects that have been completed or are not progressing satisfactorily toward achieving their objectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computed tomographic pulmonary angiograms (CTPA) for pulmonary embolism (PE) are ordered in nearly 2% of all 120 million Emergency Department visits in the United States each year; however, many of these are avoidable. Despite prior research in this area, unnecessary testing remains common and subjects patients to additional costs, ionizing radiation, risk of anaphylaxis from contrast dye, and harms from overdiagnosis and overtreatment. To improve the quality and efficiency of care for patients with suspected PE, this investigation will refine, pilot, and evaluate the acceptability and appropriateness of an empirically-derived multi-dimensional strategy that targets unique barriers to de-implementing low- value imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CAREER ENCHANCEMENT PROGRAM The Developmental and HyperActive Ras Tumor (DHART) SPORE Career Enhancement Program (CEP) supports faculty at the Instructor and Assistant Professor levels to engage in translational research focused on developing treatments for tumors characterized by mutations in NF1. The CEP recruits early stage investigators, with a special emphasis on recruiting underrepresented minority investigators, and provides financial and scientific support (via core expertise and facilities), and structured mentorship from SPORE scientists to accelerate CEP awardee development into independent researchers in the field of cancer biology and therapeutics related to NF1.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is the first to systematically evaluate the efficacy of single and combined academic accommodation, behavioral treatment, and medication treatment in a large sample of children with ADHD. Using a scientifically rigorous, cross-over design the impact of these approaches on ecologically valid measures of outcome (on- task behavior, quiz scores, academic productivity) will be assessed to inform effective school intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The mechanism controlling the time and place where messenger RNA is activated to make proteins is unknown, yet this problem is at the heart of all cell function and at the basis of neurological diseases and cancer. We have devised a variety of technologies to answer this question, using transgenic animals, innovative microscopy and unique mRNA tagging strategies to determine where the critical events occur in the cell. We will use this methodology on neurons, where the local activation of protein synthesis at synapses is at the basis of learning and memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The optimal approach to diuretic therapy in patients hospitalized for acute heart failure (AHF) remains poorly defined and contributes to prolonged inpatient stays, as well as unacceptably high death and readmission rates. We seek to evaluate a targeted diuretic approach guided by urinary sodium measurements, begun shortly after emergency department arrival, and protocolized throughout a patient’s hospitalization. We expect this will hasten and maximize symptom relief, decrease resource utilization and, regardless of results, have a significant impact on clinical care of patients with AHF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a significant public health need for comprehensive lifestyle interventions to address health disparities related to low physical activity levels and unhealthy dietary quality among Latinas (cardiometabolic disease, obesity). Our study proposes a novel, low-cost and high reach web-based multiple-behavior intervention to increase physical activity and promote healthy eating in Latina women. This approach has potential to reduce the disproportionate burden of physical inactivity, poor diet quality and related chronic health conditions among the largest racial and ethnic minority group in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma incidence has been increasing in the past several decades in the United States due to increasing prevalence of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. It is unkown what determines the progression of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease to hepatocellular carcinoma and other end-stage liver disease. The objective of the proposed study is to establish a longitudinal cohort study of patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease with advanced fibrosis in the United States and to prospectively evaluate the modifying role of immunune response factors, bile acids and gut bacteria for the progression of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease with advanced fibrosis to hepatocellular carcinoma and other liver complications. The findings of the proposed study will advance the preventive strategy against the development of hepatocellular carcinoma and end-stage liver disease in high- risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Chloropicrin (CP) and phosgene (PG) are widely available chemical threat agents, yet the mechanisms of in vivo acute toxicity and long-term pathophysiologic impacts are not well understood. To protect the public and devise interventions following exposure we need a better understanding of the inhalation dose relationship to biological response, biomarkers of exposure and understanding on long term sequelae. This research will address these critical data gaps for these two chemicals in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Relevance/Project Narrative Alcohol consumption by adolescents and young adults continues to be a substantive public health concern in the U.S. The hippocampus, one of the most alcohol-sensitive brain regions, is crucial for both memory and affective functioning and we have shown a number of deficits in hippocampal function after adolescent alcohol exposure. This project will identify specific biological mechanisms underlying those effects and assess several treatments that may prevent or reverse those effects on brain and behavioral function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The growing availability of endophenotypic data in cohort studies of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) provides an exciting opportunity to further characterize the genetic architecture of this devastating disease. However, there is a pressing need to develop and apply advanced harmonization approaches to align AD-related endophenotypes across cohorts. The goal of this coordinated national initiative – the AD Sequencing Project Phenotype Harmonization Consortium, or “ADSP-PHC” - is to provide a centralized database of robust endophenotypes for large-scale genomic analyses that will accelerate the identification of novel targets for therapeutic intervention in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substantial evidence has suggested that vascular networks are critical in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and the change in cerebral blood flow is one of the earliest indicators of the disease. However, current studies in living human brain are limited to large vessels while leaving the microvasculature unexplored. This study proposes to establish a novel optical microscopy technique to map the comprehensive microvascular architecture network in human AD brains, which builds up the foundations to unravel the biophysical changes in brain function during the disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a pressing need for new, scalable approaches to address patient heterogeneity in diseases such as ALS and identify patient-specific or broadly-effective therapeutics for multiple forms of ALS, particularly those with unknown genetic etiologies. The proposed study will combine ALS iPSC models with a novel platform we developed for cancer therapeutics that uses single cell transcriptomics to assess drug effects on 10-50 patient lines in one dish. We anticipate that this study will establish this new platform and address the critical barrier of patient heterogeneity in ALS drug discovery, evaluate 3 newly discovered therapeutic targets with novel mechanisms of action on a large cohort of patient lines, determine if this model system can predict efficacy in vivo, and identify new targets through a genome-wide screen on multiple patient lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: LAGIER-TOURENNE WARD BLAINEY – NARRATIVE Disruption of the natural splicing process that stiches together different parts of a gene to form proteins necessary for healthy function has emerged as a key mechanism leading to neurodegeneration in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and dementia. In this effort, three labs will collaborate to apply new genomic technologies that make it feasible for the first time to comprehensively track the abnormal splicing events occurring in disease and to identify genetic modulators that correct this process and may represent new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Radiation therapy delivered at ultra-high radiation dose rates, which are more than 100 times faster than traditional radiation therapy delivery methods, has been postulated to produce a FLASH effect of similar tumor responses but with less toxicity to healthy tissue. However, not all preclinical studies testing ultra-high dose rates have reported consistent FLASH effects and no optimization has yet been performed to maximize the normal tissue sparing after FLASH compared to conventional irradiation. Therefore, the proposed study will analyze the FLASH effect using different types of radiation modalities, optimize parameters for delivery, and more precisely measure tumor curability, enabling consistent translation of this method of radiation therapy delivery to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE Natural products (NPs) have been a prolific source of small molecule drugs, but their discovery is currently hindered by repeated rediscovery of the same or similar compounds. The goal of the proposed research is to leverage big-data analysis and thorough biosynthetic investigations to produce new NPs from hundreds of thousands of untapped microbial biosynthetic gene clusters and thus significantly increase the chemical diversity of NPs. In doing so, we aim to reinvigorate the field of NP-based drug discovery which is well aligned with the mission of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences by laying the foundation to discover novel drug leads to address new and rising public health needs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this study we propose to contribute to the national ECHO Program by recruiting a diverse cohort of pregnant individuals from two medical centers at Kaiser Permanente Northern California serving a diverse population (~70% racial/ethnic minority groups with 50% having a low income), the conceiving partner, their resulting child, and to follow all of them at multiple visits after the child is born. Individuals who have a second pregnancy during the study period, the conceiving partner and child, will be recruited for a preconception pilot study. We will investigate the impact of maternal prenatal psychological distress, substance use, and lifestyle factors (diet and 24-hour movement) on child obesity and neurodevelopment and identify potential mechanisms and factors that may moderate adverse effects. Findings from this study will have important implications for informing interventions, prevention strategies and policies to ensure optimal health and well- being for all children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will undertake discovery of protein blood biomarkers for the early detection of ovarian cancer using serial plasma samples from the PLCO biorepository in ovarian cancer cases and controls. Combined with a new technology that measures ~1,500 proteins in a small biological sample, and statistical modeling of longitudinal results, this project will have an excellent chance of identifying biomarkers that rise over time in a substantial fraction of ovarian cancer cases while remaining stable in most controls. Early detection of ovarian cancer may decrease mortality from ovarian cancer due to the much greater survival when detected in early stages.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE An ECHO Pregnancy Cohort site in Charleston, South Carolina, will fill a critically important recruitment gap with a diverse, rural population from the Deep South. Pregnancy and preconception studies of environmental exposures that extend through childhood are critically needed to understand the link between gestational and early life exposures and their association with health and disease in children and adults. Including geographic, racial, and ethnic diversity in ECHO will strengthen the national cohort and broaden its scope.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Mouse models spanning different ages and sexes are routinely used to quantify anatomic, molecular, and pathologic changes in neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), yet, the scientific community lacks sexually differentiated rodent brain atlases of different ages that are necessary to accurately study these attributes. By applying the most advanced technologies available, we will (1) generate publicly available, sexually dimorphic 3D hippocampal aging and AD brain atlases to be used as standard atlas templates for all aging and AD research and (2) we will comprehensively characterize morphological dystrophies, as well as connectional and synaptic disruptions, across aging and AD. Our team, with decades of experience in connectomics and brain atlasing, is sure to deliver standard hippocampal atlas templates for all neuroscience research and to determine sexually dimorphic anatomic regions vulnerable across age and AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sjögren’s Disease (SjD, previously known as Sjögren’s syndrome) is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes significant morbidity and predominantly affects women. While previous research has demonstrated that vitamin D deficiency is a known risk factor for several autoimmune conditions, the role of vitamin D in SjD is understudied. The objective of this F31 fellowship application is to identify and characterize vitamin D binding sites that are associated with SjD susceptibility, onset, and severity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to evaluate changes in treatment (e.g., national guideline-recommended antiretroviral therapy), quality of care, and health outcomes (e.g., healthy days at home, mortality) among an increasingly older population living with HIV (PWH) in the Medicare program. Importantly, the proposed research will also identify the patient-, drug plan-, market-, and community-level factors associated with higher quality of care and improved clinical outcomes among a national, longitudinal cohort of older PWH with age- associated comorbidities (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), cardiovascular disease, and mental illness) and of historically marginalized subpopulations with HIV. Finally, this work will be the first national study to evaluate the impact of Medicare value-based alternative payment models (APMs) on older PWH, including Accountable Care Organizations and Bundled Payment Models, which can help inform national public health and policy efforts aimed at improving care for PWH, including consideration of specific policy modifications and carve-outs for PWH under APMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many children have developmental language disorder, which makes it difficult to learn language, including vocabulary, and results in ongoing academic and social difficulties. Despite the fact that most words are learned in context without direct teaching, we know very little about how children with developmental language disorder learn words in context. This project will combine, for the first time, two strategies which improve contextual word learning in children with typical development, and test their effect in both typically developing children, and those with developmental language disorder. The results will provide timely information that will contribute to evidence based practice for contextual word learning in children with developmental language disorder.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE While it is well-established that severe RSV infection is associated with later childhood asthma, delineating the severity- and age-dependent relationship of RSV infection on asthma risk and lung function is not known and is the focus of this application. The answers to these questions will be critical to developing prevention strategies and informing public health expectations for RSV non-pharmaceutical preventive strategies and evaluating potential long-term value-added benefits of vaccines in preventing lifelong chronic respiratory disease. These data may not only bolster RSV vaccine acceptability and uptake in the US but will almost certainly be useful in evaluating the cost-effectiveness of RSV prevention strategies in low and middle income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop an efficient means of detecting early stages of a lung blood vessel disease called pulmonary arterial hypertension. Such a tool would reduce the number of tests doctors must order to detect the disease in patients and could be used to estimate how common the disease is in a community. During this study we will collect clinical data, ultrasound images, and blood samples in order to determine how patients develop and can be diagnosed with this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Initiation of cannabis use usually occurs during adolescence, which represents a vulnerable period in neurobiological development. The proposed research is designed to elucidate how chronic cannabinoid use during adolescence produces neural plasticity- that is changes in brain structure and function- related to short- and long-term behavioral adaptations exemplified by withdrawal and relapse-like behavior. Identifying these important adaptations may inform the development of novel therapies for cannabis use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline and sporadic loss of function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene, NF1, drives a subset of breast cancer with increased metastatic potential, endocrine resistance, and dismal outcomes in disease. Here, I propose to study the mechanisms in which loss of neurofibromin-ERα interaction contributes to this aggressive subtype of breast cancers in order to identify tractable therapeutic options while receiving new training in next generation sequencing and analysis along with comprehensive analysis of cancer datasets. In the next phase of my career I will build upon this foundation of knowledge to expand my discoveries in identifying novel functions of NF1 and its role in cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The rising incidence and decreasing mortality from acute respiratory failure (ARF) is leading to increasing numbers of ARF survivors who experience significant health impairments and increased healthcare utilization. Efforts to improve the long-term outcomes for ARF patients are hindered by the absence of a patient-centered and statistically efficient endpoint that is practical to measure in large cohorts and appropriate for assessing interventions with either palliative or restorative intents. This proposal aims to design and evaluate a method to quality-weight hospital-free days using patient-reported assessments of quality of life, function, or caregiver burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Research into tissue repair holds tremendous impact to human health because improper repair after injury can lead to chronic wounds, severe complications, and even death. Tissue repair requires the coordination of many cell types, and recent advances show that many of these cells accumulate potentially oncogenic mutations that may affect the overall repair process and lead to cancer. We use novel microscopy approaches to study how these mutations affect wound repair, with therapeutic implications for both chronic wounds and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Trypanosoma cruzi is the etiological agent of Chagas disease, an illness affecting 6-7 million people worldwide, for which very few treatment options are available. Protein phosphorylation plays several key biological roles in the complex life cycle of the parasite, and protein kinases are known druggable targets in different eukaryotic pathogens. Here we propose to perform a barcode multigene-gene knockout screening in T. cruzi to identify essential protein kinases in the progression of the parasite’s life cycle.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how physical and mental health during pregnancy can help predict cardiovascular disease and mental health disorders in later adulthood is essential to women’s health. The specific objective of the proposed research is to examine the association of pregnancy complications and prenatal mental health with subsequent cardiometabolic profile and mental health in middle adulthood among Hispanics of Puerto Rican heritage living in the continental US, the Hispanic subgroup with the highest prevalence of diabetes, obesity, and major cardiometabolic risk factors. Study outcomes will inform culturally sensitive prenatal interventions for early life prevention of future chronic disorders in an understudied and particularly vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunction of the immune system has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several age-related lung diseases, including pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and pulmonary fibrosis, suggesting that reversing or delaying age-related immune dysfunction may be an effective strategy for treating these diseases as a group. Our preliminary data supports a role for increases in inflammatory signaling within structural cells of the lung as a cause of aging-associated immune system dysfunction. The aim of this proposal is to understand how this inflammatory signaling induces immune system dysfunction, with the ultimate goal of identifying new potential therapeutic targets to treat age-related lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Drinking to relieve stress is among the most robust predictors of later onset of alcohol use disorder (AUD), but prior experimental studies have often failed to capture alcohol’s ability to boost mood in the face of stress. The current study is unique in that it looks to real-life drinking contexts to identify stressors capable of harnessing alcohol’s powerful stress-relieving capabilities. By examining “real life” stressful contexts, the current study could have a number of important conceptual and clinical implications, including for understanding mechanisms underlying AUD vulnerability, identifying individuals at risk for AUD, improving reinforcement- centered harm reduction and prevention focused interventions, and refining the understanding of “high risk” relapse settings for those in treatment. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it thoroughly tests how perturbations in cardiac mitochondrial Ca2+ impact the heart’s ability to produce energy and pump. By establishing the effects of cardiac mitochondrial Ca2+ increase and decrease on mitochondrial and organismal function in homeostasis, the proposed work represents a conceptual advance towards the NIH’s goal to gain fundamental knowledge of living systems. Furthermore, testing the effects of mitochondrial Ca2+ increase and decrease in two distinct mouse models of heart failure, and discerning when elevated or reduced Ca2+ is deleterious or beneficial, paves the way for significant progress in the NIH’s mission to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell immunotherapy mediating impressive response rates in B cell malignancies, fewer than 50% of patients experience long-term disease control. Elucidating T cell phenotype- function relationships is critical to informing future CAR T cell therapy design and cancer treatment. Toward that end, this study will characterize senescence in the context of CAR T cells, delineating the molecular roles of telomerase in T cells and identifying senescent markers correlated with patient features and treatment response on CAR T cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Osteoporosis is a major public health problem, and orally-available treatments that stimulate bone formation are lacking. We have identified a new pathway that promotes bone formation. Here, we will define how this bone building pathway interacts with other hormones, and develop this novel approach to treat osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elderly people are more susceptible to respiratory tract infections. Pulmonary macrophages are among the first cell types to respond to all the environmental exposures (e.g., air pollution) and functional discrepancies in this innate immune cell subset can increase the severity of diseases such as influenza due to aggravated inflammation; however, age-associated changes in pulmonary macrophages that are under constant influence of the environment exposures is not well studied. This proposal is designed to investigate the hypothesis that atmospheric particulate matter is contained within the macrophages and due to these particulates, aging pulmonary macrophages have altered transcriptional profile with compromised respiratory immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Recently discharged psychiatric inpatients who misuse alcohol are at high risk for suicide. The proposed project involves the development of a novel intervention that would enhance care for these individuals by pairing inpatient-based emotion regulation skills training with a mobile health application that extends this treatment into the post-discharge period. Through acquisition and eventual utilization of emotion regulation skills to replace maladaptive, stress-induced emotion-driven behaviors (e.g., heavy drinking, suicide attempts), this approach could reduce post-discharge risk for a suicide crisis and costly rehospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE We will renew, continue and expand our effort to describe, understand, intervene on, and mitigate the Alzheimer’s disease health disparities experienced by American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders by studying mid- and late-life resilience and risk factors. We will achieve this goal by funding social and behavioral Pilot Studies that advance the field, emphasizing the recruitment and mentorship of Native junior and mid-level researchers. These trainees will receive training on methods and analyses so that their work meets high scientific standards, while being culturally appropriate. This work will advance Alzheimer’s disease research and increase the number of independent investigators focused on Alzheimer’s disease disparities experienced by our target populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are a leading cause of morbidity and premature death, and it is crucial to enhance preventive efforts. High blood levels of branched-chain amino acids can have adverse effects on CVD risk, but it remains unclear whether diet, physical activity, and weight loss can substantially lower their levels. Findings from this project can inform personalized lifestyle recommendations for CVD prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop new computational models and tools for the discovery and optimization of synthetic processes harnessing organic radical intermediates. Control over the generation, reactivity, and enantioselectivity of triplet diradicals will be studied, and general predictive models for the site selectivities of homolytic substitutions will be developed and validated. Conceptual advances will be harnessed to create a practical and broadly applicable computational platform for (i) developing radical strategies for the preparation of new drug candidates and (ii) predicting small molecules’ metabolic stabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Patients with Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis (EGE) suffer for years without a diagnosis or adequate therapy due to lack of understanding of risks and markers for disease. Identification of immune markers reflecting immune underpinnings and phenotypes of disease will improve the identification, comprehension, and diagnosis of the disease. Furthermore, recognition of familial risks for EGE will aid clinicians in their diagnostic path, empowering them to diagnose disease early on, and treat adequately, avoiding increased medical costs and complications of disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: This application leverages the national ECHO Cohort dataset to examine risk and protective factors for children’s mental health problems and obesity, with a focus on understanding sex-specific associations, identification of prevention and intervention targets, and generalization of findings to communities of color. We also propose to retain the socioeconomically and racially diverse CANDLE sample in the ECHO Program, reconsenting participants into the new ECHO Protocol and collecting high-quality, complete data from the urban South. Our team brings a strong record of consortium leadership and partnerships across the ECHO Cores and Cohorts, which we will continue in the next phase of the ECHO Program to advance collaborative science and improve the health and well-being of all children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persistent racial and ethnic disparities in colorectal cancer (CRC) mortality remain a public health concern. Focusing on survival, this project will identify novel biomarkers and create a prognostic index that suggests therapeutic targets and more precise patient stratification for personalized treatments, with the potential to improve outcomes in CRC patients that may particularly benefit those racial and ethnic groups with high CRC mortality. This research will provide me with cutting-edge cross-disciplinary research experience in the rapidly growing field of integrative tumor epidemiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment with buprenorphine is effective and is typically initiated in an office-based setting, however the process of starting buprenorphine is increasingly complicated by precipitated withdrawal for individuals using fentanyl. Withdrawal during buprenorphine initiation reduces interest in treatment and increases the risk of drop-out and relapse. This project proposes to test a novel approach to initiating buprenorphine that can be completed in 10 hours in outpatient settings without requiring or precipitating opioid withdrawal.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Atopic conditions (atopic dermatitis (AD), food allergy, asthma and allergic rhinitis) pose a significant social and financial burden to children and families; however, the fundamental descriptive epidemiology trends for severe atopic multimorbidity or SAAM (AD, food allergy, asthma with or without allergic rhinitis) are unknown for US children, and current clinical practice lacks an early biomarker to identify infants at risk. In conjunction with ECHO-wide committee and working group participation, proposal submissions, and manuscripts, this project will assess incidence rates of SAMM to target populations at risk and use placental DNA methylation to identify potential biomarkers linking social and environmental conditions to disease outcomes. The proposed investigations and scientific collaborations across ECHO will more precisely identify children at risk for multiple atopic co-morbidities which is an important first step in preventing childhood atopic disease co-morbidity and improving the health of children across the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrinolysis is a key regulator of bleeding severity, and long-lasting knockdown of plasminogen using gene therapy tools has the potential to mitigate fibrinolysis, blood loss, and re-bleeding in early stages of hemorrhage, thus decreasing morbidity and mortality. The RNA therapeutics developed in this study to knock down plasminogen will (1) elucidate the role of fibrinolysis at the onset of acute bleeding, which will answer a fundamental mechanistic question in the biochemistry of hemostasis; and (2) provide proof-of-concept in small and large animal models that siRNA targeting plasminogen can be used to manage bleeding in a wide variety of genetic and acquired bleeding disorders. The results will enable development of these RNA therapeutics into novel “universal” therapeutics that could overcome the limitations of current antifibrinolytic strategies to treat many types of diagnosed and undiagnosed bleeding disorders, thus improving the quality of life for the nearly one million Americans suffering from bleeding disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Current control strategies for mosquito-borne pathogens largely rely on reducing mosquito vector populations using insecticides but this approach is becoming less effective as insecticide resistance develops against many mosquito adulticides and larvicides. We have developed novel pH responsive compounds capable of delivering a range of toxic payloads to the larval gut and its unique high pH conditions. This provides an opportunity to develop highly specific larvicides with minimal effects on non-target organisms and the flexibility to switch toxic compounds if resistance develops.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the known association between hypercoagulability and sickle cell disease (SCD), venous thromboembolism (VTE) has remained an understudied complication of pediatric SCD, leading to a scarcity of data on VTE outcomes and hindering the optimal management of VTE in children with SCD. This project aims to elucidate clinical and molecular risk factors for incident and recurrent VTE among children with SCD, and to apply these findings to the development of prognostic models for VTE in this population, by means of a multicenter prospective-retrospective cohort study with parallel biospecimen banking. The aims of this study align with the NIH research priorities in SCD by providing critical knowledge to better predict long-term outcomes in this population, implementing the use of biomarkers as means of identifying patients with SCD at high risk for adverse clinical events, and providing much-needed scientific evidence to guide effective management strategies aimed at reducing adverse VTE outcomes in children with SCD and VTE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) can lead to severe neurological dysfunction when infection spreads to the CNS (CNS-TB) and is the cause of significant neurological complications around the world. Here we will use single cell and single nuclei RNA-sequencing of human brain and CSF samples from patients with CNS-TB, along with a spectrum of rodent models that represent different severities of CNS-TB, to determine how different cell types contribute to human CNS-TB. We will work to build single cell/single nuclei RNA-seq research capacity at the University of Cape Town by developing research infrastructure in South Africa and facilitating skills transfer through a structured training and skills development program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Inflammatory Bowel Disease is a debilitating disease without a cure, a serious unmet need. The inflammatory protein, eNAMPT (extracellular nicotinamide phosphoribosyltransferase), is a key driver of unchecked inflammation and a highly novel therapeutic target and candidate gene in IBD. Our Phase I/II goals are to validate and optimize the eNAMPT- neutralizing humanized mAb, ALT-100, as a therapeutic strategy for IBD, and to complete IND-enabling studies that will facilitate ALT-100 development in human IBD trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The gut houses billions of resident microbes, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi that actively support human health; however, when unbalanced, these microbes can activate various immune responses that cause disease or increase disease severity, such as cancer, autoimmunity and infection. This proposal seeks to examine how gut microbes impact health and disease through immune cell activation and immune structure formation. Understanding the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota support these immune structures during disease will contribute greatly to our ability to treat patients with chronic difficult to treat diseases, including cancer, autoimmunity, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hyperkalemia (a high potassium level in the blood) is a frequent electrolyte abnormality and is associated with an increased risk of death. The kidney is the primary organ for excretion of potassium from the body, but currently only the kidney's ability to filter potassium from the blood is measured; however, the secretion of potassium, which is an important mechanism for potassium elimination, is not measured. This proposal will measure novel biomarkers that reflect kidney tubule secretion and determine their association with the risk of developing hyperkalemia in a cohort of heart failure patients from the NHLBI sponsored TOPCAT study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Using 3 mouse models of MDS, patient cells and iPSC models of age-related clonal hematopoiesis (ARCH) we identify a transcriptional signature comprising Nucleoporin (NUPs) family members as highly associated with MDS induction and disease transformation in patients and disease inducing in mice and human models. Our goal in is to comprehensively examine the role of the NUP pathway in the induction of MDS from aging related factors of ARCH and inflammation and identify the mechanisms of their actions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: For the second phase of the Environmental Influences on Child Health Outcomes (ECHO-II) consortium, the Columbia Center for Children’s Environmental Health (CCCEH) proposes to use ECHO-wide core data elements and specialized protocols to determine how prenatal exposure patterns contribute to asthma and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder comorbidity. CCCEH also plans to implement the ECHO Cohort Protocol with high fidelity and proposes a plan for enhancing diverse perspectives that will be implemented while conducting all scientific aims. This proposal intends to contribute fundamental knowledge pertaining to two burdensome childhood diseases to fill current research gaps that, in turn, should help raise risk-awareness, increase referrals for assessment of comorbid disorders, and allow for earlier intervention.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Many youth are burdened with attention deficits, inattention, hyperactivity, anxiety or depressive mood, and these conditions can have long term serious consequences that impair their ability to succeed in school, obtain and keep productive jobs, get along with their peers, or find happiness. This project seeks to understand and identify some early childhood exposures, behaviors, or experiences that may increase risks for those problems, and ones that may help them avoid these issues. The public health importance of the proposed project is that finding out what changes a child’s risks or improves their outcomes can help public health agencies to design interventions to help children before the problems become severe or even before they know they are affected by these conditions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We plan to recruit at least 2500 pregnant people, their partners, and offspring from the University of Pennsylvania and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia as part of the nationwide ECHO Cohort to understand the role of early exposures on child health outcomes and identify ways to reduce disparities. The health system at Penn and CHOP serves a diverse population underrepresented in other pregnancy and pediatric cohorts in the US (largely Medicaid-insured and plurality Black).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE LATE-NC (limbic-predominant age-related transactive response DNA-binding protein of 43 kDa [TDP-43] encephalopathy neuropathological change) is the third most impactful cause of dementia, but we cannot yet diagnose, treat, or prevent LATE-NC in living persons. This project seeks to define molecular and cellular signatures of LATE-NC by detailed profiling of hundreds of human brain samples, and to generate a comprehensive roadmap for model system development, diagnostic biomarker discovery, and therapeutic target identification. As LATE-NC is a common and pernicious brain disease that primarily affects the oldest old, the most rapidly growing segment of the population in the United States, this project has the potential to have an enormous public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Climate change is increasing the disproportionate environmental and public health impacts of disasters on marginalized communities, demanding action to address existing gaps in environmental and public health disaster research training in graduate and continuing education, and to create pathways to increase representation of trained underrepresented minority (URM) scholars. In response, the University of Washington will develop a short course, Increasing Diversity in and Equitable Access to Applied Learning in Disaster Research Response: IDEAAL DR2, led by faculty with expertise and experience conducting interdisciplinary health-related disaster research to provide such training to up to 100 scholars. We will partner with the William Averette Anderson Fund (BAF), the premiere non-profit organization dedicated to diversifying the fields of disaster and hazard research and practice, to create an inclusive recruitment strategy and provide targeted advising and financial support to URM scholars and advisors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: It is critical to use a clinically-relevant model and to take a multi-system approach when developing drugs to treat the pathologies associated with genetic ion channelopathies of the brain and heart. In people, KCNH2 variants are linked to a high risk of epilepsy, sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP), arrhythmias, and Long QT Syndrome Type 2 (LQT2). As there are no established anti-seizure medications for LQT2 patients with epilepsy, we will demonstrate that our new translational model of Kcnh2-mediated epilepsy, SUDEP, and LQT2 will facilitate future neurotherapeutic discovery and testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We initiate a crucial research direction for understanding structural mechanisms of phosphatase diseases caused by mutations in PP2A. The proposed study will illuminate unprecedented super-long dynamics in PP2A regulation and disease mutations that perturb the global allosteric network near or at the super-long dynamic interface, providing general insights into the regulatory roles of disordered human proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This study is relevant to health of individuals at risk for atherosclerotic carotid plaque formation and are pre-disposed to chronic stigma/discrimination stress based upon the intersection of their HIV, gender, racial/ethnic, and sexual minoritized status. A multidisciplinary research team will compare the magnitude of response to social rejection and discrimination focusing on key neural, immune, and cardio- autonomic pathways in real-time using functional magnetic resonance imaging and ecological momentary assessment to further knowledge of underlying biobehavioral mechanisms for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently found two forms of cytosolic DNAs, SINE RTE DNA and mitochondrial DNA, contribute to death of the retinal cells in an aging-related disease in humans. By investigating the mechanisms by which these two cytosolic DNAs synergistically collaborate to promote aging and compromise retinal function, we will develop new knowledge that could provide new medically relevant knowledge for reducing the ill effects of aging and improving healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Widespread azole resistance among Candida and Aspergillus spp. along with emerging echinocandin resistance in C. glabrata and C. auris raises the specter of untreatable multidrug resistant fungal infections, even as advances in medicine (cancer chemotherapy, organ transplant, premature infants, HIV/AIDS therapy) have increased the size of the vulnerable population. In October 2022, the World Health Organization (WHO) published a report on the first global effort to prioritize fungal pathogens (WHO Fungal Priority Pathogens List), and Candida and Aspergillus species were placed in the most critical priority group, highlighting the need to develop mechanistically novel antifungal agents against these pathogens. This project aims to develop a novel therapeutic to treat life-threatening fungal infections due to drug resistant Candida and Aspergillus with no cross resistance to existing agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subretinal fibrosis underlies the end-stage pathogenesis of several retinal diseases including age- related macular degeneration (AMD) and proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR). The cellular and molecular mechanism of subretinal fibrosis is still unclear, and the clinical treatment for this condition is very limited. The proposal will define the function, identity, and origin of myofibroblasts in subretinal fibrosis; and determine the therapeutic potential of miR-24 in subretinal fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The proposed research investigates how genomic polymorphisms of TNFRSF13B predict and potentially govern the character and outcome transplantation immunity in humans. We will determine whether allelic TNFRSF13B variants of known phenotype engender donor-specific B cell responses to organ allografts and the association of those responses with transplant outcome. The functional properties of the most important TNFRSF13B alleles will be confirmed and the mechanism ascertained by engineered tnfrsf13B mutations in mice and testing such mice as recipients of heterotopic cardiac allografts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms of residual cell survival following initial therapy, one of the leading causes of cancer recurrence, remain under-studied, in part due to the scarcity of tools and models to faithfully study the evolutionary dynamics of residual disease. My doctoral work will focus on designing novel imaging methodologies to visualize spatiotemporal metabolic and vascular heterogeneities during residual disease and recurrence in vivo while my postdoctoral work will focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms that drive recurrence using faithful PDX models of triple negative breast cancer to identify actionable metabolic and vascular targets. This synergistic approach will provide a holistic understanding of the behaviors of residual tumors, guiding the development of targeted therapies aimed at eradicating residual disease to reduce or delay recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Before a newly budded HIV-1 particle becomes fusogenic (and infective) it must undergo maturation. During maturation the contents of the virion transform from a spherical shell into a conical structure after a series of cleavages of the 55 kDa Gag polyprotein by the viral protease. Here, we propose to utilize full-scale molecular dynamics simulations, integrating shaped-based coarse-grained and atomistic methods, to determine motion- structures that reveal the mechanistic details of HIV-1 virion maturation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD) disproportionately impact Hispanic Americans, who represent the fastest-growing segment of the elderly population in the US and particularly in Texas, but this ethnic group is severely underrepresented both in research study participants and in the research workforce. To overcome these deleterious shortfalls, the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) AD/ADRD-RCMAR will build upon longstanding strengths in social and behavioral science at UTRGV (located in the impoverished and 90% Mexican American-populated US/Mexico border region) and facilitated by a partnership with the South Texas AD Research Center, will continue to lead and coordinate efforts in South Texas to enhance the diversity and capacities of the workforce of minority aging research. This effort will catalyze increased research participation by Hispanic Americans and develop a robust infrastructure and data collections for high-impact research aimed at reducing the impacts of AD/ADRD on Hispanic Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) is a common condition that places patients at risk for life- threatening hemorrhage, and can be caused by low levels of the sugar molecule sialic acid on the platelet surface. The aim of this proposal is to define where and how sialic acid is removed from the surface of platelets. This work will illuminate fundamental aspects of platelet biology and will pave the way for development of effective therapies for thrombocytopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  Imidacloprid is a small and relatively water-soluble pesticide with high likelihood of environmental accumulation and chronic exposure of non-target species such as humans. The proposed research project will investigate the mechanisms of toxicity and detoxification of imidacloprid in immature and mature mammalian ovaries as well as characterize novel drug targets within the ovaries such as metabolic enzymes and acetylcholine receptors. The public health outcomes of this work include identification of possible reproductive toxicants and development of methods to prevent or treat pesticide-induced reproductive problems.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative - While postpartum rooming-in has become the new standard-of-care, the ongoing use of bassinets designed for use by ambulatory nursery staff has resulted in risk of infant drops/falls and maternal frustration, as the difficulty of accessing infants has led mothers to either experience significant pain or injury during infant transfer or rely on nurses/others for assistance with non-medical needs. The iatrogenic obstacles conveyed by existing bassinets can contribute to newborns being on maternity beds or held on chairs while the adult is asleep, instead of being in the secure sleeping environment of the bassinet, increasing the risk of drops or suffocation events. Addressing these issues, Couplet Care is developing a novel bassinet that is heigh-adjustable and can be positioned over the hospital bed, facilitating access to the infant and promoting safe mother-infant bonding and care during rooming-in, while also reducing demands on nurses who may already be short-staffed.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Autism spectrum disorders have complex etiologies, involving both genetic and in utero environmental factors. A novel gene locus was identified from placental samples collected prior to the diagnosis of autism, called NHIP (neuronal hypoxia inducible, placenta associated). To understand why NHIP levels were lower in autism brain and placenta, this study will identify the molecular functions and regulators of NHIP and test its efficacy in protecting embryonic neurons from oxidative stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: As metabolism is at the core of physiology, metabolomics and proteomics are the ideal platforms to characterize an integrated view of failures in arginine metabolism in people who develop delirium following elective surgery. Of these patients, ~17% are at greater risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease or one of its related dementias (ADRD), equating to ~170k people in the US in 2018. Such information could provide totally novel insights about disease mechanisms and progression, providing a biochemical roadmap for novel treatment development. Further, we aim to develop and fully validate a CSF based test to predict those people at greatest risk of developing delirium and subsequently ADRD. In this application, we enrich our efforts by bringing together world experts in metabolomics, delirium, and molecular modelling to build an atlas for aberrant arginine metabolism in delirium sufferers while developing predictive tests for those at greatest risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement This project will investigate the mechanism of collagen fibril degradation by matrix metalloproteases (MMPs). Collagen degradation plays an essential role in tissue remodeling and cell invasion and underlies many diseases, including numerous skin diseases, cancer metastasis, wound, inflammation, pneumonia, and atherosclerosis. Understanding the mechanism of degradation can significantly impact public health by identifying better therapeutic targets and strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Conceptual significance: Results of this research are expected to have high impact on our understanding of mechanisms of  processing and coding of salient stimuli along sensory pathways. The proposed research project aims to test fundamental qualitative  changes in coding frameworks of auditory and visual pathways and investigate underlying processing and information flow mediating  these changes, a novel and promising research that could explain how salience of sensory inputs is processed and encoded in the  brain, which is fundamental to how we perceive and interact with the world around us.  Technical significance: The proposed action uses innovative multielectrode recording techniques in awake and behaving animals to  understand flow of information and coding of salient stimuli from midbrain to forebrain audiovisual regions. In addition, it will implement  and interdisciplinary approach, combining recording of neuronal population responses and computational modeling of coding and  processing schemes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal involves developing techniques for measuring the energetics of G-protein coupled receptors in an atomic force microscopy assay without chemical denaturant. The techniques will be applied to arginine vasopressin receptor 2, informing the molecular origins of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. More generally, development of these techniques will establish a paradigm in which energetic measurements may be made directly on biomedically relevant systems, rather than model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a great unmet need to improve success rate in drug discovery for psychiatric disorders due to the high rate of failure. Given the need to address poly pharmacology and create truly novel chemistry for complex CNS disorders, PsychoGenics Inc. and Collaborations Pharma Inc. are joining forces to develop a novel machine learning-based drug discovery platform that can design novel compounds and predict their phenotypic therapeutic potential to guide the early stages of target-agnostic unbiased CNS drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The multifarious needs of ADRD caregivers often remain unaddressed, and the utilization rate of supportive services remains strikingly low, with many caregivers uncertain about what services may be right for them, what exists, and how to access them. There is a need for a robust, reliable tool that comprehensively evaluates ADRD caregiver needs with a mechanism to connect needs with existing services, thereby overcoming barriers that ADRD caregivers face in accessing needed supportive care. The proposed project seeks to iteratively develop and test an online self-assessment and tailored referral platform, grounded in machine learning principles and informed by stakeholder perspectives, to address needs and enhance knowledge and use of relevant services, with the overall goal of linking ADRD caregivers with relevant support and thereby promoting their mental health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Millions of patients undergo procedures requiring general anesthetics – drugs whose effects on the brain remain poorly understood despite continuous use for over a century. This innovative proposal combines whole brain imaging at cellular resolution with cutting edge techniques for monitoring and modulating brain activity to ultimately identify the neurons and circuits responsible for the establishment of anesthetic-induced unconsciousness. Such detailed understanding of the unconscious state is a necessary pre-requisite for improving upon existing anesthetics and will reveal the fundamental mechanisms that control the level of consciousness in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The development of omics technologies and the use of the most advanced data sciences has transformed every biomedical field and provides a limitless potential to understand biological processes and develop new treatments for human diseases. However, designing, executing, and analyzing data generated by these technologies requires significant expertise, notably missing in junior investigators. The education program described in this proposal is designed to train a new generation of diverse biomedical investigators and provide them with skills, knowledge, mentoring, professional skills, and networking to foster their pathways to independence using omics and data sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Community water fluoridation may affect perinatal health outcomes, but this has never been evaluated in the United States. It is critical to understand how this widespread practice affects the health of mothers and infants, and whether subgroups of the population are uniquely vulnerable. This project will provide critical information to assist public health officials in making informed decisions about the ongoing practice of adding fluoride to water supplies in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Nr4A sub-family of transcription factors are critical for consolidation of long-term memory and have been linked to diseases associated with deficits in this process, such as Alzheimer's disease. In the current project, the mechanisms underlying the regulation of memory by Nr4A transcription factors will be investigated using single cell transcriptional signatures, behavioral and proteomic approaches to uncover the gene expression patterns that regulate native protein folding, an essential process for memory formation. Findings from these studies are expected to form the basis for future work that identifies therapeutic targets to treat memory impairments associated with aging and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sjögren’s syndrome (SS) is a complex autoimmune disorder, affects 2-3.1 million Americans, involves dysfunction of moisture-producing glands that is mediated by immune responses, and can result in irreversible tissue damage and serious complications such as neurological problems, lung disease and cancer. This project involves a large international group of SS experts collaborating to identify and characterize genetic risk factors that alter the function of various cell types in salivary glands and the immune system. This new knowledge is critical for identifying effective ways to subset patients based on different causes of SS, developing better clinical tools to diagnose patients earlier before tissue damage occurs, identifying patients at high risk for lymphoma and other poor outcomes, and helping to establish the feasibility of novel candidate therapies and repurposing existing drugs that may be effective in SS but have not yet been considered for clinical trials. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKIs) can be life-saving therapies for many patients suffering from cancer. Unfortunately untoward cardiovascular side-effects are common and can lead to cessation of a life-saving therapy. This proposal is motivated by our hypothesis that TKI-induced arrhythmia acts in part through oxidative activation of CaMKII and increased INa,L in cardiac myocytes leading to cardiac excitability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will combine olfactory psychophysics, behavioral tasks, neuroimaging, and non- invasive brain stimulation to examine neural principles of olfactory reward in the human brain. The proposed studies will be important for revealing neural correlates and the causal contributions of brain networks to learning and decision making involving food odors. The expected findings may have clinical relevance for neuropsychiatric diseases that are characterized by impaired learning and decision making.

PHR: Narrative Kidney repair is a key determinant of the outcome or prognosis of AKI survivors. This project will investigate DNA methylation in kidney repair after AKI. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older, Black adults (age ≥ 60 years) do not tend to engage in the recommended levels of physical activity and are less active than younger, White adults. This lack of PA is associated with increased risk of all-cause mortality. This proposal seeks to optimize the Fit and Strong! program, or a physical activity intervention for older adults, by creating an adjunct, online platform that is capable of syncing with wearable devices (e.g., fitbit). We will partner with the Black Ministerial Alliance to examine the feasibility, acceptability and explore the efficacy and sustainability of this adjunct, online platform in Black churches. This project addresses the critical need of enhancing physical activity in older, especially Black, adults and could have a substantial public health benefit if gains are maintained through the follow-up phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on identifying how TRIM29 promotes bladder cancer invasive progression and metastasis. This information is likely to identify biomarkers which may allow early detection of invasive/metastatic potential and novel therapeutic targets, both areas of unmet need in the bladder cancer field. This proposal is directly responsive to the NCI mission and specifically responsive to FOA: PAR-19-183 Biology of Bladder Cancer, which identifies “Mechanistic understanding of bladder cancer invasion and metastasis,” and “Developing and validating new human relevant models of bladder cancer” as key areas of interest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  The ability of HIV to escape from sub-optimal dosing of existing antiretroviral drugs and avoid neutralization by the immune system are two of the greatest challenges facing the development of effective strategies to control and eliminate infection. This proposal seeks to develop a novel class of drugs that can both neutralize HIV while simultaneously reducing the activity of addictive substances. Using this approach, we seek to create functional cure of HIV infection and substance use disorder with a single product administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative (3 sentences) Brain-body communication is crucial for maintaining tissue homeostasis and overall health. Studying how aging affects brain-body communication is important for finding ways to prevent age-related diseases and promote healthy aging. We aim to develop an interdisciplinary platform to unravel the intricate aging trajectories within the complex organism to uncover age-related changes in brain-body communication and develop personalized aging interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plant nectar-feeding is essential for survival and reproduction for many mosquito species, and mosquitoes locate sugar sources by using their sensitive olfactory system. Trap-and-kill systems that exploit the nectar-feeding behaviors have shown to be an effective control intervention, but we don't know which odorants in the plant scent that mosquitoes find attractive, or how they process this information in their olfactory system. Using Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, we will characterize the genes involved in the odorant reception of nectar source odors and determine the mechanisms by which this olfactory input is processed in the brain, thereby providing new attractant lures and tools for mosquito control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age reversal in an entire organism can postpone age-related diseases and enhance the well-being during the later stages of life. Our research has revealed that sexual planarians of Schmidtea mediterranea have evolved a natural solution to age reversal at the whole-body level, and here we propose to investigate the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms that drive age reversal. Successful completion of the project holds the promise of providing valuable insights to advance anti-aging medicine for humans.
