IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Benzodiazepines are frequently prescribed to adolescents and young adults, yet we lack key data on misuse, abuse, and overdose risk following benzodiazepine treatment and on what policies reduce benzodiazepine- related harms in young people. The proposed research will examine the risk of overdose and harmful substance use following benzodiazepine treatment and will evaluate whether state prescription drug monitoring program features are associated with a reduction in benzodiazepine-related harms and risky benzodiazepine prescribing. As more young people seek treatment for mental illness, it is of urgent public health importance to investigate the misuse and abuse potential of commonly prescribed pharmaceutical treatments and to consider modifiable factors, such as existing prescription drug monitoring programs, that can be leveraged to reduce harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all adolescents use social media sites, yet for a vulnerable subset of teens, social media use may increase risk for suicide. Given rising suicide rates among adolescents in recent years, it is critical to examine the reasons why social media use may be related to suicidal thoughts and attempts. Findings of this study will have the potential to inform future suicide intervention and prevention efforts that address the unique needs of adolescents in the digital age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative When a taste is placed on our tongues, we must recognize that a taste is on the tongue, identify that taste, decide whether it’s palatable or not, and then either swallow it or expel it. This thought process can be observed to play out in the firing of neurons in taste cortex, but evidence suggests that cortex doesn’t work alone. We will rigorously test how the amygdala (the seat of emotion in the brain) and hypothalamus (the center that controls hunger and thirst) work with cortex, and with one another, to make taste decisions happen, and how these decisions get implemented by motor circuits—adding to a systemic understanding of taste that will help us fight against a spectrum of feeding-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For more than 20 years we have studied the impact of cocaine use in African American people living with HIV (PLWH); from which two important findings are (1) cocaine accelerates coronary disease (CAD), and (2) a contingency management (CM) intervention reduces cocaine use and slows, even reverses CAD progression in PLWH. We now propose to study the impact of reduced cocaine use using this CM intervention on cognitive decline and associated structural and functional brain MRI measures in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Co-occurring substance use and HIV risk among people in carceral settings is a syndemic. Yet, gold standard interventions to stem adverse OUD outcomes and prevent HIV infection (e.g., pre-exposure prophylaxis, PrEP; and medications for opioid use disorder, MOUD, e.g., buprenorphine) have been underemployed in carceral and community re-entry settings. Therefore, we propose conducting a hybrid implementation-effectiveness type 2 study to optimize and test the efficacy of a long-acting injectable PrEP + buprenorphine (XR-B) co-located intervention in jail and prison settings located in Ending the Epidemic Sites in Maryland and Washington, DC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The tumor microenvironment (TME) in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is characterized by a dense and anergic stroma that inhibits vascular perfusion, suppresses immune function, and reduces tumor permeability to drugs and immune cells. We propose developing and evaluating a novel oncolytic virus modified to selectively deliver stroma-degrading enzymes to enhance the expression of neoantigens and increase tumor immunogenicity as well as immune cell infiltration. Currently, advanced PDAC patients have limited treatment options; thus, this project will address a critical unmet need for more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Angiogenesis is a key pathogenic component of obesity and at least 70 known diseases, and it is primarily driven by the vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR) and its family of VEGF ligands. However, targeting VEGF alone has not achieved the promise of stable vascular control, so new approaches are needed to control and direct vascular development. The purpose of these studies is to biologically and computationally assess how the new theory of cross- family signaling may control vascular signaling at the molecular, protein, and cellular levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence and prevalence of methamphetamine and other stimulant use disorders have been steadily increasing to epidemic proportions, with no approved drug treatments available. Fannin is developing a drug with a novel mechanism of action that reduces neuroinflammation and has shown therapeutic potential in animal models of cocaine-use disorder. Here, we propose to further advance the compound through testing in preclinical animal models and complete further testing to demonstrate safety and efficacy and to prepare for eventual clinical testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Corneal keratocytes play a central role in fundamental biological processes such as developmental morphogenesis, normal wound healing, and corneal scarring. In this proposal, we request supplemental funding to acquire a microscope stage CO2 incubator system that will allow us to perform live-cell analysis, time lapse imaging, and provide us with multi-modal information. The acquisition of this live-cell imaging system will allow us to characterize interactions between keratocytes and their microenvironment in real time, and provide unprecedented insights into the role of key biophysical signaling pathways on the differentiation of keratocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to improve a novel device to treat anxiety and drug use in subjects with opioid use disorder. The rationale for this proposal is predicated on the belief that non-invasive, non-pharmacological activation of peripheral sensory receptors by specific mechanical stimulation modulates brain substrates dysregulated by opioid use disorder. Our novel technology has much promise to target the brain mechanisms underlying the recreational use and abuse potential of opioids, and its development will pave the way for an FDA-approved de novo device to reverse dependence on opioids and save lives and resources throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study addresses a highly relevant public health question: how people living with HIV and affected by disaster access and remain engaged in HIV care. This study will take place in Ukraine, which continues to experience one of the highest HIV rates in Europe and has been devastated by Russia’s 2022 invasion and ongoing war. The information gained through this study has the potential to inform the development of policies and practices to help people living with HIV maintain access to care in contexts of instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addiction is a chronic, relapsing disorder that affects millions of people in the United States and worldwide, and yet no successful treatments have been developed. In the past years, the composition and type of bacteria that inhabit our gut (the gut microbiota) has emerged as a crucial regulator of brain maturation, function, and response to different diseases, including addiction; however, the mechanisms behind this communication remain mostly unknown. This project proposes a novel multidisciplinary approach directed to characterize clear and mechanistically defined interactions between the gut microbiota, psychostimulant use, and addiction, which can lead to the development of more successful evidence-based systemic interventions for treating this debilitating psychopathology. |Contact PD/PI: Cuesta, Santiago

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The experiments proposed aim to examine the neural mechanisms of active avoidance learning and explore how these mechanisms are modulated by fear extinction learning circuits. We will use a novel conditioning and avoidance paradigm to gather functional MRI and subjective reports data from healthy controls and from patients diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The anticipated impact is to enhance our understanding of the neural mechanisms of adaptive and maladaptive avoidance responses, reduce the translation gap in this area between rodents and human studies, and explore potential novel targets for advancing the treatment of PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The experiments proposed are aimed to understand how timing and location of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in humans will impact their ability to reduce conditioned fear responses and impact the activation of their brain regions involved in fear regulation. We will use a novel TMS approach to vary timing and location of its delivery so that we can characterize and establish best time and location to obtain optimal impact on fear inhibition, and then test these parameters in PTSD patients and see if such can rescue extinction deficits in PTSD. The anticipated impact is to enhance our understanding of the neural mechanisms of associated with TMS use and explore potential novel approaches for advancing PTSD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Summary This proposal is submitted in direct response to RFA-DA-23-021 Developing Regulated Therapeutic and Diagnostic Solutions for Patients Affected by Opioid and/or Stimulants use Disorders (OUD/StUD) (R43/R44). Persons of all ages with Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) are at risk for opioid overdose, which can cause Opioid Induced Respiratory Depression (OIRD), leading to hypoxia and death. Most overdose deaths in the U.S. occur without anybody else present, preventing bystander administration of the lifesaving drug naloxone. Technology to detect OIRD and issue an emergency signal could help ensure responders arrive at the scene of an overdose to administer naloxone in a timely fashion. Currently, there are no FDA-approved products to detect opioid overdose or OIRD that are designed for continuous wear in a discreet location on the body. Resilient Lifescience’s goal is to develop a wearable medical device that can detect OIRD and issue an emergency alert, calling a friend, loved one, or emergency medical service to the scene. The central hypothesis to test in this proposed work is that a patch-based wearable medical device worn on the abdomen will be effective at detecting OIRD in patients and will be a well-accepted form factor for use by individuals with OUD. The overall objective of Phase I in this proposal is to determine technical feasibility of the project by showing that the device is effective at measuring oxygen saturation using reflective photoplethysmography (PPG) on the abdomen and to demonstrate commercial viability of the product by showing that individuals with OUD will adhere to use of the product. Resilient Lifescience will do this by 1) completing feasibility research to evaluate the device’s ability to measure oxygen saturation using reflective PPG on the abdomen, 2) executing user-centered industrial design, and 3) demonstrating that opioid users will adhere to use of the device during a two-week pilot study. The overall objective of Phase II in this project is to de-risk the commercialization of the device by demonstrating that the device is suitable for manufacture, passes required compliance testing, and is effective at detecting OIRD within patients receiving opioid analgesia in a hospital setting. The research team will accomplish this by 1) reaching design-freeze and soliciting quotes for small batch production of the device, 2) testing the ability of the device to detect OIRD in a hospital setting, and 3) completing required electromagnetic compatibility, biocompatibility, ingress protection, and human factors testing for the device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amidst an explosive increase in overdose deaths linked to stimulants (e.g., cocaine, methamphetamine) along with fentanyl, it is unknown what proportion of deaths are due to unintentional exposure to fentanyl, particularly in people living with or at risk of HIV who have had relatively prevalent stimulant use alone. We propose a randomized controlled trial to test an innovative approach to opioid overdose prevention that repurposes a known injectable, long-acting opioid blocking medication (naltrexone) and when possible, couples it with injectable HIV prevention or treatment medication. Aiming to shield people living with or at risk of HIV who use stimulants from unintentional opioid exposure, this study seeks to combine overdose prevention with HIV care, addressing two critical health concerns in one integrated approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work on the development of two new mouse models of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and testing a new potential therapy (oral D-DHA) is important for protecting human health because AMD can cause loss of central vision. Current treatments are limited, especially for the advanced dry (geographic atrophy) form of the disease. If these mouse models are protected by D-DHA, this will also implicate DHA oxidation as a key pathogenic mechanism in the models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Viruses in the Reoviridae family infect a wide range of hosts, including animals, plants, fungi, and bacteria; within this family, rotaviruses cause 450,000 deaths worldwide each year, and BTV kills livestock, with devastating economic and social consequences. The proposed structural and functional studies focus on BTV and CPV to provide structural answers to fundamental questions of replication of these and other dsRNA viruses. The results will provide profound insight into the structural basis of dsRNA virus spread and inform rational development of anti-viral drugs and vaccines against these and other viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genome Center will lead the prioritization, recruitment, and selection of samples from study participants representing global diversity consented for open access data release. With those samples, we will produce 200 new, very high-quality haplotype-resolved, and annotated, human genome assemblies for inclusion in the human pangenome reference resource. We propose to complete this work with a team of ethical, legal and social implications (ELSI) scholars who will be embedded in our effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-use of fentanyl with xylazine, a sedative for which naloxone, the standard of care for opioid intoxication is ineffective, has reached crisis levels in the US, with xylazine-positive overdose deaths increasing by 1,127% in the South and over 100% in all other regions between 2020 and 2021. The proposed work addresses the urgent need for a reversal agent for combinations of fentanyl and xylazine, compatible with naloxone, that restores respiration and reverses xylazine-induced sedation. Such a therapeutic would save lives, improve patient outcomes, and relieve burden on already strained hospital resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Pregnancy is a "natural stress test" that may reveal higher cardiovascular disease (CVD) risks in early adulthood, thus providing opportunities for early prevention to alter the long-term trajectory of CVD in women. This project will provide the first comprehensive assessment of all major adverse pregnancy outcomes in relation to CVD risks across the life course in a large population-based cohort of 2.5 million women. The results will help improve women's health by identifying the long-term CVD risks associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes and guiding early prevention and long-term clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Component A – Project Narrative: Vaccine effectiveness is a measure of how well a particular vaccine protects people against infection, symptomatic illness, hospitalization, and death in a real-world condition. This research aims to provide accurate estimates of the effectiveness of influenza and COVID-19 vaccines against respiratory virus- associated illness in that population, in the context of varying social determinants of health disparities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, Platform to Assess Influenza and COVID-19 Vaccine Effectiveness in Underserved Arizona Populations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study seeks to understand how well the Influenza and COVID-19 vaccines work in a real-world setting and how their effectiveness is changed by factors related to the person, the specific vaccine or the most common type of virus. The study also examines what affects who gets infected at home when someone has an infection, and what might change that. The researchers will also look into the body response to the infection or the vaccine to help understand what can be done to lessen the risk of getting an infection.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, CORVETS - Cleveland Ohio Respiratory Viruses Vaccines Effectiveness across Traditional Risk Factors and Social Determinants of Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Component A: Michigan-Ford Initiative to Measure Vaccine Effectiveness (MFIVE): Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19, and Respiratory Virus Vaccines Timely monitoring of the effectiveness of influenza and COVID-19 vaccines in prevention of outpatient visits for acute respiratory infection is critical information for vaccine recommendations and preparation of new vaccines. We propose a platform for the monitoring of effectiveness overall, coupled with genomic data that will provide estimates for effectiveness against specific variants and strains.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004:Michigan-Ford Initiative to Measure Vaccine Effectiveness (MFIVE): Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19 and Respiratory Virus Vaccines

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR IMMUNIZATION AND RESPIRATORY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – Duke Human Vaccine Institute Influenza, SARS-CoV-2 and other viral respiratory pathogens lead to tens of millions of infections on an annual basis resulting in burdens on population health, healthcare, hospital systems, and the U.S. economy. Vaccines to prevent influenza have been widely available for decades, while vaccines to prevent COVID-19 vaccine have recently been deployed to combat the ongoing SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. The Duke Human Vaccine Institute will provide coordination for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s network designed to assess the effectiveness of respiratory virus vaccines, including both influenza and COVID-19 vaccines, at preventing symptomatic respiratory infection in the community setting.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-IP-22-004, US Platform to Measure Effectiveness of Seasonal Influenza, COVID-19 and other Respiratory Virus Vaccines for the Prevention of Acute Illness in Ambulatory Settings

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: COVID-19 may have long-term effects on violence through an under-appreciated channel: learning loss for children in school, particularly to low-income and minority children, leading the U.S. Secretary of Education to recommend that schools leverage high dosage tutoring - a scalable and reliable policy to increase learning - to address the problem. As previous research has shown a strong positive correlation between education and violence but evidence for actionable educational policies is scarce, we aim to tackle the basic science question of whether education affects violence involvement, as well as the policy question of whether academic remediation can prevent the expected long-term increase in violent crimes and victimization. Our University of Chicago research team in partnership with Chicago Public Schools aims to use several randomized control trials (RCTs) delivering high-dosage tutoring interventions, two of which were carried out in 2013-15 under ideal field conditions and an additional larger-scale trial that is currently underway, linked to administrative longitudinal data on violence-related outcomes (offending and victimization) to produce short- and longer-term experimental evidence of the violence-reducing effects of tutoring delivered at different scales to answer our research questions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-004: Experimental Evidence on the Effects of Academic Remediation on Violence

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to increase Medical Trust to lessen HIV prevention and treatment inequities experienced by HLMSM. The study will both uncover factors associated to medical mistrust and implement an intervention aimed at increasing medical trust in HIV prevention and care services. If successful, this study may inform future interventions, hence, potentially decreasing HIV inequities experienced by HLMSM.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-PS-23-006, De Confianza: Creating Medical Trust with Latinx Communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Oral squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) has a high recurrence rate that leads to poor patient survival. Tumor progression and recurrence rely on invasion of tumor cells away from the main tumor, so investigating mechanisms responsible for invasion are extremely important for identification of novel therapeutic targets that could improve survival. The objective of this project is to understand how SCC co-opts adjacent ‘normal’ epithelium to promote invasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relapsed and refractory Hodgkin lymphoma patients have few treatment options and overall survival remains low. Current genomic technologies struggle with cancers defined by rare malignant cell populations, leaving some cancer types poorly described - Hodgkin lymphoma is one such cancer. This proposal will address these shortfalls by using newly developed technologies and diverse sources of DNA to describe somatic variation and clonal architecture in relapse and refractory Hodgkin lymphoma.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Our team aims to discover molecular mechanisms by which certain patients with coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19) do very poorly. COVID-19 is a pandemic caused by infection with the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, which primarily damages the lungs but can also have devastating effects on the heart and circulation. Data from China, Europe and US indicate that underlying cardiovascular conditions, such as hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and coronary artery disease, lead to higher likelihood of getting COVID-19, more severe disease, and greater risk of death. These conditions are highly prevalent in the Veteran population, yet some Veterans with cardiovascular conditions have poor outcomes while others with similar conditions appear to be resilient. We propose to study blood samples from a bio repository at the Atlanta VA that banks blood left over from routine laboratory tests of COVID-19 patients. We will determine whether specific novel molecular markers in blood can predict susceptibility to poor outcomes and potentially become therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is the leading cause of nonatherothrombotic myocardial infarction in women under age 40 years, the etiology of ST-elevation myocardial infarction in 1 of 5 women under age 50 years, and a frequent cause of heart attack among pregnant women. Most patients with SCAD do not have traditional risk factors such as tobacco use, high cholesterol, diabetes, but rather, they have abnormalities in the peripheral arteries such as fibromuscular dysplasia, aneurysms, and dissections. The proposed aims of this proposal explore the vascular, autonomic, and myocardial phenotypes in women with SCAD and in doing so better understand pathophysiologic mechanisms, risk for disease, and ultimately guide approaches to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Among military veterans, substance abuse is a strong predictor of both subsequent healthcare utilization and mortality. For veterans who abuse heroin or other opioids, mental health conditions are highly prevalent. These include disorders of mood and anxiety. Although opioid abuse is an important health problem for both veterans and the general population, only limited medications are currently available for treating patients who are addicted to opioids. Melatonin is a hormone and neurotransmitter which plays a role in establishing daily and seasonal rhythms and may also contribute to perception of pain and drug addiction. This project will use an animal model of opioid addiction to determine how melatonin influences the brain mechanisms underlying perception of pain and addiction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This innovative project will study epigenomic modifications in cancer cells and their link to stemness and drug resistance. We hypothesize that treatment with platinum induces chromatin modifications promoting a cancer stem-like phenotype and vulnerability to epigenome modifiers. We propose to tackle this question by using next generation sequencing adapted to the study of rare cell populations, by focusing on the enzyme Dot1L and the target gene, FoxK2. Successful demonstration of this concept will provide the rationale for pursuing Dot1L inhibitors to restore response to platinum in ovarian cancer. We envision that this strategy will increase sensitivity to platinum and impact clinical outcomes. Our findings could be translated to other treatment- resistant solid tumors. As platinum-resistant cancer kills a significant number of US Veterans and military personnel, this project is highly relevant to the Department of Veterans Affairs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal cord injury (SCI) is among the most disabling conditions affecting wounded members of the US military. No effective treatment has been available for SCI veterans. Our goal is to understand how lumbar motoneurons (MNs) are altered caudal to a thoracic SCI and how a beneficial restorative treatment affects their Using an adult mouse T9 moderate contusive SCI model and an adeno-associated virus serotype 2 vector encoding NT-3 (AAV2-NT-3) gene transfer approach, we will determine the mechanism by which NT-3 improves recovery after SCI and long-term efficacy of the NT-3 treatment using a clinically feasible delivery route, and whether exercise training will enhance the effects of NT- 3, and how the functional role of specific descending pathways will affect lumbar MN neural circuitry and functional recoveries after an optimal treatment. This proposal will reveal the fundamental mechanism of NT- 3/exercise training on MN circuitry remodeling and also facilitate the development of new therapeutics for SCI. reorganization and functional consequences.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE U.S. Emergency Departments (ED) had approximately 145 million visits in 2016, a figure that has been steadily rising for the past twenty years.1,2,3 Twenty-five percent of the U.S. population visit the ED each year4, many of whom are the sickest and most vulnerable in the health care system,11 presenting with complex disease processes and high risks of adverse events. There is a specific need for emergency care clinicians and related health professionals to be trained as clinical and health services researchers to improve health outcomes and decrease preventable ED visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Motor deficits, such disturbances in voluntary fine motor skills, are associated with healthy aging as well as the pathological aging observed in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Despite overlapping phenotypes, age-related motor deficits in physiological (i.e., healthy) and pathological (e.g., AD) have traditionally been studied separately – thus, it is unknown if motor phenotypes and the underlying mechanisms present in healthy aging are distinct from those that precede AD cognitive symptoms. Through a combination of behavioral, molecular, and cellular reprogramming techniques, this project will specifically investigate the role of corticospinal neurons (the primary drivers of voluntary fine motor control and the only direct output from the cortex to the spinal cord) in fine motor decline of healthy aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lung transplantation is an effective short-term treatment for patients with end-stage pulmonary disease, but long- term outcomes are disappointing. Chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) is the most important immune- mediated complication after lung transplantation, representing the leading cause of late death in lung transplant recipients. This proposal will integrate two large existing NIH-funded lung transplant datasets and apply innovative statistical methods to define CLAD progression patterns and inform the design of future CLAD treatment studies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Parkinson’s disease is the most common neurodegenerative movement disorder of the elderly, affecting over four million people worldwide, and is responsible for significant health care dollar expenditures annually. This disease afflicts a disproportionately large number of US Veterans based on factors such as advancing age, male gender, and exposure to certain toxins, all of which are associated with increased risk for the disease. Progress toward effective treatment has been hindered by the lack of a biomarker that can diagnose and distinguish Parkinson’s disease from related neurodegenerative conditions. The proposed research will detect pathogenic forms of the protein alpha-synuclein in the blood of patients with Parkinson’s and related diseases, with the ultimate goal of expanding diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic options for affected US Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project delineates essential and fundamental molecular pathways that are conserved throughout eukaryotes, including humans. Understanding these pathways and how they are integrated with other cellular pathways will provide the intellectual underpinning for investigators carrying out translational research. Defects in these pathways of ribosome assembly lead to human diseases, including Acute T-cell lymphoblastic leukemia and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposal addresses basic health issues since kidney disease causes untold suffering and kills more Veterans than many cancers. Ischemic injury to the kidney results in acute kidney injury, progression of chronic renal disease to end stage kidney disease and transplant failure; yet there is currently no specific treatment. This proposal aims to define mechanisms of protection and potential treatments with the ultimate goal of effective therapies to improve the lives of Veterans and other patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal application will support the core infrastructure and follow-up of the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (HPFS), a cancer epidemiology cohort of 51,529 male health professionals ongoing since 1986. The cohort includes biennial questionnaires, cancer outcomes, and mortality information linked with biospecimens: plasma, red cells, germline DNA, toenail samples, and tumor tissue. With additional follow-up, particularly after cancer diagnosis, the cohort remains ideally positioned to make innovative contributions to the overall goal of reducing the burden of cancer and identifying primary and secondary prevention strategies.

PHR: Project narrative: We have identified novel roles of eukaryotic-line serine/threonine kinase (eSTK) signaling pathway that controls β-lactam resistance in Staphylococcus aureus through classical and non-classical mediators. β-lactams are important drugs for treating S. aureus infections, but resistance to these drugs often complicates treatment. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant infections are rapidly spreading and taking a staggering toll in all healthcare systems including the VA Healthcare system. Of critical importance, there are few approved antibacterial drugs currently available to treat many Gram-negative bacterial infections and few new drugs in the pipeline. The most difficult to treat pathogens are the Gram-negative bacteria that are resistant to all antibiotics (so called “Superbugs” containing NDM and KPC enzymes). Most worrisome is their resistant to Imipenem, the “last line” agent that is used in the most serious cases. We have also found that some Superbugs are also resistant to the recently developed drugs just released (e.g., Avibactam). Even new drugs being developed are at risk. We are taking new approaches based on basic research to understand why resistance to Imipenem and Avibactam occurs in KPC and how resistance to cephalosporins can further emerge in NDMs. We have been extremely fortunate to have built a program that has been at the forefront of new drug resistance research in the VA for nearly 20 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parasite resistance to artemisinin with a validated mutation in the pfkelch13 (k13) gene has been found in Rwanda. Given that all front line antimalarial combination therapies for treating Plasmodium falciparum in Africa rely on artemisinin, this portends serious setbacks for the large-scale efforts aiming to control and eliminate this disease. We will use large-scale genomics, experimental systems, and mathematical modeling to map and study the spread of resistance overtime, and, together, these studies will improve our understanding of the biology and evolution of this resistance in Africa, help us to predict its spread and allow development of interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sophisticated synthetic gene circuits have been designed and constructed for clinical applications, such as treating infectious diseases and cancer. However, the substantial heterogeneity resulting from the interactions between the gene circuit and host cells significantly affects the functional robustness of engineered gene circuits. Our proposed studies aim to quantify, characterize, and control heterogeneity in the host-aware synthetic gene circuits and make the circuits operate as desired in a complicated real-world environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative It is clear that new approaches for the detection of the etiologic antigen(s) in sarcoidosis are needed. Using bronchoalveolar lavage cells from sarcoidosis patients from the United States, this proposal will extend our current level of understanding of the role of CD4+ T cells in the initiation and progression of sarcoidosis. The identification of sarcoidosis antigens could lead to earlier diagnosis and more directed therapeutic intervention that would directly impact the health of affected individuals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bleeding disorders in women are an under-recognized and under-treated condition, and von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is the most common bleeding disorder diagnosed in women. This study will develop a screening algorithm for VWD that incorporates a brief bleeding history and point-of-care iron level. We will test the algorithm's validity, acceptability, and feasibility in primary care settings.

PHR: Narrative This application is aimed at augmenting Medication for Opioid Use Disorder (MOUD) usual care with a time- limited wraparound intervention called “Maintaining Independence and Sobriety through Systems Integration, Outreach, and Networking (MISSION) specifically for individuals with co-occurring opioid addiction and mental illness given that they have high rates of treatment discontinuation and poor outcomes. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnostic tools, such as prenatal ultrasound and prenatal gene sequencing, have the capability to increase our understanding of fetal brain abnormalities (FBA). By intersecting human prenatal sequencing, bioinformatics filters to identify novel candidate genes, and functional modeling in an animal model, we aim to identify novel candidate genes specific to FBA; additionally, we will perform whole genome sequencing on a prospective cohort with FBA to increase our understanding of diagnostic yield and genotypes/phenotypes in a well characterized cohort. Our findings will shed light on the molecular underpinnings of human brain development and has the potential to improve pre- and postnatal counseling/management, and lead to novel preventive and therapeutic strategies that can be applied in the perinatal period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death and disability in industrialized nations and its prevalence is rising rapidly in developing nations. Current therapies for cardiovascular disease are aimed at treating the symptoms rather than repairing the damaged myocardial tissue. This proposal aims to elucidate the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms of the cardiac regenerative response in order to strategically design new potential therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed at a rate of four males to one female; however as research has identified and included more females, a number of important differences have emerged between males and females. The majority of prior research has only studied autistic males and females at one timepoint, therefore there is a critical gap in our understanding of the early developmental trajectories of autistic females that can only be addressed through longitudinal research. This R01 will address this need and examine how autistic males and females differ in early childhood (4 to 8 years) using a novel longitudinal design and across measurement approaches to understand early sex differences and gender diversity in ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: During times of severe illness, the kidneys can suffer injury and stop functioning. As the patient improves, the cells in the kidney can regenerate and restore kidney function, a process that requires macrophages to change from a pro-injury state to a pro-repair state. This grant studies how those macrophages change to a repair state, and what signals they use to help kidney repair so that we can develop better therapies to restore kidney function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rotaviruses are one of the most important causes of severe diarrheal illness in infants and young children. Despite the availability of multiple vaccines, rotavirus gastroenteritis is responsible for an estimated 215,000 deaths every year. Our proposed studies of rotavirus-host entry factor interactions will facilitate the rational design of novel vaccines and therapeutics against rotavirus, thereby reducing the overall infection-associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: CRISPR/Cas systems are exponentially growing as gene and RNA editing and detection technologies with a huge potential for applications in diagnosis and treatment of a range of genetic diseases. The proposed research will lead to the discovery, understanding, and engineering CRISPR/Cas systems to solve challenging issues of lower efficiency, poor specificity, and lack of control. A deeper understanding and development of next generation of CRISPR/Cas technologies for diagnosis and treatment of diseases would have a transformative impact to a wider research community across multiple disciplines, institutes and centers of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute exposure to nerve agents induces status epilepticus (SE), which compounds the peripheral cholinergic crisis, leading to death or significant brain damage and long-term neurological morbidities. Treatment of nerve agent-induced SE with diazepam—the anticonvulsant approved by the FDA for this indication— or midazolam, which is considered to be a better alternative to diazepam and may soon replace it, does not exert good control of SE and has minimal neuroprotective effects. We have discovered an antiglutamatergic therapy to suppress hyperexcitability and excitotoxicity—consisting of LY293558, an AMPA/GluK1 receptor antagonist, and caramiphen, an antimuscarinic compound that also antagonizes NMDA receptors—which provides full neuroprotection in immature rats, administered 1 h after soman exposure, and we are proposing to test the antiseizure and neuroprotective efficacy of this two-component combination therapy in young-adult and aged male and female rats exposed to soman, in comparison with the corresponding efficacy of midazolam.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes is the fastest growing epidemic in the western world and is characterized by high levels of blood sugar, which reacts non-enzymatically with cellular proteins in a process called glycation. We recently found that glycation specifically accumulates on histones, inducing significant changes in chromatin architecture and subsequent cellular transcription. The proposed research project will comprehensively examine the molecular mechanisms of histone glycation, elucidate its contribution to abrogated chromatin structure and function, and finally characterize repair mechanisms that will open new avenues for therapeutic development in both diabetes and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative This application aims to apply an award-winning pipeline to construct the largest-scale knowledge graph (KG) to date using all PubMed abstracts and PubMed Central full-text articles. Applications that are previously infeasible will then be developed on top of the KG including KG-based knowledge visualization, knowledge navigation and knowledge discovery. As our model is able to distinguish between new discoveries and background knowledge in scientific articles, we will also develop novel tools taking advantages of this new capability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) affects approximately 16 million Americans, and is characterized by recurrent exacerbations that lead to 1.5 million Emergency Department visits and 700,000 hospitalizations annually. Pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) is a structured program of exercise and self- management support that has been proven to relieve shortness of breath and increase quality of life when initiated after an exacerbation, but unfortunately, few eligible patients participate. This project will compare the effectiveness of two novel strategies – one involving video narratives of other patients telling their story of how they overcame challenges and completed PR, the other involving telephonic peer coaching – to enhanced usual care, and to each other, at increasing patient participation in PR after an exacerbation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Research regarding the dopaminergic system, which is highly involved in reward, voluntary motor behavior, and substance use disorders, has long focused on neurons. With evidence that microglia can modulate neuronal activity and the discovery of a novel subpopulation of microglia expressing the dopamine receptor DRD1 by our lab, support for a glial axis of dopaminergic regulation is mounting. In this proposal, I will use transgenic mouse models to investigate the determinants of microglial DRD1 expression and how it impacts the neuronal response in two instances of sustained changes in dopamine levels: juvenile dopaminergic development and chronic cocaine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research on the impact of alcohol outlet density on alcohol consumption has recently remained stalled due to the mixed results of ecological and individual-level studies, in addition to the lack of clarity regarding the threshold effects of every additional alcohol outlet added to an area. We propose to create a responsive buffer — a new measurement of individuals’ exposure to the alcohol environment that is responsive to documented individual-level and neighborhood-level characteristics — to advance studies on alcohol outlet density. A new measurement of the alcohol environment has critical implications for establishment of the relationship of alcohol outlet density and alcohol consumption, which will therefore directly inform environmental prevention efforts, like licensing and zoning, to reduce alcohol consumption and improve population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the retina, opsin molecules that capture light are housed within disc-shaped membranes stacked in the outer segment compartment of photoreceptor neurons. Many inherited retinal diseases are caused by defects in formation of the disc membranes within the outer segment, leading to photoreceptor cell death and human blindness. The purpose of this proposal is to investigate components that contribute to forming these disc membranes to better understand the pathogenesis of inherited retinal degeneration and identify potential treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA molecules play fundamental roles in transmitting and regulating genetic information in all living systems, including disease-causing bacteria, RNA viruses like HIV and SARS-CoV-2, tumor cells, and our own brains and bodies. New potentially life-saving therapies and vaccines that target or repurpose these RNAs are being hindered by our imperfect understanding of how RNAs fold into intricate 3D structures. Our work aims to develop new 3D-structure-focused tools that are missing in current RNA biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The microfold cell (M cell) is known to be a central actor in regulating mucosal inflammation in barrier organs but has received almost no attention in the lung. We now show that lung M cells can be induced by airway inflammation and by viral infection. We seek to define the functional roles of these understudied cells in the setting of lung inflammation and infection so that we can lay a foundation for designing new therapies targeting inflammatory and infectious diseases of the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it interrogates how immune aging impairs functional response to vaccination and how dysregulation of CD4+ T cells drives advanced immune aging, leveraging Down syndrome as a genetic model. This knowledge would establish the foundation to identify the patients, both with and without Down syndrome, who would benefit from altered vaccination strategies, and novel therapeutics to attenuate advanced immune aging, with likely utility across a broad spectrum of immune- related conditions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission pertaining to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chediak-Higashi Syndrome (CHS) patients show enlarged lysosome-related organelles (LROs) resulting from either excessive fusion or inhibited fission of vesicles together with defects in microtubule and centrosome behavior at the immunological synapse. LRO biogenesis is highly conserved in Drosophila, allowing us to exploit its genetic and molecular cell biological advantages to study both vesicle trafficking and microtubule and centrosome behavior in the oocyte and embryo. This will illuminate the controversial role of the protein encoded by the gene mutated in CHS not only in the LRO, but importantly also in centrosome and microtubule behavior and will thereby unlock possibilities for developing drugs to treat CHS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell anemia is an inherited blood disorder with enormous global burden of disease, especially within sub-Saharan Africa, where it causes severe morbidity and high early mortality. We are conducting a large research study (REACH) for children with sickle cell anemia living in four African countries to test the safety, feasibility, and benefits of hydroxyurea treatment in this setting, and to better understand the scientific and genetic reasons why children respond differently to hydroxyurea treatment. We will now investigate the long-term benefits of hydroxyurea treatment as these children enter puberty, focusing on prevention of organ damage and trying to understand the basis for malaria protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The cognitive diversity of the biomedical workforce must grow to maximize scientific innovation and enhance U.S. global competitiveness in addressing human health concerns. This growth can be achieved, in part, through greater inclusion of individuals from specific racial and ethnic groups, with physical disabilities, and from challenging socioeconomic backgrounds that are currently significantly underrepresented (UR) in the biomedical sciences. The goal of our program, Purdue PREP, is to enhance the cognitive diversity of the biomedical workforce by increasing the number of college graduates from UR backgrounds that successfully enter and complete a Ph.D. or dual- doctoral degree program in translational biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Bladder cancer screening by cytopathologists is difficult and prone to high interobserver variability, and to combat this I developed the AutoParis machine learning algorithm as a quantitative diagnostic aid to help the cytopathologist render the correct diagnosis according to the gold standard Paris System for Urine Cytology. But before AutoParis is ready for clinical deployment it must: have its training set expanded, be retrained in a more flexible framework (Pytorch), have a graphical user interface, and be proven non-inferior / superior to standard cytological bladder cancer screening in a head-to-head comparison. This career development award will enable me to gain the necessary computer programming skills so I can advance the AutoParis system to the clinical deployment stage, thus enabling significantly more quantitative and reliable bladder cancer diagnoses (especially in resource-poor areas of the US and the world) and paving the way for other algorithmic diagnostic systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are substantial gaps in our understanding of the role of the tumor microenvironment, the interaction of tumor cell types and their specific responses to cancer therapies. Mass spectrometry-based proteomics enables deep molecular profiling of protein expression that is invaluable for cancer research, diagnosis and therapy evaluation, but it has lacked the sensitivity and throughput to extend these measurements to the single-cell level for large-scale experiments. We will develop a novel platform for in-depth single-cell profiling that combines nanodroplet sample preparation with ultrahigh-performance and multiplexed liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry with a measurement throughput of hundreds of cells per day, which will greatly accelerate cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Pediatric germ cell tumors (GCTs) are cancers that affect approximately 600 children and adolescents per year in the United States. Survival rates are high for GCTs due to the effectiveness of platinum-based chemotherapy; additional molecular analyses may help inform treatment decisions for the subgroup of patients with poor outcomes. Little is known about why these types of cancers develop, and our analyses evaluating the role of genetic variation may shed some insight into the causes of GCT.

PHR: Neurological diseases and stroke affect the extracellular space among neurons. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Roads and neighborhoods with a built environment that support safe and active transportation are a major priority in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) due to 90% of road traffic deaths occurring in these locations, especially to pedestrians and other vulnerable road users, yet data on key built environment features at a large scale are not always readily available in these settings. My career goal is to improve population health by examining the effects of the built environment and transportation on health through the adoption and use of methods that can leverage Big Data sources and answer complex, multilevel research questions by overcoming the lack of built environment data in LMICs. The proposed research uses deep learning and advanced statistical methods to create a citywide dataset of built and social environment features in Bogota, Colombia that will provide crucial data to answer questions of their impact on pedestrian injuries and deaths, as well as assessing the presence of health inequities in their distribution and that will lay the groundwork to expand these efforts to more cities in Latin America and other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrations/Public Health Relevance There is an urgent need to develop and evaluate stress management interventions in Black adults with asthma to help improve asthma medication adherence and asthma control and reduce asthma disparities. In this study, I will develop and evaluate a new stress management intervention, called CALM, that is designed to help Black adults cope with common stressors such as psychosocial issues, difficulty managing their asthma, and financial difficulty. By helping Black adults with asthma manage their stress we can potentially improve their quality of life and prevent asthma attacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gut malrotation is a birth defect of abnormal intestinal rotation that occurs once in 500 live births, and predisposes affected babies to volvulus, a catastrophic strangulation of the intestine and its blood supply. Making use of the accessibility of the chicken egg, genetic mouse models, and force measurements we have developed the tools to answer fundamental questions surrounding correct gut rotation, focused here on the molecules governing physical forces that shape the intestine and pattern gut vasculature. Our work will reveal how the gut rotates and why this process fails, with the goal to improve diagnosis and increase survival in neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Gust is proposing a career development program to become a translational clinician-scientist who works on improving the brain health of children and young adults with cancer. In this project, she will use a mouse model to examine the causes of life-threatening neurotoxicity that occurs during cancer immunotherapy with chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells. The results from this work will pave the way toward better strategies to prevent and treat CAR T cell neurotoxicity, which will make this revolutionary therapy safer and decrease the need for toxic chemotherapy and radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Second only to joint replacement and spinal fusion surgeries, procedures to repair tendon and other soft connective tissues represent ~20% (~2.5 million) of all major musculoskeletal procedures. The incomplete understanding of the complex cellular and molecular processes in tendon injury has hindered the development of biological therapies for regenerative tendon repair. This proposal develops a human microphysiological system to elucidate the roles of inflammation and fibrosis in this pathology and enable evaluation of safety and efficacy of disease-modifying treatments to inform clinical trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because leveraging a social media platform to increase awareness among individuals eligible for lung cancer screening is a novel untapped platform to reach vulnerable, high-risk individuals. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the cancer research mission of the National Cancer Institute and, more broadly, the National Institutes of Health’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of individuals and the application of that knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability through early detection of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Log2Lose is a clinical trial that seeks to evaluate whether people lose more weight when they  receive small financial incentives for weekly weight loss or diet logging. Study software collects  and analyzes weight data from a cellular-connected scale and dietary data from a smartphone dietary  application ('app'). Algorithms analyze these data to determine if participants meet the criteria  to receive an incentive. Participants receive a text message about whether they earned an  incentive, and, if so, receive payment on a debit card.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is a hereditary and progressive heart disease that can cause cardiac dysfunction, fatal ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, affecting as many as 1:1000 Americans. To date, there is an unmet need for effective treatment of patients with ARVC. This proposal identifies a new mechanism underlying the disease and will lead to novel breakthrough therapeutics that improve quality and life expectancy for patients with the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is the deadliest of the common cancers and one of commonest causes of cancer death. Detecting pancreatic cancer at an early stage greatly improves survival from pancreatic cancer. We propose to evaluate a tumor marker gene blood test for pancreatic cancer early detection in a clinical trial and to evaluate other promising tests aimed at improving the early detection of pancreatic cancer in patients with an increased susceptibility undergoing pancreatic surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Populations Underrepresented in Mental illness Association Studies (PUMAS) Project will collect samples from 17,000 individuals with severe mental illness from across African and the Americas to create a total sample dataset of 183,000 from across Africa and the Americas. We will generate and analyze whole genome sequencing data on 40,000 schizophrenia patients, 40,000 bipolar patients and 40,000 controls to learn the similarities and differences of the genetic architecture of severe mental illness across diverse ancestries and environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will design an ingestible electronic device that can non-invasively modulate the activity of sensory neurons in the gut. Using pig models, ingestible device with flexible electrodes will pace nerves that innervate the gut while brain activity will be recorded using fMRI. If successful, ingestible devices that modulate the gut- brain axis can serve as a platform technology to better understand and treat digestive and metabolic diseases including obesity and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In spite of the rates of sleep disturbance in spousal bereavement and its detrimental impact on mental and physical health, it is currently unknown whether interventions aimed at improving sleep in this population are either feasible or effective. This study will develop a targeted behavioral intervention for sleep disturbance among spousally bereaved adults and test it for feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects. Given the efficacy of behavioral treatment for sleep disturbance in other populations, this intervention shows great promise for reducing sleep disturbance and thereby improving related mental and physical health outcomes following the death of a spouse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Strokes, which are a leading cause of serious long-term disability, frequently result in the development of compensatory behavioral strategies that can encourage disuse of impaired modalities and contribute to persisting dysfunction. This project will advance understanding of neural mechanisms underlying the influence of compensatory behaviors on persisting disability after stroke and potential strategies for overcoming it, which is significant for informing efforts to optimize and tailor post-stroke interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Log2Lose is a clinical trial that seeks to evaluate whether people lose more weight when they receive small financial incentives for weekly weight loss or diet logging. Study software collects and analyzes weight data from a cellular-connected scale and dietary data from a smartphone dietary application (‘app’). Algorithms analyze these data to determine if participants meet the criteria to receive an incentive. Participants receive a text message about whether they earned an incentive, and, if so, receive payment on a debit card.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a common mental disorder which is poorly understood and inadequately treated. Research investigating alternative pathways involved in the etiology and pathogenesis of MDD are important to identify novel therapies to reduce the burden of this disease. In this study, we identify mechanisms by which changes in the gut microbiome contribute to changes in the production of microbial metabolites and alter signaling to the brain in the hopes of identifying novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Narrative Behavioral treatments for alcohol use disorder are generally effective, yet there is a need to improve treatments’ effect size and reduce relapse rate through theoretically-informed adjunctive approaches. The results of this study are expected to lead to the development of a technology assisted intervention to standard outpatient alcohol treatment designed to increase engagement in rewarding substance-free activities that can compete as alternatives to drinking. If efficacy of this intervention is established, this low-cost and accessible intervention has the potential to be incorporated in standard alcohol treatment to improve treatment outcomes such as reduced risk for relapse and other negative consequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Current treatments for medication related osteonecrosis of the jaw (MRONJ), a serious side effect of antiresorptive medications that can result in devastating pain and morbidity, are mostly empirical and often require major surgery. In this application, we investigate early changes during MRONJ, with the ultimate goal of uncovering mechanistic pathways that lead in MRONJ pathogenesis. Our research could lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches that can reduce the incidence, severity, and progression of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cholera is a devastating diarrheal illness responsible for severe morbidity and mortality in developing countries around the world. These proposed studies will characterize Vibrio cholerae-gut microbiome interactions during V. cholerae infection, with the goal of better understanding V. cholerae stress responses and pathogenesis and, potentially, discovering novel treatment and prophylactic interventions for cholera.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Short stature is a major symptom of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), a genetic bone disorder; however the mechanism of developing growth deficiency remains unknown. In this proposal, we will determine whether dysfunction of cartilage cells plays a critical role in growth deficiency of OI. The outcome of the proposed studies will advance our understanding of the pathogenesis underlying growth impairment and lead to the development of novel therapies to remedy growth deficiency in OI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cranial trauma, tumor invasion, cerebrovascular disease, and brain surgeries all can cause defects to the dura mater. Xenogeneic grafts, when properly treated and handled, have the potential to preserve the overall architecture of the matrix and provide enhanced structural support. This study aims to answer the question “Do acellular xenogeneic dura grafts elicit a less deleterious immune response than naturally derived commercial grafts and maintain structural integrity over the long term for in vivo studies?”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Between 81,000 and 138,000 people die each year from snakebite envenomation, and up to 400,000 are left permanently disabled, making snakebite envenomation a major risk to global health. Currently available antivenoms require correctly identifying the snake species, have a short shelf-life, cause unwanted side effects, and are targeted only to individual species. This proposal will develop a universal, thermostabilized, broad- spectrum, human-derived antivenom capable of treating snakebite envenomation from multiple species, in the field, through intramuscular dosing, using dual chamber syringes or auto-injectors, thereby increasing protection in populations such as the U.S. military and rural communities worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term learning and memory systems known to be crucial for the acquisition of complex skills are an almost completely untapped route to understanding the mechanisms and specific factors that lead to better math outcomes crucial to individual prosperity and well-being. We propose an accelerated, repeated-measures longitudinal project examining how neurocognitive measures of specific long-term memory systems contribute to learning-related changes in specific math outcomes in 1st through 5th grade children at multiple levels of analyses (brain and behavior). By revealing specific, directional links between memory and math systems, this work will also help determine which memory systems would be most effective targets for future randomized controlled trials, thereby increasing the probability of developing successful interventions aimed at improving outcomes in children with and without math learning difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Mucosal alterations in the microbiome and chronic local inflammation are believed to play major roles in the development of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and other autoimmune diseases in humans. Studies of this process have identified specific mucosal changes which appear to drive the earliest phases of autoimmunity and eventually result in tissue destruction. This proposal will support studies of the mucosal phenotypes present that appear causally related to rheumatic and autoimmune disease initiation and evolution in cohorts of informative subjects. These tasks will be accomplished through access to data and biolological samples, as well as enrichment programs and pilot grants to facilitate the interest and development of early career investigators who will make important discoveries going forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In day-to-day life, we must select actions by envisioning the likely outcomes of our behaviors. The capacity for this prospective decision making improves during adolescent development, on the one hand, and is imperiled by addictive drugs on the other. This proposal will help to understand the developmental-biological factors controlling goal-seeking behavior; new information could ultimately help combat drug misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Congenital heart disease is a leading cause of neonatal death and long-term morbidity, including a significant risk of neurodevelopmental impairments. The placenta in pregnancies complicated by moderate and severe fetal heart disease is functionally impaired with a significantly higher burden of pathologic lesions compared to placentas from healthy pregnancies. The connection between the placenta and the developing fetal brain has been elucidated by many recent studies, and this project seeks to understand the influence of placental blood flow on brain development in fetuses with moderate and severe forms of congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis describes a severe illness caused by infection, and in sub-Saharan African settings, such as Tanzania, sepsis is a common and deadly reason for admission to hospital. Using clinical data and blood samples from Tanzanian adult patients with sepsis, this project will identify the key patient characteristics and the key markers in the bloodstream that will enable classification of sepsis into subtypes that reflect the different biological pathways that lead to the severe illness. By understanding these underlying pathways, this project will advance our progress towards better management strategies tailored to sepsis subtypes, and improved management will eventually lead to decreased risk of death and disability due to sepsis in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphoma survivors are increasingly experiencing morbidity and mortality due to cardiovascular events that often result from the anthracycline-based chemotherapy used to treat their cancer. Our team of experienced investigators will test the utility of a patient-centric, individually tailored physical activity intervention implemented throughout chemotherapy to attenuate physical inactivity, reduce fatigue, and preserve exercise capacity, cardiac and cognitive function, strength, and health-related quality of life: all metrics that associate with or reduce cardiovascular risk. By fostering a lifestyle that maintains or increases physical activity and exercise capacity, this project seeks to reduce overall cardiovascular morbidity and mortality of lymphoma survivors and thereby improve their overall survival and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal tau protein in the brain in which patients can present with a number of different clinical syndromes. In this longitudinal study we will determine whether the different progressive supranuclear palsy syndromes show different patterns of abnormalities on brain imaging and different distributions of tau at autopsy. The findings will improve our understanding of the neurobiology of these syndromes and will be critically important to allow the appropriate targeting and monitoring of future therapies for progressive supranuclear palsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: UTMB OAIC PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) The University of Texas Medical Branch Claude D. Pepper Older Americans Independence Center (UTMB OAIC) will identify the pathways that lead to functional loss with aging and translate these discoveries into interventions for the promotion of functional recovery and independence in the growing diverse population of older Americans. The UTMB OAIC will use its highly productive and integrated research and training infrastructure to ignite new research, develop novel methodologies, support externally funded research, develop and support new collaborations with other programs and train the future leaders in aging research and geriatrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tools to help physicians tailor treatments to match the biologic aggressiveness and drug sensitivity of each patient’s breast cancer are urgently needed to achieve precision medicine. The proposed research will lay the groundwork for translating a new functional imaging-based, non-invasive approach to assess early response to neoadjuvant endocrine therapy for patients with hormone receptor positive primary breast cancer. A direct method of measuring functional endocrine sensitivity is relevant to the NIH’s mission and is expected to have significant clinical impact by better informing decisions for optimal, individualized therapy and ultimately by reducing breast cancer morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative / Relevance  One of the longstanding mysteries concerning human memory is how the brain organizes and recalls memories of past experiences. Cognitive theories of memory search and retrieval propose that each memory is encoded into its own unique situational context, that the context of a memory is updated each time we retrieve it, and that this context information guides memory search. The proposed research will combine computational modeling approaches with analysis of direct brain recordings in neurosurgical patients, as well as non-invasive recordings in healthy adults, to bridge these cognitive theories of memory with the neural mechanisms underlying this vital human ability.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal seeks to identify the critical physicochemical and structural attributes of a variety of rectal and vaginal semi-solid dosage forms and to develop suitable in vitro performance test methods and method validation strategies for such drug products. This will facilitate the development of in vitro comparative characterization-based bioequivalence approaches for locally-acting rectal and vaginal semi-solid drug products. As a consequence of the proposed research, the regulatory burden will be reduced and the public access to high quality and cost-effective topical rectal and vaginal drug products will be improved.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: In Vitro Based Approaches to Evaluate the Bioequivalence of Locally-Acting Rectal and Vaginal Semi-Solid Drug Products

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an incurable, aging-associated, and fatal fibrotic lung disease associated with lung epithelial cell damage and abnormal activation of lung fibroblasts and myofibroblasts. The development of therapies for IPF relies on the comprehensive understanding of lung fibrosis resolution pathways. The studies in this proposal will elucidate the role of ubiquitin E3 ligase Nedd4L in BMP4/BMPRII-mediated myofibroblast de-differentiation and fibrosis resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol is a significant problem in HIV care; novel intervention strategies are needed to decrease alcohol use and improve co-morbid psychological symptoms among people with HIV (PWH). The goal of this application is to conduct a remote, randomized clinical trial (RCT) of a brief, telephone-delivered Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) intervention to determine its efficacy relative to a standard brief alcohol intervention (BI). If successful, this intervention will have broad implications for implementation in HIV and other integrated care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are non-neuronal cells which are critical components of cortical circuits underlying learned behavior, yet their mechanistic role in modulating synapses to influence neuronal and circuit plasticity is poorly understood. We will use high-resolution imaging of astrocyte and neuronal activity in motor cortex of behaving mice learning a skilled movement, combined with computational analyses and state-of-the-art tools for modulating astrocyte function, to define how astrocytes influence learning in motor cortex circuits. These findings will provide insight into how dysregulation of astrocyte function may influence brain dysfunction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The proposed project seeks to determine best practices for recruiting and engaging women living in the Deep South who are vulnerable to HIV infection into a digital cohort, with the goal of evaluating factors that contribute to STI and HIV infection and HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis use. Outcomes from this study will help identify gaps in Ending the HIV Epidemic initiatives in reaching Southern women at highest risk for acquiring HIV and guide future intervention development. This project is responsive to national priorities outlined by the Ending the HIV Epidemic initiative as well as the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases AWARE funding opportunity announcement.
